The Nasdaq was down more than 1%, then quickly bounced back as it became clear that a merchant ship seized by Iran did not have Americans on board. The composite closed with a loss of 0.1%. Interestingly, it found support near the 5,000 level.…
Finding too many attractive stocks isn't a bad problem to have. But being too active could be damaging to a portfolio.

Trying to hop in and out of a stock repeatedly in order to chase potential profits or protect your capital may sound like a good strategy. Some investors may keep jumping from one stock to the next because they keep finding new compelling ideas.
But by doing so, they might miss a stock's major move — often a minimum gain of 20% to 25%. It can take a lot of trades and many small gains to rack up a 20% return.
And even if trading commissions are a fraction of what they used to cost in the past, they can still add up .
Still, others may engage in day trading, which involves buying and selling multiple stocks on the same day. Most investors lose money doing this, IBD founder and Chairman William O'Neil says. Why?

"The reason is simple: You are dealing predominantly with minor daily fluctuations that are harder to read than basic trends over a longer time period," he writes in "How to Make Money in Stocks." "Don't try to make money so fast. Rome wasn't built in a day."

Overtrading can also leave investors vulnerable to trading during tough times in the market, such as a correction or whipsaw activity. And juggling too many stocks may dilute precious time that investors could otherwise use to research the best stocks in the market.

Instead of spreading your capital around in multiple stocks, target only the leading candidates and make sure the market is behaving properly. The best time to buy stocks is when a confirmed uptrend starts.

IBD offers readers plenty of resources for stock ideas in The IBD 50, Stocks On The Move, Stock Spotlight and other lists and columns. Many of the stocks featured in these sections meet certain fundamental and technical criteria.

Create a watch list from these leading stocks, then continue to follow earnings reports and other news, and keep track of their price action on the daily and weekly charts. Many of these are stocks that have the potential to rise upward of 20%.

The chart above shows the potential gains that can be had if you focus on one or two leaders. FleetCor Technologies (FLT) broke out from a cup base in August 2013 and surged 117% in 10 months before pausing to start a new base. (Watch a case study of Fleetcor's run.)

Read The Big Picture and the accompanying Market Pulse every day to stay on top of what's going on in the market. The Market Pulse shows if the market is in a confirmed uptrend, if the uptrend is under pressure or if the market is weak and in a correction.

Breakouts tend to work best during a confirmed uptrend. Start by concentrating your buying power in one or two high-quality stocks. You can add shares at secondary buy points or fresh breakouts if they continue to act well.

If the uptrend goes under pressure, be cautious about taking new positions or adding shares. It may be a better time to lock in profits and cut losses. Put the brakes on buys and stay mostly in cash when the market is in correction.

It's always best to trade more actively when the market is rewarding investors for taking risks.Finding too many attractive stocks isn't a bad problem to have. The bears are watching in disbelief as the Nasdaq and S&P 500 hit new closing highs. How can the market go higher with so many questions about the first-quarter earnings season, the health of the economy and the prospects for rising interest rates, they wonder. The bulls, on the other hand, are taking advantage of profit opportunities when they arise,…

Stocks can often seem like they're doing their best to fool you or fake you out. Perhaps never is that more true than when a fundamentally healthy stock forms a base-on-base pattern. Base-on-base patterns take a large number of forms. Most commonly, a stock will climb out of a cup or a flat base, advance less than 20% — often much less — then stall and build another cup or flat base.
The result often sends investors looking elsewhere, forgetting about the stock until it roars past the base-on-base buy point and moves on to new highs.
Take Two
In "How to Make Money In Stocks," IBD founder William O'Neil says base-on-base patterns often form near the end of bear markets, when a top stock is fighting a negative trend in the overall market.
When the market turns and launches a follow-through day , stocks in base-on-base patterns are often the first to emerge.
"It's like a spring that's being held down by the pressure of a heavy object," O'Neil wrote.

A textbook base-on-base pattern forms with the low point in the second base above or just even with the high point in the lower base. When bases do not match up this way, and instead are more equally aligned, they are base-beside-a-base patterns. These can produce positive breakouts, but they don't have the same spring-loaded effect as a base on top of a base.

FleetCor Technologies (FLT) has stumbled through a series of not-quite base-on-base patterns for the past year. Facebook (FB) has struggled to make headway, forming side-by-side flat base patterns since October.

Stocks that are currently making good on recent base-on-base breakouts include O'Reilly Automotive (ORLY), NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) (following an early January breakout) and homebuilder Lennar (LEN).
Stocks with base-on-base patterns under construction include Sykes Enterprises (SYKE), Tableau Software (DATA) and LinkedIn (LNKD).

Remember, the usual healthy base rules apply in terms of how deep, how long and where buy points occur. The one rule usually waived is the requirement for at least a 30% uptrend prior to the start of the base.
An Exceptional Breakout

A good example of a base-on-base vs. a troubled market is Varian Medical Systems (VAR) in an early November 2000 breakout past a 50.10 entry point. The maker of radiation and X-ray therapy equipment didn't have fundamentals quite as strong as you'd like at the time. But its EPS was on the way to a 300% increase in 2000, then rose 29% in 2001.

The stock formed what was technically a base-beside-a-base pattern from April to October. The pattern was not perfect, partly because the base formed and the stock broke out as the Nasdaq composite and the S&P 500 were collapsing into the historical tech sell-off.
The Nov. 2 breakout occurred in volume that exploded 636% above average, and the rally began the month when the Nasdaq would drop more than 22%.

Varian shares rose 20% that November and went on to gain 270% over the next 40 months.Stocks can often seem like they're doing their best to fool you or fake you out. The one rule usually waived is the requirement for at least a 30% uptrend prior to the start of the base.An Exceptional BreakoutA good example of a base-on-base vs. a troubled market is Varian Medical Systems (VAR) in an early November 2000 breakout past a 50.10 entry point. The maker of radiation and X-ray therapy equipment didn't have fundamentals quite as strong as you'd like at the time. But its EPS was on the way to a 300% increase in 2000, then rose 29% in 2001.The stock formed what was technically a base-beside-a-base pattern from April to October. The pattern was not perfect, partly because the base formed and the stock broke out as the Nasdaq composite and the S&P 500 were collapsing into the historical tech sell-off.The Nov. 2 breakout occurred in volume that exploded 636% above average, and the rally began the month when the Nasdaq would drop more than 22%.Varian shares rose 20% that November and went on to gain 270% over the next 40 months.

Falling fuel prices are great for vehicle-fleet operators but not so much for fuel-card firms that get a cut on sales when customers swipe their cards at the pump.FleetCor Technologies (FLT) is one of the biggest fuel-card companies in the U.S. And it has a sizeable international business, thanks to acquisitions of local fuel-card networks.The Norcross, Ga.-based firm generates revenue from its payments network and card processing services for commercial and government fleets.The company charges fees to fleet operators that use its various fuel cards and a usage fee to gasoline companies that take the fuel cards.FleetCor and analysts who follow the firm remain upbeat about its prospects in the face of lower fuel prices in the U.S.For one thing, FleetCor generates much of its revenue from services that have nothing to do with prices at the pump.In addition to various fees, FleetCor offers productivity tools, fraud protection and fleet-maintenance management, among other money-saving services.What's more, a wide spread between the wholesale price of fuel and the retail price offsets lower fuel prices — at least in the near-term. While wholesale prices react quickly to oil-price changes, retail prices tend to follow more slowly.Profit From Price SpreadsThe spread, for now, offsets some of the negative impact from declining gas prices, acting as a kind of hedge, analysts say.Eric Dey, FleetCor's chief financial officer, said in a post-Q3 conference call that higher fuel-spread margins lifted North American revenue by $5 million in the quarter.Analysts from Evercore ISI noted in a research report earlier this month that the average spread between wholesale and retail fuel prices in the fourth quarter grew 40% year over year.Given the wide spread and a decline in foreign exchange headwinds, Evercore raised its Q4 forecast by three cents a share, to $1.38. That's two cents above analysts' consensus of $1.36. In the year-earlier period, FleetCor earned $1.08.Barclays' analysts also don't seem too fazed by the impact of lower fuel prices on FleetCor's financial health. Barclays has an "overweight" on the stock, and it notes, "Long-term prospects outweigh short-term headwinds.""We suspect that during 2015, investors will look through the gas price and (foreign exchange) impacts and instead look at normalized growth potential," analyst Darrin Peller of Barclays wrote in late December.FleetCor shares rose 27% in 2014 but are down 8% so far this year, however.The company's "normal" growth has been impressive. Revenue over the last four years has grown 26% annually on average, while earnings have gone up 36% a year on average over that time.Numerous acquisitions have fueled some of FleetCor's growth. In Q3, the three biggest deals from 2013 — in the U.S., the U.K. and Brazil — accounted for about half of the company's revenue growth, CEO Ronald Clarke said in the last conference call.Total company revenue in the quarter jumped 31% to $295.3 million, while earnings per share rose 27% to $1.37.FleetCor has made more than 60 acquisitions since 2002. They include the recent $3.45 billion deal for Comdata, which closed in November and was its biggest buy ever.Comdata provides electronic fleet, virtual card and gift card solutions to more than 20,000 customers worldwide. Fleetcor management expects sizeable synergies, including cuts in fixed costs and cross-selling opportunities.Acquiring To GrowGoldman Sachs analysts see up to $1 billion of additional "accretive" deals this year.New acquisitions, organic growth and cost synergies from the Comdata deal "will more than offset" headwinds from weak fuel prices and negative foreign currency translations, Goldman Sachs analysts wrote after a meeting with management in mid-December.FleetCor's forecast for Q4 calls for earnings of $1.33 per share, assuming a foreign currency headwind of 5 cents. Analysts on average expect $1.36, according to a poll by Thomson Reuters.For all of 2014, FleetCor raised its EPS forecast to $5.07-$5.11 from $5.04-$5.10 previously. The company also raised its 2014 revenue forecast slightly, to $1.1-$1.11 billion.For 2015, management kept its previous guidance for EPS of $6.35 at the midpoint, despite an expected $.15-$.20 EPS headwind from unfavorable foreign exchange and lower U.S. fuel prices.The 2015 EPS guidance implies a 25% gain from FleetCor's expected EPS for 2014.The CFO noted in the call that the Comdata business — yet to be acquired then — was doing better than expected and that financing costs were lower than thought.FleetCor's revenue is almost evenly split between North America and international, with faster growing North America slightly higher at 52.9% of the mix.North America revenue in Q3 jumped 35.6% vs. the prior year to $156.3 million, with organic growth of 19%.Double-digit growth in the U.K. fueled much of the growth on the international side, which saw revenue rise 26.4% to $138.9 million.Even FleetCor's business in ailing Russia was "hanging in there," CEO Clarke said in the call. He and other executives declined an interview request.Maine-based rival WEX (WEX), formerly Wright Express, saw Q3 revenue grow 16% to $222.1 million. Earnings rose 17% to $1.56 per share, but analysts expect Q4 earnings to fall 1% from a year earlier.Its shares have fallen off sharply since late November.In IBD rankings, FleetCor is rated higher than WEX, with a Composite Rating of 93 vs. WEX's 74. The highest score possible is 99. The ratings factor in several metrics such as earnings growth and stock gains.Both stocks are in IBD's Finance-Credit Card/Payment Processing industry group, which is ranked 83 of 197 groups in performance.FleetCor is No. 3 in the group by Composite Rating, after Vantiv (VNTV) and Alliance Data Systems (ADS). Other stocks rated above 90 are Global Payments (GPN), MasterCard (MA) and Euronet Worldwide (EEFT).

Stocks took a thumping Monday, with energy stocks leading the way lower as oil prices briefly dropped below $50 a barrel.Investors in the stock market today also worried about events in Greece and a slowdown of Europe's economies. The dollar rose sharply, which could hurt exporters and international firms with large holdings outside the U.S.The Nasdaq fell 1.6%, the S&P; 500 dropped 1.8% and the Dow Jones industrial average was off 1.9%. Volume was heavier on both exchanges.Energy-related industry groups fared the worst, mostly down 4% to 7%. Solar energy stocks were down 5%. Among 197 groups, only gold miners managed a nearly 3% gain. Gold rose in a flight to safety.Electric car maker Tesla (TSLA) dropped nearly 5%.The National Bank of Greece (NBG), whose American depositary shares trade on the NYSE, gapped down and closed 10% lower. Its stock has collapsed from a November 2007 high of 677.40 to under 2. Some investors think the possible election of an anti-austerity government in Greece could lead to a default on the national debt. German Chancellor Angela Merkel was quoted as saying she was prepared to let Greece exit the eurozone.Petrobras (PBR), the national oil company of Brazil, gapped down and closed 10% lower. It produces 2.1 million barrels a day, much of it from high-cost offshore platforms.The Russian economy is being savaged by falling oil prices and U.S. and European sanctions. One-time leader Qiwi (QIWI), which operates cash-dispensing kiosks in Russia, dropped nearly 4%.Among IBD 50 stocks, seven were up and 43 were down. The best performers were medical stocks Akorn (AKRX) and Illumina (ILMN), up 3%. The worst performer was Fleetcor Technologies (FLT), which makes payment products for commercial fleets and oil companies; it fell more than 4% and sliced through its 50-day moving average.

No single stock screen will be the best in every uptrend. Different uptrends reward different kinds of stocks, and the screens reflect that reality. For example, during the last bear market, the aggressive and growthy complexion of the IBD 50 (then the IBD 100) faded.Stocks making the list on Oct. 27, 2008, included El Paso Electric (EE), Campbell Soup (CPB), Procter & Gamble (PG) and Johnson & Johnson (JNJ).The mention of those equities alone said, "It's a bear market."As of early November, the 85-85 screen has been the top-performing screen over the past six months. The 85-85 was up 6.1%, while the S&P 500 gained 1.1% and the IBD 50 1.5%.What can be made of this? There are two ways to use a screen — the micro approach and the macro approach.The micro approach studies the list to find stocks that might be near buy points and that have few misses by CAN SLIM standards .The macro approach looks for patterns in the list. What kind of stocks are making the list — small caps or big caps? Which sectors or industry groups are plentiful? Are the stocks making the screen aggressive or defensive?Let's contemplate two screens — the IBD 50 and the 85-85, also known as Your Weekly Review in Friday's newspaper.Generally, the IBD 50 is a collection of stocks that have higher ratings than those in the 85-85 screen. Because the IBD 50 has higher ratings, these stocks should do better in a long and strong uptrend.Quality growth stocks, though, will likely correct more sharply than defensive stocks when the market runs into trouble.What is the advantage of the 85-85 screen?The 85-85 will pick up more turnaround stocks than the IBD 50. (A turnaround stock is less likely to have strong annual ratings over the past three years.) The 85-85's looser standard means that it's also more likely to pick up stocks benefiting from sector rotation. It also will pick up more small and thinly traded stocks than the IBD 50.The sector rotation angle has been apparent recently. Small bank and S&L industry groups accounted for 40 of the stocks in the 85-85 at the end of October.Yet only two bank stocks made the IBD 50 — Bank of the Ozarks (OZRK) and Signature Bank (SBNY). Many of the 85-85 bank stocks are thinly traded. Some, though, still attract quality mutual fund holders, as the table shows.

The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 notched fresh all-time highs Tuesday, but the Nasdaq lagged as biotech stocks sold off hard.
The Dow added 0.6%, with about one-third of its components up 1% or more. The S&P 500 rose 0.4% and the Nasdaq eased 0.2%. Volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq was tracking just below Monday's levels.
Breadth was pretty good on the NYSE with advancing stocks beating decliners by about 2-to-1. On the Nasdaq, winners beat losers by a 7-to-6 margin.
In economic news, the final revision to Q3 gross domestic product came in much better than expected at 5%. That's on the heels of 4.6% growth in Q2.

In the stock market today, biotechs came under pressure. IBD's biotech group fell more than 5% following a 1% loss Monday. Regeneron (REGN) and Celgene (CELG) sliced below their 50-day lines, falling 5% and 7% respectively.

Biogen Idec (BIIB) also took a hit, falling 5%. It's still holding above its 50-day line, but is well below a recent 347.85 buy point. The sharp decline in biotechs could be a sign that institutional investors are ready to rotate out of a group that's been leading the market for months.
Biogen's recent breakout attempt has stalled like many others, including Baidu (BIDU), FleetCor Technologies (FLT) and Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX), among others.
The selling wasn't just confined to biotechs Tuesday. Eight of the day's worst performing groups in IBD's database hailed from the medical sector.
Top gainers in the IBD 50 included Noah Holdings (NOAH), Asbury Automotive (ABG) and CDW (CDW).

After the close, watch for earnings from egg producer Cal-Maine Foods (CALM). Profit is seen rising 57% to 85 cents a share. Cal-Maine reclaimed its 50-day moving average last week in heavy volume. Stocks extended losses midday Thursday, a day after the Federal Reserve raised interest rates for the first time in nearly a decade. The S&P 500 fell 0.8%, while the Dow Jones industrial average and the Nasdaq were each down 0.7%.
Volume was running higher on both the NYSE and the Nasdaq compared to the same time Wednesday.

Economic news was mixed, with unemployment claims falling a little less than expected in the week ended Dec. 12, while manufacturing in the mid-Atlantic region fell much more than expected in December. The Conference Board's index of leading economic indicators rose 0.4% in November, down from the prior month's 0.6% increase but ahead of analysts' forecasts.
Mining and energy stocks were hit hardest in the stock market today on declines in oil and metals prices.
Newmont Mining (NEM), a Colorado-based miner of gold and silver, lost 8%, leading the S&P 500 lower. Oil transportation stock Oneok (OKE) also dropped about 8%.

Most IBD 50 stocks were lower, led by Global Payments (GPN), which fell more than 2% in heavy volume. The stock plunged 8% on Wednesday, slicing through its 50-day line, after agreeing to buy rival credit card payments processor Heartland Payment Systems (HPY) for $4.3 billion.
Total System Services (TSS), another credit card payments processor in the IBD 50, fell 2.7% but remains well above a 48.18 buy point of a cup-with-handle base that it cleared in October.
But Chinese social media stock Weibo (WB) was a bright spot. It jumped more than 4% in heavy volume, closing in on a 20.80 buy point of a deep, cup-shaped base.

The stock boasts a rising Relative Strength line and an Accumulation/Distribution Rating of A, indicating strong demand for the shares. The S&P 500 rose 0.3% to a new high. Meanwhile, the Nasdaq was also up 0.3%. Blue chips continued to outperform, as the Dow Jones industrial average climbed 0.4%. Turnover was tracking higher on both major exchanges compared with the same time Thursday.

Among leading stocks, Freescale Semiconductor (FSL) gapped up and rallied 5% to a near six-month high. It's now nearly 9% past a 22.73 buy point from a double-bottom base cleared Wednesday. The chipmaker was featured in The New America earlier this year.

May initial public offering TrueCar (TRUE) rose 3% as it builds the right side of a potential double-bottom base. The provider of auto-buying services is expected to lose 6 cents a share this year. But profit is expected at 12 cents a share in 2015.

FleetCor Technologies (FLT) climbed 2% and regained a 150.02 buy point from a cup base. The stock has been bouncing back after finding support at its 50-day moving average Monday. Action has been rocky since its high-volume breakout Oct. 31.

On the downside, Big Lots (BIG) gapped below its 50-day moving average and tumbled 14% after reporting disappointing results earlier in the stock market today. The stock erased a 10% gain past a 46.89 buy point from a cup-with-handle base.Stocks continued to make small improvements Friday afternoon. A much better-than-expected jobs report boosted equities.The S&P 500 rose 0.3% to a new high. Meanwhile, the Nasdaq was also up 0.3%. Blue chips continued to outperform, as the Dow Jones industrial average climbed 0.4%. Turnover was tracking higher on both major exchanges compared with the same time Thursday.Among leading stocks, Freescale Semiconductor (FSL) gapped up and rallied 5% to a near six-month high. It's now nearly 9% past a 22.73 buy point from a double-bottom base cleared Wednesday. The chipmaker was featured in The New America earlier this year.May initial public offering TrueCar (TRUE) rose 3% as it builds the right side of a potential double-bottom base. The provider of auto-buying services is expected to lose 6 cents a share this year. The stock market closed sharply lower Monday, as the major indexes slid from their mildly ascending paths.
The Nasdaq stumbled 1.3%, its worst loss in more than six weeks. Apple (AAPL) shares fell 3%. The stock was off as much as 6% earlier before it pared losses.
The S&P 500 lost 0.7% and the Dow Jones industrial average 0.3%. The small-cap Russell 2000 slid 1.5%.
Volume rose, of course, after Friday's half-session.
Energy stocks took the brunt of the selling in the stock market today. Solar, pipeline, refining and exploration stocks were among the worst performers.
The transportation sector, which has flourished amid falling oil prices, also lagged Monday. The Dow transportation average plunged 2.7%.
Most IBD 50 stocks closed lower, although volume was well below average in most cases.
That wasn't the case for Ambarella (AMBA), which slid 8% in heavy trading.

United Rentals (URI), meanwhile, fell below its 50-day moving average in active trading but got support at the 200-day line. Still, the loss moved the stock further off a potential breakout at 119.93.

FleetCor (FLT), down 3.5% on the day, started trimming losses after it touched its 50-day line. But the stock fell as much as 5% below a prior 150.02 buy point. Stocks dredged out early losses Monday, as oil prices bounced and energy sector stocks groped for support.
The Nasdaq tumbled 0.9%. The S&P 500 was down 0.6% and the Dow Jones industrial average eased 0.5%.
Volume was briskly mixed in the stock market today, up 21% on the Nasdaq and 9% lower on the NYSE, compared with Friday's opening action.

Oil prices gained after the start of trade, with the U.S. benchmark West Texas intermediate up almost 2% to above $67 a barrel. Oil-related stocks still were the bulk of the worst hit stocks on the S&P 500 index. Chevron (CVX) and Exxon Mobil (XOM) rose 1% each, easing some of the downward pressure on the Dow. General Electric (GE), which sees a growing portion of its revenue from oilfield service and alternative energy, dropped more than 2%.
VimpelCom (VIP) and Baidu (BIDU) dropped 3% apiece, the worst early losses among the Nasdaq 100 stocks.

Economic news showed Markit's Purchasing Managers Index for November dipping to 54.8, down from 55.9 and below consensus views for a 55 reading. The Institute for Supply Management's November manufacturing index was more positive at 58.7, down slightly from October's 59 tally, but above economist expectations of 57.8.

Among leading stocks, EQT Midstream Partners (EQM) opened with a 10% loss, by far the hardest hit among IBD 50 stocks, but it quickly shaved that decline to 2%.The Pennsylvania-based natural gas pipeline company was still well below its 200-day line of support following a 5% drop on Friday.

Fleetcor Technologies (FLT) slipped more than 3%. There was no holiday cheer for the stock market Monday, as sellers whacked the major indexes and leading stocks. The Nasdaq snapped a six-session win streak, tumbling 1.3%. That marked its biggest loss since the Oct. 21 follow-through signal. Biotechs, chips and Internet stocks were hit hard. Apple (AAPL), which makes up about 8% of the Nasdaq, dropped 3%. The…
Most of the major stock indexes were near session lows just over two hours into Monday's session as earlier rebound efforts crumbled.

The Nasdaq slumped 1.2% while the S&P 500 dropped 0.7%. The Dow Jones industrial average fell a milder 0.2%, thanks to gains in Caterpillar (CAT) and Visa (V). Volume rose across the board in the stock market today.

Equities stumbled Monday amid disappointing data in Europe and China. Weak retail sales didn't help either. According to the National Retail Federation, weekend sales from Thursday to Sunday tumbled 11% from a year ago.
Many leaders were under fire. Nearly all stocks in the IBD 50 were in the red.
United Rentals (URI) slumped 8% and sliced its 50-day moving average. But it's closing in on potential support at its long-term 200-day line.
Ambarella (AMBA) erased early gains and tumbled nearly 8% after fading badly from a new high Friday.

FleetCor Technologies (FLT) was off its session low, but still fell 5% in fast trade. Intraday, it fell 5% below a 150.02 buy point from a cup base. FleetCor is trying to find support at its 50-day line.

Top-rated stocks up in volume were few, but Jack in the Box (JACK) rose 1.5%, extending gains from the past two sessions. Stocks held their gains in early-afternoon trading as IBD 50 stocks advanced in volume.

The Nasdaq maintained its 0.5% lead and the S&P 500 was still up 0.2%, while the Dow Jones industrial average climbed to a 0.1% gain. Volume was tracking lower on the NYSE but marginally higher on the Nasdaq in the stock market today.

FleetCor Technologies (FLT) rose 4% to a new high in twice normal trade, extending its gains for a fourth straight session. The IBD 50 stock is now 4% above a 150.02 buy point. The fuel card provider on Monday completed its acquisition of Comdata, a corporate payment processing company, for $3.5 billion.

Among other IBD 50 stocks, Foot Locker (FL) climbed 1% in fast turnover ahead of its Q3 earnings report due out Friday before the open. The stock is working on a flat base with a potential 58.50 buy point. Analysts expect the athletic footwear retailer to post a 16% EPS increase to 79 cents on a 6% rise in sales to $1.7 billion.

NetEase (NTES), also on the IBD 50, gained 3% to an all-time high in brisk trade. That marks its eighth advance of the past nine sessions. The stock is up 13% from a 91.26 flat-base buy point. The Chinese online gaming company last week reported Q3 revenue that crushed views, though its earnings missed.

Covenant Transportation Group (CVTI) advanced 4% to a record best. The stock has nearly doubled in price since breaking out past a 12.39 cup-base buy point in June. The trucker boosted the size of its secondary offering to 2.64 million at $22 per share, from the 2.2 million it previously announced.

On the downside, El Pollo Loco (LOCO) stumbled 4% in massive volume after announcing the pricing of its 6-million-share follow-on public offering at 27. The stock is holding above its July 25 IPO price, but is on track for its ninth decline of the past 10 sessions.

Stocks were trading moderately lower and near the lows of the day heading into the noon hour Monday. The Nasdaq dropped 0.3% while the S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.2% in the stock market today.
Volume will finish well above the level of Friday's abbreviated post-Thanksgiving level, but was tracking below average on the NYSE and Nasdaq exchange.

Among IBD 50 stocks, 16 were higher and 34 were lower. Among the top performers was Cambrex (CBM), up 2% in volume well above average. Last week the developer of active pharmaceutical ingredients broke out of a cup-with-handle base with a 52.68 buy point. The stock is trading at an all-time high.

Integrated Device Technology (IDTI), another IBD 50 stock, was up nearly 2%, also trading at an all-time high. Company management will present at the Credit Suisse Global Technology Conference Tuesday.
The worst performer on the IBD 50 was Regeneron Pharmaceuticals (REGN), down more than 2%.
Energy names were among the day's best performing industry groups, pushed by oil prices, which were about 2% higher.
Chinese social media platform Weibo (WB) rose nearly 5% in volume running nearly triple its usual pace. It's attempting to build the right side of a deep base.

But Sohu.com (SOHU), another Chinese Internet stock, gapped down and was trading 6% lower. Stocks ended mixed Tuesday after making a feeble attempt to rebound from a sharp sell-off the prior day. The S&P 500 added 0.2%, the Dow Jones industrial average edged up 0.1% and the Nasdaq dipped 0.2%.Volume was lower across the board, falling 12% on the NYSE and 8% on the Nasdaq compared to Monday, according to preliminary data.Apple (AAPL) was the Dow's biggest decliner, sinking 2.5%, after Japan's Nikkei newspaper reported that the tech giant would cut production of its 6S and 6S Plus iPhone models by about 30% more than planned in the first three months of the year. The report cited Apple suppliers in Japan and abroad.Apple, a former market leader, is now more than 20% off its 52-week high and its Accumulation/Distribution Rating stands at D-, indicating heavy selling.Elsewhere in the stock market today, Gilead Sciences (GILD) rose nearly 1.3% following positive results for its experimental hepatitis B drug.Semiconductor stocks were among the worst performers in the IBD 50.Macom Technology Solutions (MTSI), which makes semiconductors for the auto, communications and defense industries, lost 3.3%. The stock erased a 12% gain past a 38.69 buy point of a cup-with-handle base, triggering a sell signal.Singapore-based chip designer Avago Technologies (AVGO) dropped 3.4% in light trade as it works on a handle in a long consolidation with a buy point at 149.82.Meanwhile, Smith & Wesson (SWHC) was easily the biggest winner in the IBD 50. Shares jumped 11% after the firearms maker issued bullish guidance late Monday.Monsanto (MON) and RPM International (RPM) are among companies due to report quarterly earnings Wednesday.Economic reports scheduled for Wednesday include the Institute for Supply Management's index of service sector activity for December, factory orders for November, the trade balance for November and minutes from the Federal Reserve's Dec. 16 meeting.Follow Scott Stoddard on Twitter @IBD_SStoddard.

Here's a short list of short lists of leading stocks.In May 2003, Investor's Business Daily launched the IBD 100. The feature each week zeroed in on 100 leading stocks — the best of the best among leaders, aimed at saving investors time by culling stocks with healthy fundamentals and chart action from the daily NYSE and Nasdaq listings.After much careful study, IBD tightened the list to the IBD 50 in January 2011. This more-refined offering had carefully explored which stocks among the eight years of IBD 100 lists tended to show the best performance.Keeping the strong, discarding the weak, IBD has concentrated its list down to even more fine-tuned leadership. The list is now published twice a week, on Monday and on Wednesday.The list continues to offer IBD's proprietary minicharts, jammed with critical fundamental and technical information on each stock, not the least of which are chart descriptions, including buy points and critical sell signals.As with any stock offering, readers should never buy a stock simply because it appears on the IBD 50. Remember, the IBD 50 is not a buy list. Treat it as a key watch list. You should always analyze the chart pattern, dig deeper into the fundamentals and read articles about the company to understand fully what sets it apart from the thousands of also-rans that populate the stock market.Here are a few of the list's current offerings, and when they first appeared on the list.Ambarella (AMBA) showed up on the IBD 50 list in February last year, as it carved through its first real base. The cup showed a 33% decline, the deepest allowed for a good cup base. The designer of chips that go into wearable cameras broke out at 13.52 in massive volume in March and ran up 170% to a Jan. 7, 2014, high of 36.49.Jazz Pharmaceuticals (JAZZ) was an IBD 50 play the week that it cleared a cup-with-handle base on May 22, 2013. A nine-month advance, up to just before its current modest consolidation, carried it 193% above that buy point.FleetCor Technologies (FLT) joined the IBD 50 crew as it was basing in early August 2012. It broke out from that base two weeks later, launching a run that would drive shares up 199% over the next 15 months.Generac Holdings (GNRC) was in the IBD 50 in July 2012 while forming the first tenable base amid a volatile advance. The portable and backup power generator manufacturer snapped out of the nine-week base in October, receiving an added boost from the heavens as Superstorm Sandy slammed into the East Coast — knocking out power and driving up demand for generators.The stock tore out of a cup-with-handle base with a 24.44 buy point Oct. 1. By Nov. 5 it had climbed 60%. More recently, Generac notched a new high Monday, 144% above the initial entry.

With most IBD 50 stocks extended from buy points, few choices remain for new purchases, and the most recent breakouts are having mixed results. A few stocks that broke out in the past couple of weeks are above their buy points and acting well enough. Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) last week got its breakout on track and jumped to new…
Stocks barely budged Wednesday as volume eased from the previous session's bullish pace.
The Nasdaq tacked on a 0.1% gain, while the S&P 500 finished a sliver under flat. The Dow Jones industrial average and the small cap Russell 2000 each lost 0.2%.
Volume was about 10% lower on the Nasdaq and about 6% lower on the NYSE, according to preliminary data.
Although the session was quiet for most stocks, several IBD 50 stocks moved in strong volume.
Gentherm (THRM), a maker of climate-controlled seats for autos, galloped 10% in huge volume after reporting quarterly results that topped the Street's estimates on sales and earnings.
On the downside, fuel-card provider FleetCor Technologies (FLT) dropped 3% in almost double volume. The stock has enjoyed a run-up since August 2012 and recently cleared a later-stage base.

Firearms maker Smith & Wesson (SWHC) isn't on the IBD 50 but it surprised the Street once again as it gapped up 16% in enormous volume. The company topped the consensus estimates on the top and bottom lines and raised guidance.

Market watchers have been declaring the gun play dead for months but so far it hasn't happened. Days in short volume for Smith & Wesson hit 11.2 in mid-February, meaning it would take 11 days of the stock's average volume to cover all the shorts. About 28% of the float was shorted at that time. A short involves borrowing shares to sell, essentially betting the stock will go down.

Among commodities, West Texas Intermediate crude oil and natural gas suffered the biggest losses, each down about 2%. Platinum enjoyed the biggest percentage gain, up almost 1%. Platinum is a precious metal that also serves as an industrial metal used in catalytic converters, electronics and dentistry.

Stocks trimmed losses early Wednesday, recovering to a tightly mixed range despite disappointing jobs and service-sector reports.
The Nasdaq and S&P 500 had turned the early drop into fractional gains, and the Dow Jones industrial average hung 0.1% in the red.
Volume was mixed, down 13% on the NYSE, up 3% on the Nasdaq.

The stock market today felt some early drag from a weak reading on February jobs from the ADP National Employment report. Overseas trading was also a net negative, with China's markets closing lower and European markets hanging in negative territory in afternoon trade.

The Institute for Supply Management kept up the pressure, reporting its ISM Services Index slipped to 51.6 in February. That was sharply below January's tally of 54 and well below economist projections for a slight moderation to 53.5.

In stocks, leaders were active, withGentherm (THRM) bolting 10% to a new high. The Michigan-based maker of climate control systems for cars and trucks reported a wide fourth-quarter revenue beat, with earnings comfortably above consensus estimates. The company also notched up its full-year revenue guidance to well above views. The stock was 22% above a 25.35 flat-base buy point.

Tableau Software (DATA) dropped more than 3% after announcing a partnership with Splunk (SPLK). The union will look to provide companies with software packages letting them better manage huge data streams from multiple sources, including mobile devices.
Tableau remains extended after clearing a cup base in January. Splunk shares were unchanged.

FleetCor Technologies (FLT) gapped down to a 3% loss in heavy trade. Stocks ticked higher, then pulled back to narrow gains at the start of trade Thursday, with earnings, economic and world news affecting early trade.

The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 0.2%, the S&P 500 0.1% and the Nasdaq held to a fractional loss. Volume was light, down 6% on the Nasdaq and a fraction lower on the NYSE compared with Wednesday morning's trade.

The https://www.investors.com/stock-market-today/ opened to mixed economic news as January durable goods orders declined for a second month, but less than in December and with orders for goods outside transportation rising 1.1%.

Escalating conflict in Ukraine placed some pressure on European stocks, helping send the dollar higher vs. the euro. Federal Reserve Chairwoman Janet Yellen was scheduled to begin testimony before the Senate Banking Committee at 10 a.m. EST.

A broad range of stocks were moving on earnings-related news. Digital recording service provider TiVo (TIVO) climbed 4%. Automated network gear maker Infoblox (BLOX), electrical power producer Dynegy (DYN) and China search engine giant Baidu (BIDU) added 3% each.

Noodles (NDLS) gapped down to an 11% loss on its fourth-quarter results. Earnings and revenue growth stopped shy of consensus projections. Management's full-year guidance was in line with analyst expectations. The Broomfield, Colo.-based fast casual restaurant chain has been consolidating since October.
Pharmacy benefit manager Catamaran (CTRX) dumped 10% at the open. Oil producer Swift Energy (SFY) plummeted 24%, while peer Whiting Petroleum (WLL) climbed 3%.

Among leaders, Qiwi (QIWI) bucked up 3% to lead the IBD 50. The provider of payment service in Russia is up 41% in the past four weeks as it makes its way back from a 45% sell-off between late December and early February.

FleetCor Technologies (FLT) and Ambarella (AMBA) also gained 3%.Stocks ticked higher, then pulled back to narrow gains at the start of trade Thursday, with earnings, economic and world news affecting early trade.The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 0.2%, the S&P 500 0.1% and the Nasdaq held to a fractional loss. The Nasdaq and S&P 500 gave bullish signals Tuesday, putting the market on a confirmed uptrend. The Nasdaq climbed 1.2% in higher volume. The gain was sufficiently large to make it a follow-through — a confirmation of a long-attempted rally started on April 15. It's unusual for a follow-through to hatch so late into a rally, in this case on…

A new market uptrend is casting a spotlight on a number of IBD 50 stocks crafting bases.Ubiquiti Networks (UBNT) is edging up toward a 48.10 buy point in a rare ascending base. The pattern can also now be interpreted as a cup-type base.The maker of wireless network equipment has risen for three straight weeks. Its Relative Strength line is near a new high and its Accumulation/Distribution Rating is A-, indicating strong demand for the shares.The stock got a boost Feb. 7 after the company reported a better-than-expected 140% jump in quarterly profit. It was the second straight triple-digit increase.Rexnord (RXN), a maker of motion control and water management products such as valves and pipes, has formed a flat base with a buy point at 29.39.The stock, which went public in March 2012, has seen profit growth accelerate for two quarters, from flat to 29% and 79%. Sales growth has stayed in the low single digits, however.Highly rated T. Rowe Price New Horizons Fund boosted its holdings last quarter.FleetCor Technologies (FLT) has risen for three straight weeks, clearing its 10-week line as it works on the right side of a late-stage cup-type base. Late-stage bases carry more risk, and FleetCor has already enjoyed a long run since it cleared a cup base in August 2012.FleetCor issues fuel cards to trucking firms and other transport companies, helping them to track and control costs.Earnings have risen for four consecutive years. Profit is expected to rise 22% this year, followed by a 16% increase in 2015. Both figures have been revised higher.Elsewhere, China-based WuXi PharmaTech (WX) is consolidating below its 10-week line. WuXi provides pharmaceutical and biotech research. Its Composite Rating of 98 leads the highly rated medical research industry group.The company is scheduled to report Q4 earnings after the market closes on March 5. Profit for the period is expected to rise 21% to 46 cents a share, slowing from gains of 39% and 31% in the previous two quarters.Revenue for the period is seen rising 24% to $155.8 million, which would mark the second straight quarter of acceleration.For the week, the IBD 50 rose 3.9%, more than double the S&P 500's 1.8% increase. Generac Holdings (GNRC) led the way, soaring 13%.

Stocks gave up early gains Thursday to finish mixed, with the Nasdaq hanging on to a narrow gain. The day marked the third straight advance for the Nasdaq.
The Nasdaq rose 0.3%; the S&P 500 was down a hair and the Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.1%. Volume rose on the Nasdaq and fell on the NYSE, according to preliminary data.

Chipmaker Cavium (CAVM) gained nearly 11% early after reporting earnings that were 59% higher than a year ago, but finished up 4% and in the lower part of its range. It has been a choppy few weeks for the stock, which remains above its 50-day moving average and a 42.51 buy point from a cup base.

Anika Therapeutics (ANIK) rose nearly 3% in above-average volume. The company reported earnings earlier this week that were 362% above the year-ago quarter. The stock seems to be shaping a new base. It is moving in a tight, constructive way, but it would be a late-stage base.

Money managers will be watching the employment report Friday morning. Economists are looking for a gain of 210,000 jobs in April compared to 192,000 in March. The unemployment rate is expected to tick lower to 6.6%.

KapStone Paper and Packaging (KS) was off its session low but still fell 3% following disappointing Q1 results late Wednesday. The company posted a profit of 36 cents a share, up 71% from a year ago. But that was 6 cents below views. Revenue jumped 72% to $549 million, below views for $554.13 million. In recent sessions, KapStone has found support near 25.

The rally that began June 24 has propelled a number of leaders to new highs. Most of those stocks are extended from any buy point and out of range, at least for the time being.
A few stocks still have potential.

One is FleetCor Technologies (FLT). It found support at its 50-day moving average Oct. 9, and has since recovered. It's slightly more than 5% above that support level, putting it slightly out of buy range.

FleetCor provides payment products to commercial fleets and oil companies. The stock has been a big winner since originally breaking out of a base in August 2012. It's made numerous trips down to its 10-week moving average, but hasn't closed a week below the line.

FleetCor has produced steady earnings growth. It has a five-year Earnings Stability Factor of 8 on a 0 to 99 scale, where low numbers correspond to steady earnings growth. The company produced EPS growth of 37% in the most recent quarterly report. Analysts expect an 18% increase in the next report.
AVG Technologies (AVG) has also found support at its 10-week line and is also 3% above a 23.88 buy point from a flat base.

The company produces security products for the PC and mobile markets, targeting individual users and small businesses. It uses the "freemium" model of giving away some products, then hoping users like the products enough to buy upgrades.

Analysts expect earnings growth of 48% this year and 14% next year. It has a five-year growth rate of 27%. In the most recent quarter, earnings grew 69% year over year and revenue was up 22%. Analysts expect only 9% EPS growth in the next report.
Web.com Group (WWWW) is another stock that has recovered above its 10-week line and is still within buy range.
This is its first trip to the 10-week line since breaking out of a base in May.
The company provides website services to small businesses, and it has shown impressive growth the past few years.
Its five-year growth rate is 24%. It has a four-quarter trailing return on equity of 62%, well above the 17% an investor should seek. Pretax profit margin last year was an impressive 20%.

Earnings growth in the most recent quarter was 34% and revenue jumped 22%. Both indexes closed practically at session lows, their charts accelerating their recent…
From the United Kingdom to Russia and down to Mexico and Brazil, Norcross, Ga.-based FleetCor Technologies  (FLT) is on the move.
One of the top fuel-card companies in the U.S. for commercial vehicle fleets, it's been buying up local fuel-card networks outside the country to fuel its own growth.
Buyout targets tend to have "less sophisticated, underinvested and underutilized" networks, said Wayne Johnson, an analyst with Raymond James.

Most of the company's revenue comes from its payment network and card processing services for commercial and government fleets, tied to drivers' fuel purchases. Vehicles it serves tend to travel "short hauls" within 100 miles of loading spots, Johnson says.
FleetCor charges a monthly fee to fleets using the fuel cards and a usage fee to gas stations that accept the cards. FleetCor's electronic network connects the two sides.
After an acquisition, FleetCor turns up the throttle by transferring the new accounts to its platform "and in doing so it can introduce new services and sometimes raise pricing," Johnson says.
Strategic Acquirer
Six to 12 months down the road, the acquisitions typically drive per-share earnings higher than analysts' expectations, he says.

Case in point: FleetCor's third-quarter results, released Oct. 30 after the market close. Earnings jumped 30% from a year earlier to $1.08, 10 cents above Wall Street's consensus. Even excluding a tax benefit of 5 cents, it still beat views by 7 cents.
Revenue grew 20% to $225.2 million, also above views.
"It was an exceptional quarter," said Evercore Partners analyst David Togut. Investors must have thought so. Shares jumped nearly 8% the next day to a new high.
It didn't hurt that the company announced it made two new acquisitions in October, expanding products and services. Togut says the buys will "set the stage for strong earnings growth in 2014."
At the same time, management raised guidance for 2013 to $4.02 per share at the midpoint. The team started the year forecasting $3.65 at the midpoint and kept raising guidance.

One of the new buys, Atlanta-based NexTraq, provides fleet operators with real-time telematics vehicle tracking and fuel monitoring services. The other, Epyx in the U.K., uses an Internet-based system to link leasing and commercial fleet clients to 9,000 service garages there, earning a fee each time the system is used to support a service transaction.
"We've been looking for ideas to extend beyond fleet fueling into fleet maintenance," FleetCor CEO Ronald Clarke said in the earnings conference call.

FleetCor also said it closed on one of two Brazilian acquisition deals previously announced, that of DB Trans, a payment company for truckers. The other, for card and voucher firm VB Servicos, closed in August.
Togut figures the latest Brazilian acquisitions will add 20 cents to FleetCor's earnings in 2014.

"FleetCor will almost certainly be the fastest earnings grower in my payments' coverage over the next few years," Togut said. He covers 24 payments stocks, including Visa (V), MasterCard (MA), Vantiv (VNTV) and FleetCor's closest rival, Maine-based WEX (WEX), formerly called Wright Express.
WEX, which offers fleet and corporate payment products, also beat earnings and revenue views in the third quarter.
"WEX is more of a U.S. company," Togut said, though he added that it's been stepping up international expansion.
FleetCor has acquired nearly 60 companies since 2002. Third-quarter results got a lift from several of them, including deals made earlier this year in Australia, New Zealand and Brazil.
In addition, it saw continued growth from a North American workforce lodging firm acquired in 2009, Corporate Lodging Consultants. CLC gives truck drivers discounted room rates.
International revenue jumped nearly 30% from last year, "led by our U.K. business," Clarke said, for a total of $109.9 million. Revenue in North America grew 13.6% to $115.3 million.
Driving Growth Abroad
International is close to accounting for 50% of the firm's revenue, up from about 30% a few years ago.

Most of the company's acquisitions in recent years have occurred overseas. One of the largest was the $312 million purchase in late 2011 of AllStar Business Solutions, the U.K.'s leading fuel-card provider.
Earlier that year a Mexico City-based prepaid fuel and food voucher business marked the company's entry into Latin America.

Hopping aboard FleetCor's bandwagon in 2012 were a Russian fuel-card company and a fuel payment processor in Brazil. The latter targets trucks, ships, mining equipment and railroads; and links fleet operators, banks and oil companies.

"It's a fixed-cost business so the company with the greatest amount of volume wins," Johnson said. "FleetCor gets high margins and earnings acceleration from the layering on of new acquisitions on its existing infrastructure."
In addition to its core business, FleetCor has forged several outsourcing deals with oil companies such as Chevron (CVX), BP (BP) and Arco for managing their corporate cards in the U.S.

Similar deals with oil companies in Europe could provide new growth opportunities, analysts say. But that could take several years given Europe's complexities, wrote Morgan Stanley analysts in a recent research note.

One of the first major oil-company outsourcing deals in Europe was EuroShell's 2011 contract with FleetCor to process fuel-card transactions in 35 countries, Morgan Stanley noted. But platform conversions have been slow due to "extensive customization requirements."
About 70% of European fleet volume flows through cards issued by oil companies and the bulk of those are still managed in-house, Morgan Stanley said.

Meanwhile, FleetCor's growing presence in emerging markets is seen as a positive since card markets there are at earlier stages of development than in the U.S. and therefore will grow at a faster rate.
But FleetCor's business in the U.K. market is hardly a laggard. Togut notes that third-quarter revenue jumped 35% from a year ago.
In a new partnership with Visa Europe, FleetCor will roll out highly secure EMV cards in 2014 in the U.K., seen as a revenue driver that year.

Acquisition opportunities are still plentiful in the fragmented U.S. market. But FleetCor, says Johnson, "made the choice that international is where it gets more bang for the buck."From the United Kingdom to Russia and down to Mexico and Brazil, Norcross, Ga.-based FleetCor Technologies  (FLT) is on the move.One of the top fuel-card companies in the U.S. for commercial vehicle fleets, it's been buying up local fuel-card networks outside the country to fuel its own growth.Buyout targets tend to have "less sophisticated, underinvested and underutilized" networks, said Wayne Johnson, an analyst with Raymond James.Most of the company's revenue comes from its payment network and card processing services for commercial and government fleets, tied to drivers' fuel purchases. Stocks struggled into mixed terrain Thursday morning, as the Nasdaq inched above its early losses. The Nasdaq strained to hold a fractional gain. The S&P 500 was less than 0.1% above the line and the Dow Jones industrial average held a 0.1% loss. Volume reversed and was up 11% on the NYSE. Trade on the Nasdaq is up 25%. The…

Stocks opened to modest losses Thursday, as company reports, jobs data and oil prices figured into early trade. The Dow dropped 0.9%. The Nasdaq narrowed its early loss to 0.4%. The S&P 500 hung 0.6% into the red.
Volume climbed 10% on the Nasdaq and was 29% higher on the NYSE, relative to trade at the same time Wednesday.

The stock market today got started on weak footing after the Labor Department reported jobless claims held steady in the week ending Nov. 7. This followed an unexpected surge in the prior week. Investors were also taking in early comments made in separate speeches by Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen, St. Louis Federal Reserve President James Bullard and Jeffrey Lacker, president of the Richmond Federal Reserve Bank.

U.S. employers claimed 5.53 million positions went unfilled in the Labor Department's September Job Openings and Labor Turnover Survey. The number was up from 5.37 million unfilled openings in August.
Oil prices were down sharply, with West Texas Intermediate off more than 2% to below $42 a barrel ahead of the Energy Information Administration's weekly inventories report, due out at 11 a.m. ET.

In stocks,Goldman Sachs (GS) and Boeing (BA) weighed on the Dow, down 2% each. Cisco Systems (CSCO) held the Dow's high ground, up a half percent before its fiscal first quarter report due out after the close. Sellers were piling on mining issues, with Freeport-McMoran (FCX) down 7% and Consol Energy (CNX) down 5% in early action.

Advance Auto Parts (AAP) peeled off a 12% loss. The Roanoke, Va.-based chain's third-quarter earnings and revenue missed estimates, guidance was weak and the Chief Executive Darren Jackson announced he would retire Jan. 2. The gap-down loss drove shares well below their 50-day moving average in very heavy trade.

On the IBD 50 list, NetEase (NTES) climbed almost 4% in strong trade, to just above two optional cup base buy points, one at 154.62 and another at 154.98. The China-based provider of online games and content reported strong third quarterly results late Wednesday.

On the downside, operations management consultant Maximus (MMS) buckled, falling 25%. The Reston, Va.-based operation reported fiscal fourth quarter earnings a penny above consensus views, but revenue stopped shy of forecasts and management trimmed its full year EPS guidance. The loss ends the stock's effort to rise above a 70.10 cup-base buy point.Stocks opened to modest losses Thursday, as company reports, jobs data and oil prices figured into early trade. Sector Leaders were mixed Wednesday, with a few strong performers despite market weakness associated with the government shutdown. The indefatigable Priceline.com (PCLN) rose 29.11, or 3%, to an all-time high of 1,067.38 in big volume. It is 7% extended from a flat-base breakout on Sept. 18. Priceline has made an enormous move and, consequently, the most recent base was late…
MasterCard (MA) reported better than expected third-quarter earnings early Thursday on brisk growth in global business as credit card transactions climbed to 10 billion.
The credit card processor's stock was again trading near an all-time high after hitting a series of fresh tops in the last six months.
Earnings per share grew 18% to $7.27 on a 16% hike in revenue to $2.22 billion.
Consensus of 34 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters was for $6.95 per share profit on $2.13 billion revenue.
MasterCard shares were up less than 1% in afternoon trading on the stock market today.

The report followed credit card leader Visa's (V)late Wednesday announcement that its earnings rose 20% to $1.85 a share, in line with estimates, while revenue accelerated 8.8% to $2.97 billion, below forecasts of $3.02 billion. Visa was down 3% Wednesday afternoon.
MasterCard's gross dollar volume of transactions rose 15% in Q3 to more than $1 trillion, and number of cross-border transactions climbed 19%.
"We had another good quarter with growth across all geographies," MasterCard CEO Ajay Banga said in a statement.
Those gains were partly offset by higher costs due to rebates and incentives.
During the quarter, MasterCard repurchased 575,000 shares at a cost of about $345 million, with $912 million remaining under the current program.
As of Sept. 30, its customers had issued about 2 billion MasterCard and its international Maestro branded cards.

Among other large companies in the Finance-Credit Card/Payment Processing group, ranked a strong 33 on IBD's list of 197 industries, American Express (AXP) and Discover Financial Services (DFS) were down 1%.

Fleetcor Technologies (FLT) stock jumped 8%. The provider of credit cards and payments processing for transportation fleet operators is on the IBD 50 list of top-rated growth stocks, and reported strong Q3 earnings and its full-year outlook of $4.02 beat analyst views for $3.92.

A few Sector Leaders found support at the 50-day moving average Tuesday, but another one fell sharply below that critical level. SouFun Holdings (SFUN) found support at its 50-day moving average, as shares rose 1 point to 51.02. The China-based provider of real estate listing and related data broke a six-day losing streak. Volume was below average. FleetCor Technologies (FLT)…

It's an interesting sign of the times: After 20 years of losing market share to debit cards, credit cards are making a comeback. According to the payment-industry newsletter the Nilson Report published Tuesday, credit cards accounted for 52.82% of U.S. card-based spending in 2012, up about 0.2% from the previous year. Debit-card share declined by a similar amount, to 47.18%.…

Puerto Rico-based Evertec (EVTC) is another of several payment-processing stocks that are market leaders today.The industry already boasts Visa (V) and FleetCor (FLT). The latter has been one of the year's top stocks, while Visa remains rock steady amid the market's sell-off. New issue Qiwi (QIWI) hit another new high Friday and has surged more than 30% since its initial public offering at 17 a share on May 3.Evertec went public a few weeks before Qiwi, on April 12 at 20 a share. After a wild IPO session, Evertec shares settled into a shallow nine-week correction.The stock broke out of that base June 17 and the stock remains near the 22.10 buy point.Evertec serves 19 countries in Latin America and the Caribbean, making it the leader in its market. It manages more than 4,100 automated teller machines and more than 104,000 point-of-sale terminals.At a presentation to investors this month, Evertec said the company finds itself at the confluence of a couple of strong trends. One is the growth of electronic payments, including the rising presence of card-swiping terminals. The other is the growth of the middle class in Latin America.The company's earnings surged 75% in the first quarter, the first time Evertec reported quarterly results. Revenue rose a modest 6%, in line with the performance of recent years.Its 2012 operating profit gain of 206% was the highest of 28 companies in the industry group. Its Q1 EPS increase was second-best in the group, after Qiwi.In the prospectus filed with the SEC, Evertec cited its high debt and its concentration in Puerto Rico as risk factors. It also mentioned its reliance on Popular, the largest financial institution in the Caribbean.Until 2010, Evertec was a unit of Popular. That year, private equity firm Apollo Global Management acquired a 51% stake in Evertec. Those companies still own the majority of Evertec shares, according to SEC filings.

The general market finished mixed Wednesday, with the Dow Jones industrials and the S&P 500 up and the Nasdaq slightly down after a valiant comeback attempt. Volume fell across the board. Sector Leaders were holding up well with a couple of exceptions. SouFun Holdings (SFUN), the Chinese real estate website, slid 2.92 to 50.59 in 75% faster trade, but it…

Leading names in the financial sector are showing strength. That's good news because rising financial stocks are often a harbinger of a rising stock market. Five financial stocks make the Sector Leaders list. That's more than any other sector. Two are mortgage servicing companies, Ocwen Financial (OCN) and Walter Investment Management (WAC). The big banks are selling off mortgage servicing…

In recent months, increasing distribution days in the major averages didn't have much effect on overall market health. Stock indexes managed to hold near highs and leading growth stocks held up well. Today, distribution days remain contained but some leaders are starting to face increased selling pressure. LinkedIn (LNKD), for example, is back below its 10-week moving average as it…

When the market is in a correction, pay attention to stocks that hold up better or buck the trend. These can go on to be big winners once the weight of the market is lifted.A number of leading stocks showed solid relative strength this past week.Green Mountain Coffee Roasters (GMCR) was quiet on headlines, but loud and clear in price and volume. The stock bolted 12% for the week, its biggest gain in more than three months.During the week, the stock blew past an 82.61 buy point from a cup-with-handle base. Volume was 59% above average when the stock broke out Aug. 20. Its weekly turnover was also well above average — a sign of professional buying. Green Mountain is now 4% past the 82.61 entry.Big volume has been lacking in many leaders amid the summer doldrums, making it tricky to interpret.Facebook (FB) is making a run at its record high, hit on its May 2012 IPO. It cleared an alternative 39.42 buy point Friday in heavy trading. The stock has shown much improved action in recent months and has now closed above its IPO price of 38. It hasn't seen any signs of distribution in three months.FleetCor Technologies (FLT) ramped to a new high after clearing a 100.97 buy point from a three-weeks-tight pattern Aug. 22. It previously had trouble with resistance at the 100 level.The stock has been in a steep uptrend for more than a year.Nu Skin Enterprises (NUS) continued to hold tight after big bouts of accumulation in July. It's now in a four-weeks-tight pattern with a 90.10 buy point. Tight action is a sign of institutional support.All of the stocks mentioned above are in buying range and make for fodder for your watch list. With the market in a correction, investors should avoid new buys. But it's good to have a buy list ready, if the market stages a follow-through.On a positive note, the current correction has been a mild one, even though the Nasdaq has sustained eight distribution days.The IBD 50 climbed 2.2% in the past week, outpacing the 1.5% rise in the Nasdaq as well as the S&P 500's 0.5% gain. The index of leading stocks has now climbed in eight of the past nine weeks.But there were a few big losers on the week. Chip designer  Ambarella (AMBA) fell to a three-month low before paring gains.Drugmaker Santarus (SNTS) gave up most of its gain past a 24.10 entry, but got support at its 50-day line.

Another day of gains and closes near session highs for major averages Friday saw more solid performances by several Sector Leaders.One day after FleetCor Technologies (FLT) cleared a bullish three-weeks-tight pattern,  Questcor Pharmaceuticals (QCOR) joined the party with a three-weeks-tight breakout of its own. The stock held gains nicely throughout Friday's session. Shares ended at 71.84, up 3.41. Volume was slightly above average.The risk with Questor is that the company derives nearly all its revenue from one drug: Acthar. But the drug has been a blockbuster so far. It's approved for 19 indications by the Food and Drug Administration, including multiple sclerosis relapses, infantile spasms and rheumatic disorders. It's also being looked at as a treatment for ALS, often referred to as Lou Gehrig's disease, a degenerative disease that affects motor neurons.When Questor reported second-quarter results in July, the company said it shipped 7,050 vials of Acthar, up 50% from a year ago. Paid prescriptions rose 35%.Elsewhere, LinkedIn (LNKD) outperformed again, rising 6.12 to 240.37 in light trade. Despite a distribution week during the week ended Aug. 16, LinkedIn has held gains nicely after soaring 13% during the week ended Aug. 2. The company recently announced it's moving into the teen market by setting up university pages where prospective college students can gather information. As of Sept. 12, the age minimum for LinkedIn membership will be lowered to 14 from 18.On the downside, Evercore Partners (EVR) underperformed, falling 77 cents to 46.68 in soft volume. The investment banking advisory firm recently broke out over 44.63. Its weekly chart is still sound as the stock trades tightly above its 10-week moving average.

Stock indexes rebounded Thursday, but the day's headline was provided by a three-hour shutdown in the Nasdaq due to technical issues. The Nasdaq popped 1.1%, while the S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average added 0.9% and 0.4% respectively. The IBD 50 rose 1.1%. Volume fell on both major exchanges. Even before the Nasdaq's shutdown, top-rated stocks weren't attracting…

Shares of FleetCor Technologies (FLT) hit a new high Thursday, one day after the stock cleared a follow-on chart pattern. The stock had formed a four-weeks-tight pattern. It moved above the 85.66 buy point Wednesday in heavy trading. Shares closed Thursday within the normal 5% buy range, which goes to 89.94. The payment-card company's stock has more than doubled since…

Stocks ended with solid gains Friday after battling back from weakness spurred by a disappointing jobs report. The Nasdaq and the S&P 500 ended up 1.7% and 1.4%, respectively. Both were down 1.6% at Friday's low. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 1.2%. According to preliminary data, volume ended higher across the board in the stock market today.Among leading stocks, Dave & Buster's Entertainment (PLAY) reversed higher to a 6% gain. The stock had already risen 3% Thursday, following the pricing of a share offering. Dave & Buster's was recently featured in Stock Spotlight.Verisk Analytics (VRSK) stretched its win streak to four straight sessions. It rebounded from a 2% loss and rose 2%. The stock nearly reached a 79.98 buy point in a flat base. Verisk, which provides data to insurance underwriters and banks, will be added to the S&P 500 after Wednesday's close.Tyler Technologies (TYL) added 2% for its second straight new high. It's now 15% past a 145.84 buy point from a flat base cleared Sept. 14. On Thursday, the company announced that it would buy privately held New World Systems for $670 million in cash and stock.Domino's Pizza (DPZ) climbed 0.5% after bucking morning weakness. It failed to retake its 200-day moving average. Domino's will report Q3 earnings Thursday. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters see the pizza chain's profit rising 17% to 74 cents a share..
When the stock market returned to uptrend last week, that was the signal to update watch lists one more time and scout for companies near a buy point.

The IBD 50 list includes the highest-rated stocks based on a variety of fundamental and technical factors. Today we'll look at the IBD 50's five top stocks — literally the best of the best. Notably, all five are leaders in growing, defensible niche markets: FleetCor Technologies (FLT), Green Mountain Coffee Roasters (GMCR), Nu Skin Enterprises (NUS), Jazz Pharmaceuticals (JAZZ) and Lithia Motors (LAD).
FleetCor provides specialized payment processing products to companies in 24 countries, and is known for its fuel cards that fleet transportation companies provide to drivers.
The payment processor's defensible niche market makes it a frequent visitor to the IBD 50 list. It boasts a 98 IBD Composite Rating, meaning it's outperformed 98% of all stocks.
Shares were roughly unchanged in Friday stock market trading.

Green Mountain also is the No. 1 single-serve coffee system maker with its Keurig brand hot beverage makers and coffee/tea pods. It's established partnerships with (IBD 50's) coffeehouse giant Starbucks (SBUX) and others, and is expanding into new markets, including single-serve soups with Campbell Soup (CPB). Green Mountain rose 1%.

Nu Skin Enterprises, which is also on the IBD Leaderboard premium list of top stocks with buy and sell points, sells nutritional shakes and other weight-loss products and offerings. Nu Skin is booming in Asia as well as the U.S., and is planning to roll out a new weight loss program called the ageLOC TR90 system. CEO Truman Hunt says it will be the Nu Skin's "largest product launch ever." Shares slid 1% Friday.

Like its fellow IBD 50 top 5 listers, Jazz Pharmaceuticals is firmly entrenched in its niche, specialty drugs. For example, more than 20% of the 50,000 diagnosed U.S. narcolepsy patients use its flagship Xyrem drug, which is projected to see annual sales of $600 million this year. Its leukemia drug Erwinaze and Prialt, for managing severe pain, are also seeing rising sales.
Its stock climbed 89% from a 50.76 low on April 16 to an all-time intraday high of 89 on Sept. 3. It's pulled back slightly, falling fractionally Friday to close at 87.18.

Car dealership chain Lithia Motors focuses on rural locations, where it's often the only dealer in town. Its sales, profits and stock price surged out of the financial crisis in sync with powerful recovery in U.S. auto sales. Its stock, which traded at 5.87 a share on July 9, 2010, closed up 1% at 70.18 on Friday, a 1,416% gain in a bit more than three years.

The Dow and S&P 500 were poised to snap three-session losing streaks Wednesday as better-than-expected trade data out of China put the market in a good mood.

With a little more than one hour remaining in the session, the Nasdaq rose 0.6%, the S&P 500 0.5% and the Dow Jones industrial average 0.3%. Preliminary data showed NYSE and Nasdaq volume tracking 10% higher than Wednesday.

In the stock market today, SouFun Holdings (SFUN) gapped up after reporting another solid quarter of growth. Shares of the China-based online real estate firm soared 12% in heavy volume. It's now 33% past a recent buy point of 29.26.

In the IBD 50, Portfolio Recovery Associates (PRAA) continued work on the right side of a base, rising 3% in solid turnover. In late-July, the debt-collection firm reported strong second-quarter earnings with profit up 37% from a year ago and sales up 24%. For the full-year, earnings are seen rising 35% to $3.31 a share.
Also in the IBD 50, FleetCor Technologies (FLT) continues to hold gains nicely after last week's earnings inspired gap up. Shares rose 2% in light trade.

In the retail space, L Brands (LTD) recent base-on-base breakout gained traction after the parent company of Victoria's Secret and Bath and Body Works reported strong July sales data and also raised its second-quarter earnings guidance. Shares gained 5% in healthy volume. The issue with Limited Brand is that its most recent breakout was from a risky fifth-stage base.
After the close, watch for earnings from Priceline.com (PCLN), Tableau Software (DATA) and Bonanza Creek Energy (BCEI)

Tableau Software went public in May at 31 and has doubled in price. It's currently working on the right side of a cup-with-handle base and sits just 2% off its all-time high. The provider of visualized analytics software isn't profitable yet but shows strong sales growth in recent quarters. After a wild week in the market, most IBD 50 stocks have escaped with little damage, although a few were left in a weakened state.

Overall, the median IBD 50 stock closed the week a moderate 6% below the 52-week high, using the list from last Monday's edition. In another sign of resilience, the majority finished high in their weekly price ranges.
One consequence was that several IBD 50 stocks found support at the 10-week moving average, and may be considered for further research.
Biogen Idec (BIIB), Celgene (CELG), FleetCor Technologies (FLT), Proto Labs (PRLB) and Ocwen Financial (OCN) are among the leaders making rebounds at the right places.

Portfolio Recovery Associates (PRAA) also rose from support, but the debt-collection company broke out of a risky later-stage base before making its pullback. Thus, its pullback also should be regarded as riskier.
Epam Systems (EPAM) and InvenSense (INVN) rallied sharply from support, but their shares have already become extended from a proper buy area.
Some have made repeated pullbacks to the 10-week line, and that fact alone makes those stocks too extended. Lithia Motors (LAD) is one example.
Jazz Pharmaceuticals (JAZZ) did not recover so well. It closed the week below its 10-week line and fell as much as 10% from an 89.10 buy point.
TripAdvisor (TRIP), which has been having its chart problems, also closed below the 10-week average. It sank as much as 14% below the 79.18 buy point of a cup with handle.
The big winner was Spirit Airlines (SAVE). The deep-discount carrier broke out of a cup-with-handle base with a 35.26 buy point, gapping up 15% Friday.
Spirit shares surged on a bullish passenger-traffic report.

For the week, the IBD 50 fell 3.4% — its worst week since May. Tuesday's broad sell-off marked the IBD 50's worst day of the year so far. It was off as much 9.1% at the week's low. By comparison, the S&P 500 rose 0.8% and the Nasdaq fell 0.4% last week.
Although the index of top-performing stocks closed above its 10-week average, its rising Relative Strength line hooked lower.

The index's weakness reflects the intense selling that swarmed over the leading stocks, which was harsher than anything many of these stocks had seen all year.After a wild week in the market, most IBD 50 stocks have escaped with little damage, although a few were left in a weakened state.Overall, the median IBD 50 stock closed the week a moderate 6% below the 52-week high, using the list from last Monday's edition. A few leading stocks had notable reactions to recent earnings reports Friday. FleetCor Technologies (FLT) gapped up and rallied 7%, thanks to better-than-expected Q2 results released late Thursday. The stock started strong Friday and closed near its session high. Volume spiked 138% above average, marking FleetCor's busiest session in more than a month. The stock ended 10% past an 89.85…
Sellers were back in the market Wednesday after Tuesday's lower-volume gains.

Just over two hours into the session, the Nasdaq took the hardest hit, falling 1%, weighed down byAmbarella (AMBA), Hain Celestial (HAIN) and Buffalo Wild Wings (BWLD). No news was readily available on Ambarella, but Hain Celestial and Buffalo Wild Wings reported earnings.

The S&P 500 fell 0.5%. It's only 2% above its 200-day moving average, a long-term support level. The Dow Jones industrial average eased 0.1%. Nasdaq volume was tracking 6% higher than Tuesday. NYSE volume fell 7%.

Before the open, the ADP private employment report came in pretty much as expected. Private payrolls rose 175,000 in January, slightly better than the consensus estimate of 170,000. The data come ahead of Friday's jobs report. Non-farm payrolls are seen rising 181,000 with the unemployment rate holding steady at 6.7%. The economy created a paltry 74,000 jobs in December.
In the stock market today, 3D Systems (DDD) crashed 17% after issuing disappointing preliminary Q4 results.

Meanwhile, casino operators took heat in huge volume on news that Macau gaming revenue in January rose just 7% from a year ago. Melco Crown Entertainment (MPEL) lost 6%; Wynn Resorts (WYNN) gave up 3.5% and Las Vegas Sands (LVS) fell 2%.

Bright spots were few and far between Wednesday but Tableau Software (DATA) was one. Shares soared 14%. Late Tuesday, the data analytics firm smashed Q4 estimates with profit of 23 cents a share, up 667% from a year ago. Sales growth accelerated for the third straight quarter, rising 95% to $81.5 million.

Sales growth accelerated for the third straight quarter, rising 95% to $81.5 million.After the close, earnings reports are due from the likes of FleetCor Technologies (FLT), Green Mountain Coffee Roasters (GMCR), Pandora Media (P), Sierra Wireless (SWIR), Twitter (TWTR) and Yelp (YELP).

Financial, retail and health care stocks bulked up on 52-week highs Friday, while at least four breakouts occurred among leading companies. Biotechs and other drug companies continued to be the standard-bearers for the medical sector.
