Stocks slip into negative action, showing narrow losses at midday Wednesday. The Nasdaq, the S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average were each off 0.1%. Volume started strong on the stock market today, but slipped into tightly mixed action before midday: Trading is higher on the NYSE but a tad lower on the Nasdaq. The market navigated a morning…
Stocks rallied in light volume Tuesday, one day after a wave of selling knocked the Nasdaq nearly 6% off its recent high.
At the close, the Nasdaq rose 0.9%, the S&P 500 added 0.8% and the Dow Jones industrial average gained 0.5%. Preliminary data showed NYSE and Nasdaq volume coming in well below Monday's levels.

In the after-hours session, data analytics firm Tableau Software (DATA) soared 16% after reporting non-GAAP profit of 20 cents a share, easily topping the consensus estimate for break-even earnings. Revenue surged 95% to $81.5 million, well above the estimate for $67 million.

Buffalo Wild Wings (BWLD), meanwhile, rose 1% in late trading after the restaurant chain reported profit of $1.10 a share, 3 cents ahead of views and a 22% increase from a year ago. Sales rose 12% to $341.5 million, slightly below expectations. Same-store sales at company-owned stores rose 5.2%. Wall Street seemed to like news that same-store sales for the first five weeks of 2014 were up 4.8%, well ahead of last year's pace of 0.2%.

In the stock market today, Michael Kors (KORS) vaulted 17% on strong earnings. Profit and sales growth accelerated sharply from the prior quarter, rising 73% and 59%, respectively. Same-store sales in North America rose 24%. In Europe, they rose 73%. Fund ownership in Kors has nearly doubled over the past year, from 551 funds at the end of 2012 to 958 funds at the end of 2013.

Elsewhere, TransDigm Group (TDG) bounced off its 10-week moving average again after a November breakout. Shares rose 4%. Earlier today, the maker of components for commercial aircraft reported its second straight quarter of accelerating sales growth, fueled by recent acquisitions.

On the downside, U.K.-based chip designer ARM Holdings (ARMH) sank 4%. Earnings of 26 cents a share matched expectations, rising 30% from a year ago. But sales growth decelerated sharply from the prior quarter, rising just 17% to $313.2 million, hurt by slower growth in smartphone sales. It was the smallest increase in six quarters.

The leading stocks from IBD's 33 sector groups fell across the board Tuesday as the market sold off.But volume was mostly tame and many remain within reach of their recent highs.Chinese gaming website NetEase (NTES) was the only leader to fall in heavy volume. It lost 2.76 to end at 73.36 in turnover that was 51% above normal.The stock is now 5% off a record high of 76.42, hit the previous day. Despite Tuesday's loss, NetEase is still well out of buying range, 13% beyond a 65.18 entry.Questcor Pharmaceuticals (QCOR) was also among a number of Leaders that came off highs hit Monday. It was Tuesday's biggest loser, slumping 3.85 — or 5% — to 68.49. It's now 2% past a 66.92 buy point from a three-weeks-tight pattern, a secondary buy pattern.The finance sector ranked No. 8 out of 33 on Tuesday, but its leading stocks posted the biggest losses Tuesday.Ocwen Financial (OCN), which buys and services distressed mortgage loans, dropped 2.26, or 4%, to end at 49.80. The stock briefly cleared a three-weeks-tight buy point at 52.35 on Monday, but volume was weak and it ended the day below the entry.FleetCor Technologies (FLT) held up best among financial leaders, sliding 1.53 to 103.17 and ending just 4% off Monday's record high. FleetCor, which provides fuel cards to commercial vehicle fleets, is now 2% above a 100.97 buy point in a three-weeks-tight pattern.Also, Evercore Partners (EVR), an investment bank, fell 2.03 to 44.34, slipping below a 44.63 entry from a long consolidation.It had been up as much as 9%. Investors should take profits before a stock retreats to its buy point, especially during a market correction.

FleetCor Technologies  (FLT) led a number of sector-leading stocks to test new highs Monday. Finance, medical and software stocks performed especially well. FleetCor, which provides fuel cards to commercial vehicle fleets, climbed 1.88 to 104.70 in heavy volume. It's now 4% above a 100.97 buy point in a three-weeks-tight pattern. The 15 or so Sector Leaders were mixed Thursday, with a breakout among them highlighting the day's action. Major averages scored nice gains Thursday despite a lengthy trading glitch on the Nasdaq that skewed volume. Several Sector Leaders followed the market higher.Priceline.com (PLCN) continues to act well after a recent breakout. Shares of the online travel firm rose 11.95 to 952.15. Priceline cleared a flat-base buy point of 847.43 in July. Soon after, it cleared a three-weeks-tight pattern. Priceline is one of several leaders showing little in the way of sell signals, a feather in the bulls' cap for now.FleetCor Technologies (FLT) soared 6.16 to 103.12. It cleared a three-weeks-tight pattern with a buy point of 100.97 Its fuel cards and workforce payment products help businesses get a better handle on spending.Elsewhere, Alexion Pharmaceuticals (ALXN) gained 1.45 to 106.77. Shares soared 18% during the week ended July 12, but the breakout never got going. On a daily chart, the stock is firming up at its 50-day moving average. On a weekly chart, Alexion undercut its 10-week moving average, but it closed slightly above the line Thursday.Alexion has made a big run in recent years, but it recently reset its base count because the low in its latest 39-week consolidation undercut the low of a prior base.Meanwhile, a look at Actavis' (ACT) chart shows tight, orderly trade, but the stock hasn't made much progress after a recent breakout from a flat base over 133.10. Shares picked up 1.43 to 134.70. It's pulled back to within buying range in recent days, but with the market still in a correction, new buys should generally be avoided.Actavis, formerly known as Watson Pharmaceuticals, is in the process of acquiring Warner Chilcott (WCRX). The $8.5 billion deal is expected to close in the fourth quarter.

Retailers and other consumer names led the list of stocks hitting new highs Thursday, thanks in part to strong earnings reports. The company said late Wednesday that profit for its fiscal fourth quarter that ended in…

Even though the market's in a correction, some Sector Leaders continue to tempt investors, trading tightly after recent breakouts or sitting close to recent buy points. FleetCor Technologies (FLT) rose 15 cents…

Evercore Partners (EVR), a provider of advisory services to firms on mergers and acquisitions, divestitures and restructurings, rose 0.96 to 46.56. Modest declines for the Nasdaq and S&P 500 Wednesday in lighter volume resulted in another day of outperformance for several Sector Leaders.Actavis (ACT) fared the best, rising 3.30 to 137.94 in heavy volume. Low-volume pullbacks to buy points can be constructive, and that's exactly what Actavis did recently. It's now 4% above a recent 133.10 entry. Shares remain under accumulation.Elsewhere, Yandex (YNDX) added 0.50 to 33.70 in 38% faster turnover. Fundamentals are top-notch for the top Web search provider in Russia. Revenue growth accelerated when the company reported second-quarter earnings last month. Annual return on equity and pretax profit margin are solid at 27% and 39% respectively. Full-year earnings are seen rising 33% this year and 28% in 2014.Yandex hit an intraday high of 34.79, up 21% from a prior buy point of 28.74. A key IBD sell rule is to take a 20% gain in a stock whenever you have it. One exception is when a stock rallies 20% in less than three weeks after a breakout. In this case, the stock should be held for eight weeks.The chart of FleetCor Technologies (FLT), meanwhile, continues to show tight trading after a recent breakout from a flat base. Shares rose 1.98 to 99.43 in brisk trade.Web.com Group (WWWW) outperformed, rising 0.64 to 28.58 in heavy volume. It recently found support at its 10-week moving average for the second time after a big breakout in early May. Adding to a position when a stock finds support at the 10-week line is sound strategy, but Web.com is extended from the buy area.Sellers finally came into LinkedIn (LNKD) Wednesday. Shares slumped 5.49 to 236.33 in 10% slower volume. The stock continues to hold above its 10-day moving average, a short-term support level.
Most Sector Leaders scored gains Thursday, as the market climbed for a third straight session. Although volume was below average in many of the gainers, there were a couple of exceptions.

Web.com Group (WWWW) rallied 0.64, or 3%, to 25.01. Thursday's lift marked its third straight new high. But the stock closed in the lower half of its trading range. Turnover surged more than three times average Thursday, making it the busiest session since May 3.
The stock cleared a 22.94 buy point from a three-weeks-tight add-on pattern June 19. It's now 9% past that trigger.
HomeAway (AWAY) rose 0.15 to 32.53 in volume that jumped 44% above average. The stock extended its win streak to six sessions following a wild session Thursday.
Shares slumped as much as 6% in the opening minutes, but the stock staged a comeback after finding support at its 50-day moving average. HomeAway is in a cup base with a 34.40 buy point.

Proto Labs (PRLB)climbed for the fourth straight session to an all-time high. It added 1.09, or 2%, to 66.38. Volume cooled off from the hectic pace of the prior three sessions, but still ended a little above average. Proto Labs closed 11% past a 59.94 entry from a flat base cleared on June 18.

FleetCor Technologies (FLT) gave up early gains and dropped 1.75, or 2%, to 83.16 in heavy trading. The downside reversal nearly erased gains from the past two sessions. But FleetCor closed above its 50-day moving average, which has acted as support lately. The 80 price level has also been support in recent sessions.

The stock market halted a three-day slide Tuesday as the Nasdaq led a bounce in the major indexes. The Nasdaq surged 0.8% and the S&P 500 0.4%. Both closed near session highs, a positive sign. It was an uncharacteristic day of leadership for the Nasdaq, which has watched the S&P 500 emerge as the leading index. At just 2% off…

Qiwi (QIWI), a Russian operator of electronic payment systems, has soared since going public in May.The stock debuted May 3 at $17 and has risen rapidly, hitting a high of 50.65 on Nov. 22 before pulling back. It's 8% off the high and is extended from a rebound off its 10-week line. Investors should wait for the stock to shape a new base.Qiwi, which ranks No. 2 in the IBD 50, charges a small fee to customers who deposit money into its kiosks to pay bills. Qiwi says more than 60 million consumers use its network of kiosks in Russia and neighboring countries at least once a month.Meanwhile, Qiwi has teamed up with Visa to offer the Visa Qiwi Wallet, which allows customers to use their cellphones to pay bills or buy items online.Qiwi's growth has been fueled by worries about credit card fraud in Russia, which has prompted more than 90% of Russians to pay bills or make purchases with cash, either by kiosk or by cellphone.Profit for the current quarter ending this month is expected to jump 142% to 29 cents a share, building on gains ranging from 46% to 211% over the prior three quarters. Revenue growth has gone from 25% to 35% to 20% over the past three periods.Qiwi boasts a best-possible 99 Composite and Earnings Per Share ratings. It's a top stock in the 25-member Finance-Credit Card/Payment Processor industry group, which on Monday was rated 19th out of 197 groups. The group includes other leading stocks such as FleetCor (FLT), MasterCard (MA) and Visa (V).Qiwi faces competition from Yandex.Money, which is 75% owned by Sberbank, Russia's largest bank, with the rest being held by Yandex, the country's biggest Internet search engine. Meanwhile, U.S.-based PayPal, owned by eBay (EBAY), has won approval to enter the Russian market.Demand for Qiwi's shares has been strong, as evidenced by the stock's robust A- Accumulation/Distribution Rating and 1.9 up-down volume ratio.Analysts expect profit to jump 88% this year to $1.24 a share, followed by a 27% gain in 2014 to $1.57. Meanwhile, annual pretax margin was 17% last year and return on equity was a robust 43%.Russia's small but rapidly growing e-commerce market is expected to boost Qiwi's earnings going forward. William Blair recently forecast that e-commerce in the country will rise 44% annually on average from 2012 to 2014.

The market enjoyed another shot of institutional buying Friday, cheered by additional — and unexpected — stimulus measures by the Bank of Japan. Another round of healthy earnings reports and a rise in U.S. consumer confidence also fueled positive sentiment.

At the close, the Nasdaq rose 1.4%, the S&P 500 added 1.2% and the Dow Jones industrial average gained 1.1%. Preliminary data showed NYSE and Nasdaq volume coming in higher than Thursday's levels. For the week, the Dow rose 3.5%; the Nasdaq picked up 3.3% and the S&P 500 added 2.7%.

In the stock market today, several names in the IBD 50 turned in solid performances. One of the best performers was Ambarella (AMBA). Shares gained 6%. The stock was a beneficiary of strong earnings from GoPro (GPRO) late Thursday. Ambarella's chips are found in GoPro's wearable cameras.

Late Thursday, GoPro reported earnings of 12 cents a share, up sharply from 1 cent in the year-ago quarter. Sales rose 46% to $280 million. The company also gave a rosy holiday outlook. GoPro surged 13%.

IBD 50 name FleetCor (FLT) also rose sharply. Shares jumped 6% on strong earnings. The stock closed nearly 3% above an early entry point of 146.39. Shares hit an all-time high early but closed well off session highs.
LinkedIn (LNKD), meanwhile, gapped up and closed just below a buy point of 232.38. Shares jumped 13%. A strong profit report was the catalyst here as well.

December gold slumped $27, or 2.3%, to settle at $1,171.60 an ounce. For the week, it slumped 5.3%. December crude oil lost 58 cents, or 0.7%, to $80.54 a barrel. The price of oil fell 12% in October.

Stocks held on to the majority of big gains Friday afternoon as the major indices tried to book another week of solid gains.
The Nasdaq held up 1.3%, while the Dow and S&P 500 each added 0.9%. Volume continued to track higher on both the NYSE and Nasdaq exchanges.
Base breakouts continued in the stock market today as the recent uptrend continued to show strength.

FleetCor Technologies (FLT) jumped 5% in heavy trade, breaking out past a 150.02 buy point in a cup-shaped base. Thursday after the close, the company reported third-quarter earnings growth of 27% on a 31% jump in revenues. Both numbers topped analysts' estimates.
Virtusa (VRTU) added 7% in heavy volume. The stock cleared a 38.59 entry from a seven-month consolidation after reporting earnings before the open Friday.
Other earnings-inspired jumps left stocks just below potential entry points.

LinkedIn (LNKD) shot 13% higher in huge trade, leaving the stock just below a potential 232.38 buy point from a cup-shaped base. The company's third-quarter earnings report helped ease fears of slowing growth and led a number of analysts to raise their price target for the stock.

Chip technology firm Tessera Technologies (TSRA) rose 9% in big trade, nearing a 30.10 buy point from a cup-shaped base. Thursday after the close, the company reported earnings ahead of expectations and issued favorable revenue guidance for the fourth quarter.

GoPro, LinkedIn, FleetCor Technologies and Starbucks are four notable companies that are set to report earnings after the close on Thursday. Here's a look at what analysts expect.

The action camera maker is expected to earn 8 cents a share on revenue of $266 million. Q2 was GoPro's (GPRO) first quarter as a publicly traded company, and it earned 10 cents a share on revenue of $245 million, topping expectations for both measures.

Shares are up about 180% since the company went public at 24 in June. But GoPro is more than 30% off its all-time high of 98.46 on Oct. 7 and down 3.8% in the stock market today heading into its quarterly results. GoPro is currently on Leaderboard's Leaders List.
LinkedIn (LNKD) is projected to earn 47 cents a share, a 21% gain from last year. Revenue is seen climbing 42% to $557 million.
The professional social network is a former Leaderboard stock that has been building a base for more than a year. Earnings in 2015 are expected to rebound 47%. Shares dipped 1.4%.
FleetCor Technologies (FLT) is projected to see a 24% boost in earnings to $1.34 a share. Revenue is expected to jump 26% to $283 million.
The provider of fuel-payment cards for trucking and other fleet operators is on the IBD 50 list of top stocks. Shares dipped 0.1%.
Starbucks (SBUX) is expected to earn 74 cents a share, a 17% rise from last year in its 2014 fiscal Q4. Revenue is seen growing 12% to $4.2 billion.

The coffeehouse chain announced in late September that it would buy the remaining 60.5% of Starbucks Coffee Japan that it didn't already own. Starbucks said it expects the deal to be "slightly accretive" to its fiscal 2015 results. Shares were little changed as of midday Thursday.
Make sure to watch our video report by IBD TV's Alissa Williams.

The S&P; 500 closed at a new high Tuesday, which technically put the market back in an uptrend. But conditions remain difficult. The S&P; 500 and Dow Jones industrial average extended their winning streaks to five sessions, but the Nasdaq couldn't keep up, weighed down by a burst of institutional selling in the biotech space. Bulls rumbled ahead Friday, as the major stock indexes pushed to good gains in strong volume. The Nasdaq pegged a 1.4% gain, while the S&P; 500 and Dow Jones industrial average added 1.2% and 1.1%, respectively. The IBD 50 tacked on 1.2%. Volume rose across the board. The Nasdaq hit a 52-week high, while the S&P; 500 is closing in…

An early bounce in the main indexes faded Tuesday, as the market remained hobbled. The Nasdaq, up as much as 0.9% at one point, closed with a loss of 1.2%. The S&P; 500 also reversed lower, shedding 0.8%. Both closed at session lows. The small-cap Russell 2000 was nearly flat after giving up a big gain. Declining stocks led advancers…

Stocks remained lower in early afternoon trading Tuesday as an analyst warning on the new Apple iPhone hurt shares of the company and its suppliers.The Nasdaq was off 0.6% while the S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average were off 0.2%.Volume was tracking lower on the NYSE and higher on the Nasdaq. Declining stocks had a small edge over advancers on the NYSE while the losers led by 7-to-5 on the Nasdaq.Solar energy, automaker, staffing and dairy product companies were among the poorest performers in the stock market today. Tesla (TSLA) skidded more than 3%, sinking deeper below its 50-day and 200-day moving averages.Metal, retail, utility and real estate investment trust industry groups were some of the best Tuesday.Some suppliers of the Apple (AAPL) iPhone were lower after Credit Suisse warned that the company was cutting back component orders for the iPhone 6S model.Apple shares gapped down to a 3% loss in above-average volume. Cirrus Logic (CRUS) slid 7% in busy trading and fell below the 50-day moving average. Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) gapped below its 50-day moving average as it shed 6% in heavy trading.On the plus side, Ruth's Hospitality (RUTH), better known as Ruth's Chris Steak House, cleared the 16.96 buy point of a double-bottom base in active trading.The company beat Q3 earnings expectations a couple of weeks ago as EPS jumped 33%. The restaurant industry group, though, has been trending lower in IBD's group rankings.

At the close, the Nasdaq lost 0.8%, the S&P 500 gave up 0.7%, and the Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.6%. Weak economic data out of China were partly to blame. With the market in correction mode, investors have to watch out for stocks setting off sell signals. Two Sector Leaders from Wednesday's paper, Salix Pharmaceuticals (SLXP) and FleetCor Technologies (FLT), staged round trips from their recent breakouts. A round trip is a sell signal that takes place when a stock gives up a double-digit gain after clearing a buy point.…

Sector Leaders rebounded along with the broad market Friday as FleetCor Technologies (FLT) found support at its 50-day moving average. The company, which came public in late 2010, is one of the top fuel-card providers in the U.S. for commercial vehicle fleets. It links gasoline stations with card users through its own electronic network. The stock climbed 0.91 to 129.55…

Last week Staples (SPLS) became the latest retailer to investigate a possible credit card data breach. But analysts still seem bullish on plastic despite the uptick in security issues leading into the holiday season.

Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters are expecting Visa (V) to report a 13.5% jump in earnings to $2.10 per share when it announces quarterly results Wednesday. Revenue is expected to climb 7.3% to $3.2 billion.
Last week Visa raised its dividend 20% to 48 cents a share, payable on Dec. 2.
MasterCard (MA) is slated to report Thursday. Analysts forecast a 7% rise in EPS to 78 cents per share with a 10.3% rise in revenue to $2.45 billion.
Home Depot (HD) and Target (TGT) are among the other retailers with extensive data and credit card security hacks.
In response to the breaches, Apple's (APPL) new Apple Pay in the iPhone 6 and 6 Plus is supposed to be more secure, as card numbers aren't stored on the device, only a device-specific account number.
But analysts wonder if the system really is secure in the wake of hackers leaking personal celebrity photos from the cloud.
Rite Aid (RAD) and CVS Health (CVS) won't accept payments from the system and instead are backing CurrentC, a similar technology in development by Merchant Customer Exchange (MCX).
MCX has been working on the system since 2011 in an effort to help retailers avoid 2% to 3% fees charged by credit card companies like Visa.
"I don't know that MCX will succeed, and I don't care. As long as Visa suffers," former Wal-Mart (WMT) CEO Lee Scott reportedly said.
Visa shares were dipped 0.1% in the stock market today. MasterCard rose 0.3% intraday.
Fuel card firm FleetCor Technologies (FLT) is slated to report earnings Thursday as well.
Analysts are expecting EPS to rise 24% to $1.34 and revenue to climb 25.6% to $282.7 million.

The Finance-Credit Card group is ranked No. 25 out of the 197 industry groups tracked by IBD. Visa has a 91 Composite Rating, meaning it's outperforming 91% of stocks based on key metrics like earnings growth.
MasterCard has an 86 rating.

Shares of FleetCor rose 2.3% to 135.19 in early afternoon trading on the stock market today, clearing a six-week consolidation. The stock hit an all-time high of 136.63 early.…

The stock market showed dull action Wednesday — perhaps a day when dull is actually a good thing. The biggest item on equity trading desks' minds was likely the minutes from the Federal Reserve's July 29-30 meeting on interest rates, released at 2 p.m. ET. Market watchers look at such reports to find any fresh clues about how and when…

Though financial technology stocks underperformed the broader equity markets in the third quarter, Sterne Agee says two stocks in the group are good bets: SEI Investments (SEIC) and Wright Express (WEX).

SEI Investments provides technology and asset management services to institutions and investment advisers. It may be close to signing its first major U.S. client to its new Wealth Management platform.
Investors sent shares up more than 6% on July 23 after management disclosed during reporting of Q2 results that SEI was helping a prospective U.S. client conduct due diligence on the new platform.

Shares have since retreated, but Sterne Agee analyst Thomas McCrohan said in a Monday note that the recent pullback "presents an attractive buying opportunity heading into the quarter." SEI reports Q3 results on Wednesday.

McCrohan also likes Wright Express, which provides payment processing and information management services to vehicle-fleet operators. Despite lower gasoline prices, he expects Wright to post per-share earnings above Wall Street views — which call for just 4% growth — due to its strong virtual-card business.
He expects Wright's volume to grow 45% in Q3, up from 36% growth in Q2.
Though IBD's Finance-Investment Management Group is ranked a relatively low 121 of 197 industry groups tracked, SEI is one of the top-ranked stocks in it. It has a Composite Rating of 90 out of 99.
Another highly rated stock in the group is investment management giant BlackRock (BLK), with a CR of 91.

Wright Express is part of IBD's Credit Card-Payments industry group, which is ranked higher at 45 of 197 groups. Wright has a Composite Rating of 94. Stocks pushed to fresh session highs near Wednesday's midpoint as investors shrugged off lackluster retail sales data.

Thanks to strength in solar, biotechs and online retail, the Nasdaq rallied 0.9% to its best levels since July 31. The S&P 500 climbed 0.7%, and the Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.6%. Volume was running mixed in the stock market today. NYSE trade was tracking about 3% higher, while Nasdaq volume ran around 3% lower.

Among leading stocks, FleetCor Technologies (FLT) stretched its gain to 6%, putting it 2% past a 134.12 buy point from a flat base. Late Tuesday, the company said that it would buy online payment services provider Comdata for $3.45 billion. The deal is expected to add between 50 cents and 60 cents a share to earnings in 2015.

April new issue GrubHub (GRUB) bolted 6% to an all-time high. It's now 6% past the 39.22 buy point that it regained Tuesday. It initially broke out July 29 but sold off and triggered the 8% sell rule a couple of sessions later.

AerCap Holdings (AER) added nearly 3%, putting it further north of its 50-day line. On Tuesday, the aircraft leasing company reported earnings Q2 earnings that surged 119% to $1.29 a share. Sales swelled 227% to $806.8 million. The stock is building a potential flat base with a 48.91 buy point.

Parsley Energy (PE) turned a 5% gain into a 2% loss. Late Tuesday, the Midland, Texas-based oil and gas company reported Q2 results above views. Ending weeks of speculation, fuel-card provider FleetCor Technologies (FLT) late Tuesday agreed to buy business-to-business e-payments firm Comdata for $3.45 billion, saying the deal would "dramatically" increase its "overall scale, earnings base and diversity."
FleetCor, which said the deal would boost 2015 earnings, rose 3% to about 133.60 in after-hours trading. Shares had closed down nearly 2% to 129.44.
Comdata facilitates more than $54 billion in payments a year and supplies items such as fleet cards and virtual cards to a customer base of more than 20,000.

"Comdata's virtual payments business will add a completely new growth leg to FleetCor," said CEO Ron Clarke in a press release. "We believe that the combination will result in significant synergies as we implement our operating disciplines to their portfolio of businesses."

Georgia-based FleetCor provides fleet cards and payment services to commercial fleets, oil companies and petroleum marketers. The company has partnerships with brands that include Shell (RDSA), BP (BP) and MasterCard (MA) .
The company is acquiring Comdata from Ceridian, which is affiliated with Thomas H. Lee Partners LP and Fidelity National Financial (FNF). A THL representative will get a seat on FleetCor's board.

The deal is expected to close by the end of the year. It will be financed by about $2.4 billion in new debt and 7.3 million shares of common stock to Ceridian, with cash payment going toward Comdata's outstanding debt.
FleetCor reported earnings at the end of July. Earnings per share grew 27% to $1.27, beating by 2 cents. Revenue increased 23.8% to $273.5 million, just falling short of analyst estimates.
Shares had spiked to a new high of 138.19 on July 31, ahead of earnings, on talk of a Comdata deal, then pulled back on the mixed results.
FleetCor expects Comdata to be "meaningfully accretive" to earnings in 2015. It sees the company contributing 50-60 cents per share for total consolidated adjusted EPS of $6.25 to $6.45.

"While our financial leverage will increase, we expect to de-lever quickly from the combined cash flow of the businesses," said CFO Eric Dey in the release. "The new credit facility will also provide additional liquidity for future business development activity."
Buyout firms Carlyle Group (CG) and Silver Lake Partners reportedly had been interested in Comdata.

FleetCor is part of the IBD 50 list of top-rated stocks. Volume rose slightly on the NYSE but eased on the Nasdaq. Action has been sleepy on the Nasdaq recently. On Thursday, volume on the Nasdaq fell for a…

He or she can concentrate a portfolio on a handful of stocks and can reduce exposure and raise cash quickly when necessary. Stocks were near session highs in early afternoon trading Wednesday after shrugging off weaker-than-expected July retail sales data.
The Nasdaq, powered by biotechs and solar stocks, held a 0.9% gain. The S&P 500 rose 0.7% and Dow industrial picked up 0.6%. Volume was tracking higher on both exchanges in the stock market today.
Retail sales were flat in July, below forecasts for a 0.2% gain and down from June's 0.2% increase. Excluding autos, sales climbed 0.1% vs. views for a 0.4% gain.

Solar stocks led the upside among the 197 industry groups tracked by IBD, along with biotechs and credit card providers. IBD 50 component FleetCor Technologies (FLT), a provider of fuel card and workforce payment products, jumped 10% on news it's acquiring Comdata for $3.45 billion.

Canadian Solar (CSIQ) gapped up and soared 20% in massive turnover. The solar product maker reported better-than-expected Q2 earnings and revenue, as solar-module shipments rose 42% to 646 megawatts from last year and exceeded its forecast. It also turned around a year-ago loss.

BitAuto (BITA) climbed 1% to a new high, on pace for its sixth straight advance. Oppenheimer on Tuesday boosted its price target to 78 from 45. Shares surged 10% Monday after the Chinese automotive website topped Q2 earnings and sales forecasts. The stock is now extended 57% past a 47.03 cup-base buy point it cleared in late June.

Palo Alto Networks (PANW) rose 4% as it moved closer to an 85.88 flat-base buy point. Piper Jaffray on Tuesday began covering the stock with an overweight rating and set a 100 price target. Analysts expect the security software maker to expand fiscal Q4 profit 83% when it reports Sept. 9. That would mark a fourth consecutive quarter of 57% or better growth.

Jazz Pharmaceuticals (JAZZ) jumped 7% in more than twice normal volume. The specialty-drug maker last week reported Q2 results above estimates and lifted its revenue outlook. It spiked 5% that day before easing over the next few sessions.

Stocks opened higher in light trade Wednesday, shadowing gains in global markets.

The Nasdaq led with a 0.3% gain. The S&P 500 climbed 0.2% and the Dow Jones industrial average added 0.1%. Volume slipped about 4% on both the Nasdaq and the NYSE, compared to trade at the same time Tuesday.
The stock market today opened on mixed footing, with global markets rising despite a heavy dose of weak economic data. U.S. retail sales for June undercut expectations.
Business inventories expanded 0.4% in June, the Commerce Department reported, slightly below May's 0.5% gain but in line with analyst projections.

In stocks, Amazon.com (AMZN) cranked up a 3% gain after news reports said the company had launched a credit/debit card reader. The reader attaches to a cellphone, allowing small businesses or businesses operating on the fly to accept credit and debit payments.

Amazon had stumbled back below key levels of support in July, after a two month attempt to climb the right side of a consolidation begun in January. It's still nearly 19% below a 52-week peak of 408.06.

On the downside, Cree (CREE) tumbled 9% after its fiscal fourth quarter EPS cleared consensus estimates by a penny, but revenue stopped well short of projections. Management dropped both revenue and earnings guidance for the first quarter to the low end of analyst forecasts.
Department stores were also under pressure after a disappointing second quarter sent Macy's (M) down 4%. Kohl's (KSS) and Nordstrom (JWN) were down 3% and 2%, respectively.

Among leaders, FleetCor Technologies (FLT) jumped 4% in early trade. The vehicle fleet fuel credit operation said late Tuesday it would acquire online payments firm Comdata for $3.45 billion. Georgia-based FleetCor said the deal would dramatically increase the company's "overall scale, earnings base and diversity." Georgia-based FleetCor said the deal would dramatically increase the company's "overall scale, earnings base and diversity." Wednesday's early gain bumped shares back above a flat base buy point of 134.12.

Scores of leaders rallied to new highs as the overall market closed with big gains in higher volume. GrubHub (GRUB) bolted 5.85, or 15%, to a record-best 45.21 in triple the usual trade. The April new issue, which extended its win streak to four sessions, is 15% past a 39.22 buy point. It first cleared the entry in the first…
Stocks turned mixed near midday Monday amid a round of similarly mixed earnings reports, as well as economic reports both foreign and domestic.

The Nasdaq turned a 0.4% loss into a 0.3% gain. Biotechs and software issues outperformed. The S&P 500 pared a 0.5% deficit to 0.1%, while the Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.2%. Volume was tracking sharply lower across the board in the stock market today compared to the same time Friday.

Among highly rated stocks,Globant (GLOB) rallied nearly 4% to an all-time high and cleared a 35.10 buy point in heavy trading. About two hours into the session, the thin stock already matched its 50-day average volume.

Nike (NKE) climbed more than 1% to another new high after being upgraded to buy from hold at BB&T. It's now 12% past a 117.82 buy point. The athletic apparel and footwear giant was recently mentioned in the New Highs column.

On the downside, Microsemi (MSCC) dropped 6% on news that it offered $2.2 billion to buy PMC-Sierra (PMCS). Its bid topped a $2 billion buyout offer by Apple (AAPL) supplier Skyworks Solutions (SWKS). Microsemi fell below a 37.51 buy point from a consolidation cleared Friday. PMC shares jumped 14%.

Valeant (VRX) slumped 6% despite beating views and raising guidance. Before the open, the Canadian drugmaker posted adjusted Q3 earnings of $2.74 a share, up from $2.11 a year ago. Sales grew 36%, the third straight period of acceleration, to almost $2.79 billion. It lifted its full-year sales forecast to $11 billion-$11.2 billion from $10.7 billion-$11.1 billion.

Profit is now expected at $11.67 to $11.87 a share, up from a prior outlook of $11.50 to $11.80. Last week, Valeant said it received subpoenas from federal prosecutors in Massachusetts and New York, requesting information about its patient-assistance programs and drug-pricing decisions.

Stocks reversed lower Wednesday, ending a four-day run for the Nasdaq and the S&P 500.

The Nasdaq fell 0.8%, while the S&P 500 lost 0.7%. They were up as much as 0.4% each at Wednesday's highs. The Dow Jones industrial average lost 0.9%. Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) was a rare winner in the blue-chip index. CEO Alex Gorsky told Fox Business Network that the company hopes to have 250,000 doses of an Ebola vaccine by May.
According to preliminary data, volume ended mixed in the stock market today. Nasdaq trade was a smidge higher, while NYSE volume slipped.

Super Micro Computer (SMCI) gapped up and surged 9% in reaction to late Tuesday's solid quarterly results. Thanks to strong server sales, earnings more than doubled, while revenue grew 43%. The stock touched a new high Wednesday, but then faded a bit. Super Micro had a failed breakout past a 27.38 buy point from a flat base.

Illumina (ILMN)rose 3% in heavy trade, breaking out past a 182.37 buy point from a double-bottom base. The move followed a 9% surge Tuesday, after Illumina reported strong quarterly earnings and sales Monday.

Strong quarterly results also helped Yahoo (YHOO), which gapped up and rallied nearly 5% to a one-month high. After Tuesday's close, the Internet search portal reported a 53% rise in Q3 earnings, the biggest gain in two years. The company delivered a 1% gain in sales, the first increase in seven quarters.

Biogen Idec (BIIB) ended well off its session low but still lost 7% in heavy trading. Shares were off by as much as 11% following mixed quarterly results from the biotech. Cognex (CGNX) gapped up and rallied 5.31, or 14%, to 43.11 on strong Q2 results from late Monday. But shares were up as much as 21% intraday. The stock nearly fell 7% below a 40.24 buy point from a…

"I'm a travelin' man," Ricky Nelson warbled in 1961. "I've made a lot of stops all over the world." If he'd had access to the services of FleetCor Technologies (FLT), he might have saved money on those worldly travels. FleetCor provides fuel cards and payment services designed to help customers track and control costs. Its operating model is pretty simple:…

With earnings season still in full swing, leading stocks like Spirit Airlines (SAVE) and Trinity Industries (TRN) are poised to make big moves in the coming week as their quarterly results provide catalysts for investors.
The IBD 50 companies due to report over the next several days all have ties — direct or indirect — to the transportation sector.
Spirit is scheduled to report Tuesday, and analysts expect Q2 earnings per share to jump 41% to 89 cents, a sharp acceleration from gains of 16% and 17% in the prior two quarters.
Revenue is seen rising 22% to $498.7 million. The discount carrier's revenue growth over the last three years has outpaced peers, and it's just getting started.

The Miami-based airline plans to increase its fleet by 36% between October and the end of 2015, taking it from 58 to 79 planes. It's buying larger planes with more seats, so seat capacity will grow even faster. Morgan Stanley on July 16 reiterated an overweight rating, and raised its price target to 77 from 72.

But Evercore recently warned that the sharp increase in Spirit's fleet raises its execution risks and the likelihood of a competitive response as it downgraded the stock to equal-weight from overweight.

Trinity Industries (TRN), a manufacturer of steel components, railcars and inland barges, reports after the market closes on Tuesday. Earnings are expected to increase 43% to 77 cents a share, while revenue is seen rising 27% to $1.35 billion.

Last month, the Dallas-based company announced an agreement to acquire Thomas & Betts' utility steel structures division for about $600 million, and in May it completed a $1.1 billion railcar leasing joint venture.
Also during the quarter, Trinity declared a 2-for-1 stock split and a 33% increase in its quarterly dividend to 10 cents a share.
Demand for new railcars could soon increase as proposed safety rules for trains carrying flammable liquids prompt rail companies to refurbish their fleets to meet requirements.
Dealership operator Penske Automotive (PAG) is due to report Wednesday, and analysts see EPS rising 20% to 85 cents with revenue up 14% to $4.2 billion.

Penske and other dealership companies like Lithia (LAD) have benefitted from improving demand for new cars. Last month, overall U.S. auto sales reached an annualized pace of 16.98 million vehicles, the highest since July 2006, according to Autodata.
FleetCor Technologies (FLT) reports Thursday, and analysts predict a 25% increase in EPS to $1.25 on a 24% improvement in revenue to $273.7 million.

The Norcross, Ga.-based company has posted earnings growth of 20% or higher for more than two years by charging commercial vehicle fleets a monthly fee to use its fuel cards. It also charges a usage fee to gas stations that accept them.
FleetCor has expanded its system across 43 countries and 500,000 commercial clients.
Old Dominion Freight Lines (ODFL) is a less-than-truckload carrier, meaning it collects freight from various shippers and consolidates it on one trailer for transport.
The company reports Thursday, and Wall Street is looking for a 22% increase in EPS to 83 cents on a 17% rise in revenue to $691.8 million.
The trucking sector has gotten a boost from better pricing and increasing demand for intermodal truck service. A harsh winter also created pent-up demand that could be seen in Q2 results.

Stocks pared losses Friday after a harsh reminder that Ukraine, even when it goes to the back burner for a while, remains an area of concern for the market.
Two days after the Nasdaq flashed a sign of strength, stocks reversed early gains, but battled back to end mixed and mostly unchanged.

At the close, the Dow Jones industrial average lost 0.3%, weighed down by General Electric (GE) and Visa (V). The S&P 500 closed fractionally lower and the Nasdaq rallied 0.3%. Preliminary data showed NYSE and Nasdaq volume coming in higher than Thursday as options expired.
For the week, the Nasdaq rose 2.2%; the S&P 500 rallied 1.2% and the Dow gained 0.7%.

In the stock market today, Monster Beverage (MNST) vaulted 30% on news Coca-Cola (KO) is buying a 17% stake in the energy drink maker for $2.15 billion. Amid slumping soft-drink sales, Coke has been expanding its arsenal. It recently bought a stake in Keurig Green Mountain (GMCR) to market a Keurig cold-beverage maker. In May, Coke upped its stake in Keurig to 16%.

Elsewhere, Leaderboard nameFleetCor Technologies (FLT) added to recent gains, rising 1.5%. Earlier this week, the market cheered news it was acquiring e-payments firm Comdata for $3.45 billion. FleetCor is a provider of fuel cards and workforce payment products.

Sierra Wireless (SWIR) gained ground for the seventh time in eight sessions, rising 3%. It's been consolidating gains since January and is only 11% off its all-time high. Full-year earnings are seen rising 74% this year, with growth accelerating in 2015, up 110%.
Gilead Sciences (GILD) rose 3% on news it won a dispute with Roche (RHHBY) over rights to its blockbuster hepatitis C drug Sovaldi.
On the downside, Nordstrom (JWN) and Dillard's (DDS) led IBD's Retail-Department Stores group to a decline of nearly 5%.

Stocks opened lower Thursday and continued selling off throughout the session, with scores of leaders taking big hits as well, adding pressure to a market already under pressure.The Nasdaq slumped 2.1%. The S&P 500 and Dow industrials, meanwhile, both sank nearly 2%, plunging below their 50-day moving averages. Volume was sharply higher in the stock market today, according to preliminary data, indicating the big money was busy selling.Few groups were spared in the downdraft. Insurers, 3D printer makers and solar stocks were among the day's worst performers.Yum Brands (YUM) gapped down and fell 5% in busy turnover, nearing a six-month low. On Wednesday, the restaurant operator said in an SEC filing that a negative TV news report earlier this month of a Chinese meat supplier has caused "significant" and "negative" damage to sales at its restaurants in China. Analysts trimmed their 2014 and '15 earnings estimates as a result.On the upside, Tessera Technologies (TSRA) bucked the downtrend as it gapped up and soared 9% to a multiyear high in massive trade. Late Thursday, the fabless chipmaker said it entered new technology and patent license agreements with Micron Technology (MU).Among leading stocks, Arris Group (ARRS), FleetCor Technologies (FLT), GoPro (GPRO) and Tesla Motors (TSLA) all reported after the close.Argentina's debt default weighed on the market. Weekly jobless claims, however, offered some good news, falling a bit more than expected to 302,000.Economic data slated for Friday morning include the July jobs report, the University of Michigan's consumer sentiment survey and the latest reading from the ISM manufacturing index.Follow Nancy Gondo on Twitter: @IBD_NGondo.

The oil and gas production company had been down as low…
The L in IBD's CAN SLIM investing system stands for Leaders, as in the best growth stocks based on an analysis of fundamental, technical and institutional sponsorship criteria.
Stocks that meet the criteria of a leader — such as strong sales and profit growth and competition-beating products or services — have the best chance of racking up big gains.

Cisco Systems (CSCO), Dell, Google (GOOGL) and Apple (AAPL) were among past leaders that became big market winners. Cisco's hardware revolutionized computer networking; Dell beat rivals by selling built-to-order computers at low prices; and Apple dominated the consumer electronics industry with its fashionable and easy-to-use mobile devices.

A more recent example of a true Leader? FleetCor Technologies (FLT) commands the top shelf in the business of providing fuel cards to commercial vehicle fleets, trucking companies and other firms. The cards help companies track and control costs.

FleetCor was ranked No. 22 in the IBD 50 list of top stocks on Aug. 15, 2012 (1), when it cleared a 41.40 buy point of a first-stage cup base. At the time, the stock boasted a Composite Rating of 98, just shy of the best-possible 99. Its Earnings Per Share Rating was 97 and its Relative Price Strength Rating was 90.
FleetCor's breakout satisfied another key requirement of a leading stock: institutional support. Its Accumulation/Distribution Rating was A- at the time, indicating strong demand for the shares.

Crucially, volume was more than double the stock's daily average as FleetCor cleared the buy point, indicating that mutual funds and big sponsors were behind the stock's move up. Stocks that don't have the backing of deep-pocketed fund managers can't continue to rise for long.
At the time of its breakout, FleetCor was the leading stock in the Finance-Credit Card Payment Processor industry group, ahead of such stalwarts as Visa (V) and MasterCard (MA).

Its closest rival is Maine-based WEX (WEX), formerly called Wright Express. But FleetCor has become the biggest player in its niche thanks to its aggressive and well-executed expansion into Brazil, Britain, Australia and New Zealand. WEX's operations have focused mostly on the U.S.

FleetCor's expansion showed up in its earnings reports leading up to its breakout. Profit rose 28% in the second quarter of 2012, beating expectations, and the company raised its full-year profit outlook. Its annual pretax margin was 50% and return on equity was 25%, both representative of the best stocks.

Though the Finance-Credit Card Payment Processor industry group had fallen to No. 57 from No. 15 in just three weeks, that's still a decent rank. FleetCor still had the characteristics of a winner. The stock went on to triple in 16 months.The L in IBD's CAN SLIM investing system stands for Leaders, as in the best growth stocks based on an analysis of fundamental, technical and institutional sponsorship criteria.Stocks that meet the criteria of a leader — such as strong sales and profit growth and competition-beating products or services — have the best chance of racking up big gains.Cisco Systems (CSCO), Dell, Google (GOOGL) and Apple (AAPL) were among past leaders that became big market winners. No single stock screen will be the best in every uptrend. Different uptrends reward different kinds of stocks, and the screens reflect that reality. For example, during the last bear market, the aggressive and growthy complexion of the IBD 50 (then the IBD 100) faded.Stocks making the list on Oct. 27, 2008, included El Paso Electric (EE), Campbell Soup (CPB), Procter & Gamble (PG) and Johnson & Johnson (JNJ).The mention of those equities alone said, "It's a bear market."As of early November, the 85-85 screen has been the top-performing screen over the past six months. The 85-85 was up 6.1%, while the S&P 500 gained 1.1% and the IBD 50 1.5%.What can be made of this? There are two ways to use a screen — the micro approach and the macro approach.The micro approach studies the list to find stocks that might be near buy points and that have few misses by CAN SLIM standards .The macro approach looks for patterns in the list. What kind of stocks are making the list — small caps or big caps? Which sectors or industry groups are plentiful? Are the stocks making the screen aggressive or defensive?Let's contemplate two screens — the IBD 50 and the 85-85, also known as Your Weekly Review in Friday's newspaper.Generally, the IBD 50 is a collection of stocks that have higher ratings than those in the 85-85 screen. Because the IBD 50 has higher ratings, these stocks should do better in a long and strong uptrend.Quality growth stocks, though, will likely correct more sharply than defensive stocks when the market runs into trouble.What is the advantage of the 85-85 screen?The 85-85 will pick up more turnaround stocks than the IBD 50. (A turnaround stock is less likely to have strong annual ratings over the past three years.) The 85-85's looser standard means that it's also more likely to pick up stocks benefiting from sector rotation. It also will pick up more small and thinly traded stocks than the IBD 50.The sector rotation angle has been apparent recently. Small bank and S&L industry groups accounted for 40 of the stocks in the 85-85 at the end of October.Yet only two bank stocks made the IBD 50 — Bank of the Ozarks (OZRK) and Signature Bank (SBNY). Many of the 85-85 bank stocks are thinly traded. Some, though, still attract quality mutual fund holders, as the table shows.

A stock market under distribution suffered more of it Thursday. The S&P; 500 fell below its 50-day moving average in higher volume and the Dow Jones industrial average suffered its worst daily percentage decline since early February.Investors were rattled by news that Argentina defaulted on its debt for the second time in 13 years, and other economic worries.At the close, the Nasdaq lost 2.1%; the S&P; 500 gave up 2% and the Dow fell 1.9%. Sales rose 38% from a year ago to $245 million, also above forecasts.FleetCor was inactive after the provider of fuel cards and workforce payment products slightly beat on the bottom line with profit of $1.27 a share, up 28% from a year ago. Sales were mostly in-line with expectations at $273.5 million.In the stock market today, all 30 Dow components closed lower.Exxon Mobil (XOM) and Nike (NKE) led the way, falling 4% and 3%, respectively. Nike followed Adidas lower after the German company issued a profit warning. Earnings from Exxon Mobil, meanwhile, disappointed.On Friday, watch for earnings from Chevron (CVX), Procter & Gamble (PG), Burger King (BKW), Catamaran (CTRX) and Gentherm (THRM).Friday's jobs report will also get a lot of attention. July nonfarm payrolls are seen rising 233,000 with the unemployment rate holding steady at 6.1%.

The market completed a good week, and some of the Sector Leaders are showing interesting chart action, mostly good, but not always. FleetCor Technologies (FLT) gave investors a second chance to buy as it broke out of a cup-with-handle base. Its first breakout was May 27 . Shipments by Old Dominion Freight Lines and other North American truckers continued to climb in May, bucking weakness in the economy, a freight analyst said Thursday.
In fact, truck freight shipments in the first five months of the year were strongest since the end of the Great Recession, Cass Information Systems said in its May Freight Index Report.
The report could further boost shares of trucking companies, which are already in high gear.

Thomasville, North Carolina-based Old Dominion (ODFL), for example, carries a best-possible 99 IBD Composite Rating, meaning its stock has outperformed 99% of all stocks on key metrics such as sales and profit growth.

"While this (report) seems counter to the dismal GDP reading for the first quarter, which shows a 1% drop or a contraction in the economy," Cass Information Systems analyst Rosalyn Wilson said in the report, "much of the decrease in GDP can be attributed to declining inventories, slowing exports and weather-related issues."
Wilson, who is also senior business analyst with infrastructure firm Delcan, said that those factors are positives for the economy going forward as inventories recover and weather improves.
Trucking shipment volume rose 3.6% year to year in May and 1% from the prior month. Total expenditures on trucking climbed 11.2% for the year to a record high, and 1.1% from April.

Cass doesn't publish dollar figures but said the amount that companies spent on trucking shipments was 77.7% higher than at the recession's end in 2009. Its index measures trends in North American truck shipping based on $23 billion annually in paid freight expenses for its customer base of hundreds of large shippers.
As shipments rise, Cass said, trucking supply is tightening, which is likely to lead to trucking companies charging higher rates, which the trucking industry would welcome.
Trucking companies have added new equipment and drivers to meet growing demand, which has driven up their costs, Wilson noted.
Shares of Old Dominion, a company on the IBD 50 list of top-rated stocks, rose 1.3% in afternoon trading in the stock market today, Thursday.
Among other highly rated truckers, Saia (SAIA), which boasts a 96 Composite Rating, was up more than 2%.

J.B. Hunt Transportation Services (JBHT), with a market capitalization of $9 billion that makes it the largest in the 20-company IBD Transport-Truck group, edged up fractionally. The group as a whole is ranked a powerful 12 on IBD's list of 197 industries.
Swift Transportation (SWFT), No. 3 U.S. trucker behind Hunt and Old Dominion, jumped 3.5% by late afternoon Thursday.

Fleetcor Technologies (FLT), a provider of fuel cards that help trucking companies track costs and whose stock is on the IBD Leaderboard list of stocks outperforming the market, rose less than 1% Thursday.

Stocks turned in a reasonable performance Tuesday, ending moderately lower in an uneventful session.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.2%. The Nasdaq and S&P 500 eased 0.1% each. Preliminary data showed NYSE and Nasdaq volume coming in very close to Monday's levels.
Stocks performed pretty well, considering the latest reading on consumer confidence from the Conference Board came in below expectations at 78.1. Economists expected a smaller drop to 80.1.

In the stock market today, RetailMeNot (SALE) was one of the best percentage gainers in the IBD 50, rising 5%. It's also a Leaderboard stock. The company operates a digital coupon marketplace. It's held up well in light of weak earnings from Groupon (GRPN) last week.

Also in the IBD 50, FleetCor Technologies (FLT) stayed in rally mode as shares rose another 2%. The stock looked like it was ready to roll over in January, but a strong earnings report earlier this month fixed that. The stock has rallied 25% since hitting a low of 101.48 in late January. It recently cleared resistance at 120 and still could be in the early stages of a breakout.

Meanwhile, Tesla Motors (TSLA) soared 14% after Morgan Stanley raised its price target to 320 from 153, citing optimism about the company's proposed gigafactory — a battery research and production venture.

Recent new issue FireEye (FEYE) jumped 5% to an all-time high. Optimism abounds for the company's next-generation network security software. It's not profitable yet, but the company shows big sales growth in recent quarters. Morgan Stanley brought the company public in September at 20. It's quadrupled in price since then.

Coming up Wednesday, a slew of retailers will be out with earnings before the open, including Target (TGT), Lowe's (LOW), Abercrombie & Fitch (ANF) and TJX Companies (TJX). The C in CAN SLIM — for current quarterly earnings — is crucial to successful investing. Without such growth, your stock is just one in a mediocre pack. Happily, IBD can help you spot the companies putting up the fattest quarterly earnings gains.Is the quarterly earnings gauge the most important of all CAN SLIM ingredients? No. There are only crucial parts to a whole.Quarterly earnings growth shows you the health of a company's short-term profitability.In the best-selling book "How To Make Money In Stocks," IBD founder and Chairman William O'Neil advises to seek out only those companies that have posted EPS and sales gains of at least 25% in the latest quarter.Please don't feel limited by 25%. As Mae West once said, "Too much of a good thing ... can be wonderful." If you don't need 50 stocks in your portfolio, you may want to set your growth bar ridiculously high.Are there companies growing their bottom lines by triple digits? Sure. The stocks of these companies may not be the best candidates — remember, the C is just one ingredient in a larger recipe — but such stocks may be a great place to start your search.So, how do you find such stocks?• Flip through Sector Leaders.They are the highlighted companies at the top of each sector in IBD's stock tables. The Financial sector has two leaders. Financial Engines (FNGN) reported 62% higher earnings on 36% higher revenue in Q3. FleetCor Technologies (FLT) upped those gauges 46% and 45%, respectively. That's why they're sector leaders.• Check out Stock Spotlight.This features a different company or two every day. Next to the feature article you'll find 16 charts — each of a company with standout fundamentals.Each chart also includes lots of info, including the most recent quarterly EPS and sales gains. These companies are almost certainly growing their business by far more than 25%.• Scan the market updates.Found on IBD's sister website Investors.com, they tend to showcase mostly high-growth stocks and members of the IBD 50, although turnarounds sneak in.Screen of the Day on Investors.com may help, too. You may also consider subscribing to MarketSmith, IBD's affiliate service. Here, you can build your own criteria for a tailor-made screen that includes EPS and sales growth.

The economy created a better-than-expected 175,000 jobs in May and that was enough to bring in buyers from the sidelines Friday. The percentage gains were impressive as major averages all rose more than 1%, but volume wasn't, as NYSE and Nasdaq volume came in lower than Thursday. Some sector leaders outperformed — not surprising on a nice up day for…
The Nasdaq and S&P 500 may have avoided another distribution day Tuesday but both indexes finished in the bottom half of their trading ranges and leading stocks took hits again.
The breakout of FleetCor Technologies (FLT) from a follow-on, four-weeks-tight pattern hasn't made much headway. Shares fell 0.81, or 1%, to 85.33. It's now slightly below a buy point of 85.66.
The company is a provider of fuel cards and workforce payment products to businesses.

Keep in mind that the best time to buy a growth stock is when it's breaking out of an early-stage base in the beginning stages of a new market uptrend. FleetCor isn't exactly in the early stages of a run at this point. Tight trading after a breakout can offer alternate entry points, but base breakouts are the best time to buy.
Priceline.com (PCLN) continues to hold near highs after a recent technical breakout. But the breakout was from a fourth-stage base, meaning it was a late-stage breakout, not an early-stage one.

To its credit, Priceline's weekly chart shows some tight closes which means another breakout isn't out of the question. The problem is the broad market, which isn't all that healthy at the moment. Shares of Priceline lost 3.93, or 0.5% to 798.69 in quiet trade.

Michael Kors (KORS) lost ground for the third straight session, falling 0.67, or 1%, to 61.57 in slow trade. Breakouts have a hard time making headway when distribution is making its presence felt in the market, and that's certainly been the case with Kors.

Shares jumped 3% in strong volume May 29 as investors cheered a strong earnings report, but the enthusiasm was short-lived. Stocks added to early gains, although volume quieted near midday Thursday.

The Nasdaq kept its lead, up 0.9%. The S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average each climbed 0.6%. Volume slipped from early levels and turned mixed, up 1% on the Nasdaq and a fraction lower on the NYSE, vs. trade at the same time Wednesday.

The stock market today opened to positive economic news: a decrease in weekly jobless claims and inflation numbers in line with forecasts. Philadelphia region manufacturing slowed much more than expected, but investors seemed more keen on individual company reports and on technical factors.

In addition, the Senate Banking Committee cleared Janet Yellen's nomination to the chairman's post at the Federal Reserve. The approval clears the way for a final confirmation vote before the full Senate. Yellen has generally been viewed as a positive for the market, suggesting only gradual change in the Fed's accommodative monetary policy.

Green Mountain Coffee Roasters (GMCR) knocked the cover off the ball, up 18% in massive trade after a strong fiscal fourth quarter. The gain yanked shares back above the stock's converged 10- and 40-week moving averages, pushing toward a second weekly advance off the bottom of a three-month, 37% correction.
Leading stocks continued to build on their broad, early advance.
Nu Skin Enterprises (NUS) defended its 6% gain, edging to a new high in very strong trade.
Ambarella (AMBA) climbed 5% in mild trade. The maker of chips used largely in sports and security cameras is hanging just below Monday's high, in its second rebound from 10-week support.

Yandex (YNDX) popped 4% in strong trade, chinning up to its 50-day moving average. The Netherlands-based provider of search engine services to Russia's Internet is five weeks into a flat consolidation with 10-week support.

Stocks rose Friday after the European Central Bank hinted at new stimulus measures to boost inflation. But the major averages ended off intraday highs.

The Nasdaq rose 0.6%, the Dow Jones industrial average gained 0.5%, and the S&P 500 was up 0.4%. Volume was mixed in the stock market today, rising 16% on the NYSE and falling 4% on the Nasdaq compared to Thursday, according to preliminary figures.
European Central Bank head Mario Draghi suggested that the ECB will introduce new stimulus measures at its Dec. 3 meeting.
Retailers, medical and apparel stocks led the upside, while data storage, energy and steel stocks underperformed.

Nike (NKE) led the Dow and the IBD 50, jumping 5% in heavy volume after announcing a 2-for-1 stock split, share buyback and a dividend increase late Thursday. The stock is well extended past a 117.82 buy point but has found support at the 50-day moving average.

Alaska Air (ALK) was also among the best-performing IBD 50 stocks. The regional airline climbed nearly 3%, in line with oil's plunge below $40 a barrel, as it nears an 82.88 buy point of a flat base. Hawaiian Holdings (HA) also rose nearly 3%. The carrier is just 1% off an all-time high and well out of buying range.

The regional airline climbed nearly 3%, in line with oil's plunge below $40 a barrel, as it nears an 82.88 buy point of a flat base. Hawaiian Holdings (HA) also rose nearly 3%. The carrier is just 1% off an all-time high and well out of buying range.On the downside, Mentor Graphics (MENT) plunged 35% to a 52-week low after Mentor, a developer of software used to test electronic systems, issued a disappointing quarterly earnings report.

With the stock market back in a confirmed uptrend, investors may want to look for big-cap companies with high Accumulation/Distributions grades that point to large institutions buying their stocks. Alexion Pharmaceuticals (ALXN), Illumina (ILMN), Micron (MU) and FleetCor Technologies (FLT) are all companies on the IBD's Big Cap Screen of the Day that have an Accumulation/Distribution grade of A- or…

Stocks trudged higher Thursday amid seemingly constant chatter from the bears that economic data and market internals don't support an upside move. The Nasdaq outperformed, rising 0.6%; the S&P 500 gained 0.2% and the Dow Jones industrial average added 0.1%. NYSE volume eased from Wednesday's level. Nasdaq volume rose 7%. The Nasdaq closed above its 50-day moving average for the…

Stock futures stepped off firm gains ahead of Thursday's open as the market looked to wrap up its holiday-shortened week.Dow futures were 60.1 points above fair market value. Nasdaq 100 futures jumped 18.8 points. S&P 500 futures were ahead 8.8 points and rising. Small caps had also improved, with Russell 2000 futures turning early losses into a 1.3-point gain.The payroll report is the top piece of U.S. economic news for the stock market today, but eyes remain sharply focused on Greece, where a referendum vote on Sunday could determine whether the country will remain part of or exit the eurozone. Greece's prime minister and finance minister have made clear they are firmly in favor of a "no" vote, which would refuse the so-called austerity measures demanded by eurozone creditors in exchange for continued bailout support. Europe's top stock indexes in Frankfurt and Paris were effectively flat near midsession, while London's FTSE 100 edged up 0.4%.U.S. nonfarm payrolls expanded by 223,000 in May, the Labor Department reported. That was a sharp downtick from April's downwardly revised total of 254,000 new jobs, and below expectations for 230,000 new hires. Private employers accounted for all the additions, with the labor force participation rate down 30 basis points to 62.6% and the unemployment rate dipping to 5.3%, from 5.5% in April and below forecasts for 5.4%. Average hourly earnings were flat, below expectations for a 0.2% gain.Initial jobless claims rose to 281,000 for the week ended June 27, a 3.6% increase over the prior week. Consensus forecasts called for a slight decrease to 270,000. The four-week moving average increased to 272,750, its first increase in three weeks.May factory orders data are due from the Commerce Department at 10 a.m. ET.Early stock action showed online international money transfer service Xoom (XOOM) vaulting 23% in premarket trade. EBay (EBAY) subsidiary PayPal announced after Wednesday's close it would acquire the San Francisco-based startup for approximately $890 million. EBay announced last week it would complete its spinoff of PayPal as a separately traded entity on July 17. EBay shares rose 1%.Tesla Motors (TSLA) jumped 4% ahead of the open. The Palo Alto, Calif.-based car and battery maker reported its sales of Model S sedans rose 52% in the second quarter vs. the year-ago period. The result topped the company's own best-case estimate of 11,000 vehicles by about 500 units. Tesla shares ended Wednesday up 48% from a March low, in a possible nine-month cup base.IBD 50 stock Centene (CNC) rose 2% after agreeing to buy Health Net (HNT) in a cash and stock transaction valued at $6.8 billion. Centene said the deal included $500 million in debt and would boost the company's earnings by 20% in the first year. Centene is extended, recovered to new highs after a high-volume stab through its 10-week line flashed a sell signal in April. Health Net shares spiked 15% before Thursday's open.Overseas, China's mainland markets took another steep step down. The Shanghai Composite shed 3.5% Friday for a 6.6% loss for the week. Hong Kong's Hang Seng edged up 0.1%, down 1.4% for the week. In Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 gained 1% and took a weekly loss of 0.1% through Thursday.The dollar was mixed, down vs. the euro, up against the yen. In commodities, oil rose a fraction, with U.S. West Texas Intermediate just above $57 a barrel and down almost 5% vs. last Friday's settle price. Gold dipped to near $1,161 an ounce Friday, down a bit more than 1% for the week. Wheat, which has had a volatile week, was slightly higher and trading up nearly 4% for the week at $5.84 a bushel.

Every great trade begins with a great idea. While there's a wealth of places in IBD to get great ideas for your watch list, one feature that investors must check out is Sector Leaders.Published today on Page B1, the Sector Leaders are the top-rated stocks that meet IBD's most stringent fundamental and technical criteria. These stocks are also the cream of the crop in their respective sectors.Over the past year through March 6, Sector Leaders shot up 94.2% on a price-weighted basis, far outpacing a 21.6% gain for the S&P 500. Year-to-date through Monday's close, Sector Leaders are already up 16.2% vs. a 3.8% advance for the Nasdaq and 1.6% for the S&P 500.With the major redesign of the stock tables back in 2008, IBD made it much faster and easier to find the best stocks from each sector. Sector Leaders are boxed at the very top of each sector heading for easy reference. In Feb. 27's IBD, BitAuto (BITA), Facebook (FB) and Qihoo 360 Technology (QIHU) were the three Sector Leaders in the Internet sector, which was ranked No. 2.Note that not all of the 33 sectors in IBD will have Sector Leaders. To make it even easier, investors don't have to flip through all of the stock tables to look for the Sector Leaders. Charts of all of the Sector Leaders usually appear on Page B1 Tuesday through Friday. The Sector Leaders charts are elsewhere in Monday's edition.Stocks that make the Sector Leaders list can make for excellent watch-list candidates. Even if they already have broken out, investors should still pay attention and see if they're still in buying range or have crafted a secondary entry point.While the Sector Leaders can make for trade candidates, they can also help you gauge the overall condition of leading stocks. If Sector Leaders are breaking down even as the market is in confirmed uptrend, then that's not a good sign for investors.On the flip side, if Sector Leaders start rising in a down market, that gives you a clue to possible improving conditions ahead.Drugmaker Actavis (ACT) was featured in the July 26 Sector Leaders charts as it formed an eight-week flat base with a 133.10 buy point 1. The stock broke out that same day and has rallied 73% 2 to as high as 230.77.Other recent winners that appeared in Sector Leaders on July 26 were Jazz Pharmaceuticals (JAZZ), Michael Kors (KORS), Priceline.com (PCLN) and FleetCor Technologies (FLT).

Stocks took back some ground Thursday, although few top-rated stocks showed much vigor. The S&P 500 rose 0.8%, while the Nasdaq added 0.7%. Volume slipped across the board. After four consecutive losses of 1% or more, the IBD 50 posted a 2.4% gain. Dig deeper, though, and the gain didn't look too impressive. Six stocks in the IBD 50 rose…

Futures pointed lower, under pressure from global markets, but were trimming losses ahead of Wednesday's open. Dow futures were 79 points lower after slipping nearly 100 points in earlier trade. S&P 500 futures were down 9.25 points and Nasdaq 100 futures declined 13.5 points, both were off early lows. Economic and earnings calendars are both light on the stock market…
Stocks ended modestly higher Wednesday, with the S&P 500 hitting another all-time high, amid data suggesting that the U.S. economy was picking up.

The S&P 500 rose 0.3% while the Dow Jones industrial average and the Nasdaq each rose 0.2%. Volume was mixed, with NYSE volume tracking 6% lower than Tuesday and Nasdaq volume rising 6%, according to preliminary data.

Private employers added 191,000 jobs in March, according to ADP, pretty much in line with the consensus estimate of 193,000. Figures from the prior month were revised sharply higher. The data came ahead of Friday's jobs report. Nonfarm payrolls are expected to increase by 206,000, with the unemployment rate ticking lower to 6.6%.
Orders for manufactured goods rose a better-than-expected 1.6% in February, the biggest increase in five months.

In the stock market today, office supply retailer Staples (SPLS) led the S&P 500 in terms of percentage gain, jumping 5% in heavy volume. However, the stock remains depressed well below its key support lines and 30% below its 52-week high.

Meanwhile, Intuitive Surgical (ISRG) continued to rebound sharply after announcing Tuesday that the Food and Drug Administration had approved its next-generation da Vinci robotic surgical system. The stock jumped 5% to a 52-week high in more than double its average daily volume. It's up 20% for the week.

On the downside, Apollo Education (APOL) slumped 9%, slicing through its 50-day moving average, after the operator of the for-profit University of Phoenix reported that revenue for the latest quarter fell a greater-than-expected 19%.

The company also said it had received a subpoena from the Education Department seeking information about the University of Phoenix's operations in the Northeast.Stocks ended modestly higher Wednesday, with the S&P 500 hitting another all-time high, amid data suggesting that the U.S. economy was picking up.The S&P 500 rose 0.3% while the Dow Jones industrial average and the Nasdaq each rose 0.2%. Stocks were hitting session highs late Thursday, recouping a big chunk of the previous day's losses, amid mixed earnings reports and economic data.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.7%, the Nasdaq rallied 0.6% and the S&P 500 added 0.3%. Volume was tracking higher on the Nasdaq and lower on the NYSE compared to the same time Wednesday.

In the stock market today, NQ Mobile (NQ) plunged as much as 55% in massive volume after short seller Muddy Waters Research Group slapped a "strong sell" rating on the stock, calling the Chinese developer of mobile security software a "massive fraud."
Muddy Waters accused the company of falsifying financial information and vastly overstating its market share in China.
Meanwhile, gunmaker Sturm Ruger (RGR) dropped 5% in volume that was running more than double its daily average.
The stock had recently risen 20% above a 56.98 buy point, a level at which investors should consider taking profits. It's now 13% above the buy point.

Generac Holdings (GNRC) was the biggest gainer among IBD 50 stocks. The maker of portable generators gapped up and bolted 15% after reporting Q3 results that blew away views. The company also raised its full-year sales outlook due to strong demand for its residential generators and impact from its Baldor Generators buyout. Generac cleared a 44.34 buy point from a late-stage double-bottom base.

Elsewhere, Medidata Solutions (MDSO) soared 16% to a new high after the provider of clinical development software reported that Q3 profit jumped 67% from a year earlier, beating Wall Street expectations. Sales for the period rose 27%.

The stock is extended 22% above a 97.48 flat-base entry.Stocks were hitting session highs late Thursday, recouping a big chunk of the previous day's losses, amid mixed earnings reports and economic data.The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.7%, the Nasdaq rallied 0.6% and the S&P 500 added 0.3%. Stocks traded quietly — mixed and mostly unchanged — just past the midway point of Friday's session.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.5%, with Exxon Mobil (XOM), UnitedHealth (UNH) and Procter & Gamble (PG) leading the charge. The S&P 500 added 0.3% while the Nasdaq eased 0.1%.
NYSE volume was tracking close to Thursday's level. Nasdaq volume fell 15% from Thursday's pace.

In the stock market today, small-cap William Lyon Homes (WLH) soared 5% after the company trounced earnings and sales expectations before the open. Group peer and Leaderboard name Toll Bros. (TOL) added 1% as it flirted with a breakout from a long cup-with-handle base.

Meanwhile, micro-cap Fonar (FONR), a top-rated name in IBD's Medical-Systems/Equipment industry group, soared 24% on strong earnings. Profit rose 57% from a year ago to 33 cents a share. Sales growth accelerated for the fourth straight quarter, rising 83% to $17.6 million. It's not an institutional-quality stock yet, but the company's MRI technology is a potential game-changer.

FleetCor Technologies (FLT) continued work on the right side of a possible base. Shares rose just under 1%. Not that long ago, it looked like the stock was in trouble but a strong earnings report on Feb. 5 changed that. FleetCor is back above its 10-week moving average, 5% off its high.

Meanwhile, IBD 50 component Globus Medical (GMED) added nearly 1%. It was a mixed day for the stock market Friday, and Sector Leaders stocks were also mixed. Spirit Airlines (SAVE) rose 1.93 to 47.58. It appears to have completed its first successful test of its 50-day moving average since breaking out of a late-stage base Oct. 11. It is trading near an all-time high. Late-stage bases have a higher failure…
When an investor is trying to identify a potential winning stock, recent earnings growth matters.
A paragraph from IBD founder and Chairman William J. O'Neil's "How to Make Money in Stocks" shows why.

"In our models of the 600 best-performing stocks from 1952 to 2001, three out of four showed earnings increases averaging more than 70% in the latest publicly reported quarter before they began their major advances. Those that did not show solid current quarterly earnings increases did so in the very next quarter, with an average earnings increase of 90%!"
This is why current earnings growth represents the C in CAN SLIM.
A common misconception is that when an investor sees fast recent growth, it is too late to buy. A too-late condition has more to do with late-stage bases than with fast earnings growth.
Let's look at some 2013 winners and their breakouts. What kind of an EPS pop did they show in the most recently reported quarter when they broke out in fast trade?

Celgene (CELG) cleared a 81.34 buy point twice. The initial breakout was Dec. 11, 2012, but the stock then retreated 5%. Celgene retook the buy point Jan. 7, 2013. Earnings growth in Q3 was 26% — the seventh consecutive quarter of EPS growth above 25%. From the ideal entry, the stock rose as much as 114% in 2013.
LinkedIn (LNKD) popped above a 117.42 buy point Jan. 10. Earnings growth in Q3, the most recently reported quarter, was 267%. From the ideal entry, the stock rose as much as 119% in 2013.
Lumber Liquidators (LL) broke past a 57.34 handle Jan. 24. Earnings grew 77% in the quarter reported before the breakout. Lumber rose 109% in 10 months.
FleetCor Technologies (FLT) hurried past a 73 buy point in a three-weeks-tight pattern March 22. Earnings grew 46% in the then-recent quarter. The stock marched 70% in about nine months.

Netflix (NFLX) brushed past a 248.95 entry July 12. At that time, most recent earnings growth was 31 cents a share vs. a loss of 8 cents a share in the year-ago period. The stock advanced 56% in three months.

Others, such as Facebook (FB) and Las Vegas Sands (LVS), had earnings growth of 58% and 48%, respectively, in the then-recent quarter.When an investor is trying to identify a potential winning stock, recent earnings growth matters.A paragraph from IBD founder and Chairman William J.
