Stocks continued to trade in split fashion Wednesday afternoon amid a round of mixed earnings reports.

The Nasdaq rose 0.4% to a fresh 13-year high, while the S&P 500 edged up 0.1%. But the Dow Jones industrial average lost 0.3%, as IBM (IBM) slumped 3%. Big blue reported mixed quarterly results late Tuesday. Volume was tracking lower across the stock market today.

Gentherm (THRM) extended its winning ways, adding 3% to a multiyear high in fast trade. The lift puts it 9% past a 25.19 early buy point from a flat base. Gentherm, which makes heated car seats, has delivered four straight quarters of accelerating sales growth.

Michael Kors (KORS) rose 3% and neared resistance at its 50-day line and the 80 price level. It appears to be benefiting at rival Coach's (COH) expense. Coach reported disappointing quarterly results. Coach slumped 7%.

FleetCor Technologies (FLT) rose 3% as it bounced back from a six-session slide. Despite this, FleetCor is still about 13% off its Dec. 2 record high. The stock, which has been in a sharp uptrend since 2012, has come under heavy selling pressure in recent weeks. FleetCor was quoted above 80 a share in after-hours trade, which would give the stock a new high. The company reported a 50% rise in earnings to 90 cents a share, and a 32% rise…

Stocks finished Wednesday with mild gains in volume lower than the previous day, according to preliminary data. The Nasdaq rose 0.1%, while the S&P; 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average climbed 0.2% in the stock market today. Bond yields, which had been rising sharply in recent days in anticipation of the Federal Reserve raising interest rates, fell sharply.

Casino operator Isle of Capri (ISLE) rose for the seventh straight day and was up 6.5%. It reported earnings Tuesday, the same day it was discussed in the IBD Stock Spotlight column. It's up 33% for the week as it emerged from a flat base with a 15.49 buy point. Stocks that rise more than 20% within the first three weeks of a breakout should be held at least eight weeks.

Among IBD 50 stocks 26 were higher and 24 were lower. The worst performer was French ad agency Criteo (CRTO), down 7%. It finished in about the middle of its daily range at about a 46.60 buy point from a cup base. There were reports Apple (AAPL) will let iPhone users block online ads with Safari.
Krispy Kreme Doughnuts (KKD) rose 14% after gapping up after an upbeat earnings report. The stock has been an underperformer for the past couple of years.

Men's Wearhouse (MW) beat estimates on its earnings report after the close Wednesday and rose 6% in heavy volume.Stocks finished Wednesday with mild gains in volume lower than the previous day, according to preliminary data. Futures soared, pointing to a sharply higher open Friday, after the Labor Department painted an improving jobs picture for April.
Dow futures were up 100 points and rising. Nasdaq 100 futures jumped 21 points and S&P 500 futures popped 11 points.

The premarket posture bodes well for the stock market today, which will be focused on whether the S&P 500 can overtake resistance near 1600. The Nasdaq heads into Friday up 1.9% so far for the week and at its highest level since November 2000. The S&P 500 is up almost 1%, but just a fraction into new high territory and stifled below 1600. Leaders have so far posted a healthy week, with the IBD 50 index up 2.4% through Thursday.

Nonfarm payrolls jumped by 168,000 in April, the Labor Department reported, up 20% from March's sharply upwardly revised 138,000 increase. Analysts had forecast an increase of 153,000. Private payrolls accounted for the bulk of the gain, up 176,000 — 85% above March's pace and in line with analyst forecasts.
The gain whittled the unemployment rate to 7.5% vs. 7.6% for March. Analysts had projected no change.
Leading stocks were among the most active ahead of Friday's open.

IBD 50 stock Regeneron Pharmaceuticals (REGN) was ahead 4% in premarket action. The Tarrytown, N.Y.-based biotech reported 89% sales growth and a triple-digit earnings gain, both far above analyst forecasts. Sales of the ocular disease treatment Eylea drove a large share of the beat, rising 153% during the quarter, and management raised its full-year sales expectations for the drug.
The stock was up 15% for the week at the end of the day Thursday, boosted by trial delays announced by rival Allergan (AGN) on Wednesday.

Fleetcor Technologies (FLT), also an IBD 50 stock, climbed 7% ahead of the bell. The provider of fuel credit systems for vehicle fleets reported a 50% jump in earnings and a 32% sales gain in the first quarter, both better then analyst consensus views.
The stock stuck close to its 50-day line this week, in its third test of support since an August breakout and just below an April 11 high.

On the injured list, LinkedIn (LNKD) remained down 10% ahead of the open, after reporting first quarter results late Thursday. The career networking site reported better-than-expected sales and earnings growth. But management's second quarter revenue and net income guidance were below expectations, the company's first forecast below consensus views.
The almost two-year-old stock ended Thursday up more than 7% for the week, at new highs and extended after a rebound from 10-week support.

Overseas, Asia's markets capped a mixed session with the Shanghai Composite up 1.4% and Tokyo's Nikkei 225 off 0.7%, while Hong Kong's Hang Seng index inched up 0.1%. For the week, the Shanghai Composite climbed 1.2% and the Nikkei 225 dived 1.4%, with the Hang Seng ending ahead less than 1%.

Europe's markets also climbed sharply after the U.S. jobs report. Its major indexes were tracking toward mixed gains for the week, led by the CAC-40, which was up 2.1% for the week through mid-session Friday.

Commodities were generally higher and headed toward mostly modest gains for the week. Oil, gold, silver and copper were all trading 1.5% above last Friday's close. Corn was up 3%. Natural gas had slipped3.6% so far for the week.

Later this morning, factor orders data for March are expected from the Census Bureau at 10 a.m. ET, as is the Institute for Supply Management's service sector index for April.Futures soared, pointing to a sharply higher open Friday, after the Labor Department painted an improving jobs picture for April.Dow futures were up 100 points and rising. Nasdaq 100 futures jumped 21 points and S&P 500 futures popped 11 points.The premarket posture bodes well for the stock market today, which will be focused on whether the S&P 500 can overtake resistance near 1600. The Nasdaq heads into Friday up 1.9% so far for the week and at its highest level since November 2000. The S&P 500 is up almost 1%, but just a fraction into new high territory and stifled below 1600. Leaders have so far posted a healthy week, with the IBD 50 index up 2.4% through Thursday.Nonfarm payrolls jumped by 168,000 in April, the Labor Department reported, up 20% from March's sharply upwardly revised 138,000 increase. Analysts had forecast an increase of 153,000. Private payrolls accounted for the bulk of the gain, up 176,000 — 85% above March's pace and in line with analyst forecasts.The gain whittled the unemployment rate to 7.5% vs. 7.6% for March. Analysts had projected no change.Leading stocks were among the most active ahead of Friday's open.IBD 50 stock Regeneron Pharmaceuticals (REGN) was ahead 4% in premarket action. The Tarrytown, N.Y.-based biotech reported 89% sales growth and a triple-digit earnings gain, both far above analyst forecasts. Sales of the ocular disease treatment Eylea drove a large share of the beat, rising 153% during the quarter, and management raised its full-year sales expectations for the drug.The stock was up 15% for the week at the end of the day Thursday, boosted by trial delays announced by rival Allergan (AGN) on Wednesday.Fleetcor Technologies (FLT), also an IBD 50 stock, climbed 7% ahead of the bell. The provider of fuel credit systems for vehicle fleets reported a 50% jump in earnings and a 32% sales gain in the first quarter, both better then analyst consensus views.The stock stuck close to its 50-day line this week, in its third test of support since an August breakout and just below an April 11 high.On the injured list, LinkedIn (LNKD) remained down 10% ahead of the open, after reporting first quarter results late Thursday. The career networking site reported better-than-expected sales and earnings growth. But management's second quarter revenue and net income guidance were below expectations, the company's first forecast below consensus views.The almost two-year-old stock ended Thursday up more than 7% for the week, at new highs and extended after a rebound from 10-week support.Overseas, Asia's markets capped a mixed session with the Shanghai Composite up 1.4% and Tokyo's Nikkei 225 off 0.7%, while Hong Kong's Hang Seng index inched up 0.1%. Some market uptrends come with drawbacks. The lack of quality breakouts from bases is one drawback for this uptrend. The slow start, however, could change quickly. A second negative is best illustrated by Big 5 Sporting (BGFV). The stock is consolidating in a constructive and orderly fashion. Yet, if the small cap should sketch a base, it would be third…

Fuel-card issuer FleetCor Technologies  (FLT) late Thursday reported accelerating earnings growth on overseas acquisitions and sharply higher revenue per fill-up. The fuel card provider also raised 2013 guidance over forecasts based on its new Australia and New Zealand acquisitions. Shares rose 9% after hours, following a regular-session gain of 3% to 77.20, a new high. FleetCor's adjusted first-quarter earnings…

FleetCor Technologies (FLT) emerged as one of this year's biggest winners. This is the story of how that occurred.The issuer of fuel cards to trucking companies and other commercial-vehicle fleets has more than doubled in 2013, far outpacing the S&P 500's rise for the year.As with other market winners, FleetCor's success began with great fundamentals. Profit growth has been robust and steady, ranging from 30% to 50% over the past seven quarters.Revenue growth has been similarly impressive.Pretax profit margin topped 50% the past two years.FleetCor issues fuel cards that allow commercial fleet companies to track spending and cut costs while also reducing fraudulent fuel charges. Its growth has been fueled by acquisitions and expansion into Brazil and other countries.Also, like fellow credit card stocks MasterCard (MA) and Visa (V), FleetCor is benefiting from a global shift away from cash to credit and debit cards. All three stocks are leaders in IBD's Finance-Credit Card/Payment Processor industry group, which has been highly ranked for much of the year.FleetCor's outstanding 2013 run actually began in 2012. The stock cleared the 41.40 buy point in a cup-without-handle base Aug. 15 in heavy volume.The stock started this year seeming to be overheating when it surged 10% the week of Feb. 8.Yet, FleetCor continued its advance. The stock formed a three-weeks-tight pattern, which it cleared on March 22 in huge volume (1). Its Earnings Per Share Rating was a best-possible 99 at the time, and its Accumulation/Distribution Rating was A-.On July 28, FleetCor cleared an 89.85 buy point in a flat base (2). Then, about a month later, it climbed above a 100.97 three-weeks-tight entry (3).In early October it briefly erased its gain from the 100.97 entry, piercing its 50-day line in heavy volume. Investors who had big profits on the stock could have taken that as a cue to sell. But the stock soon recovered and was again hitting new highs.That hiccup was about the only difficult period for FleetCor in 2013, making it not just one of the year's winners but also one of the easiest leading stocks to own.Currently, FleetCor is forming an irregular ascending base. The ascending base would be, however, a riskier third-stage base.

Resilience was the operative word Monday as major averages ended with small gains after a weak open. Stocks were spooked early as weak manufacturing data in China and clashes in Ukraine weighed. The Nasdaq fell 0.9% early but started rallying back in the first hour of trading. It ended with a gain of 0.3%. The S&P 500 rallied 0.2%. Volume…
Stocks were still mixed in late trading Thursday but have worsened.

The Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.2% and the S&P 500 lost a fraction. Meanwhile, the Nasdaq was up 0.3%. It has given up more than half of its intraday gain. Turnover was again tracking higher on both major exchanges in the stock market today.

Kirby (KEX) pared gains but was still up 7%. Earlier, the stock hit a record high and cleared a 107.03 buy point from a flat base. Late Wednesday, the transporter of petroleum products beat expectations with Q1 earnings that grew 21% to $1.15 a share. That marked a second straight period of acceleration. Sales, which also beat expectations, rose 5% to $589.3 million. The company guided Q2 profit above views.
YY (YY) rallied 6%, regaining all of Wednesday's loss and then some. The stock has slumped 39% since early March but has found support at its 200-day moving average for the past couple of sessions.

Manitowoc (MTW) trimmed a 5% gain to less than 2% ahead of its earnings, to be reported after the close. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters see the crane-maker's profit falling to 20 cents a share from 33 cents in the year-ago period. Earlier, the stock cleared a 32.90 buy point from a flat base and touched its best levels since June 2008.

KapStone Paper and Packaging (KS) was off its session low but still down 3% following late Wednesday's disappointing Q1 results. The company posted a profit of 36 cents a share, up 71% from a year ago. But that was 6 cents below views. Revenue jumped 72% to $549 million, below views for $554.13 million. In recent sessions, KapStone has found support near 25.

Stocks pared gains at midday Wednesday amid expectations the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates later in the day. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq were each up 0.2% while the Dow Jones industrial average edged up 0.1%.
Volume on the Nasdaq and the NYSE were tracking below Tuesday's levels.
Fed policymakers are expected to raise interest rates by 25 basis points, marking the first increase since the central bank dropped rates to near zero in 2008 amid the financial crisis.
In the stock market today, drugmaker Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) jumped 7% in heavy volume despite issuing a weaker-than-expected 2016 earnings forecast.

The stock jumped 16% Tuesday after announcing a distribution agreement with Walgreens Boots Alliance (WBA), which the Canada-based drugmaker said would help rebuild its business after it cut ties with Philidor Rx Services amid allegations of wrongdoing. However, Valeant's forecast for a 30% jump in 2016 profit fell short of analysts' expectations.
Solar stocks were among the day's best performers, led by First Solar (FSLR), which jumped 8% to a new high in heavy volume.

Makers of solar panels and components have gotten a lift after negotiators from the U.S. and nearly 200 other countries reached a deal last weekend to cut greenhouse gas emissions. The agreement could lead to greater investment in energy efficient solar technologies like solar.

On the downside, Global Payments (GPN) plunged 10% in heavy volume, slicing through its 50-day line, after the credit card payments processor said it would buy rival Heartland Payment Systems (HPY) for $4.3 billion.

Meanwhile, homebuiders rose after housing starts and building permits rose much more than expected in November, according to data from the Commerce Department. That sent homebuilders Pulte Group (PHM) and Toll Bros. (TOL) each up 2%, while D.R. Horton (DHI) and Lennar (LEN) both rose about 1%.Stocks pared gains at midday Wednesday amid expectations the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates later in the day. If an investor catches the breakout of a stock that advances smartly, a three-weeks-tight pattern can be an opportunity to add shares. The three-weeks-tight pattern is most easily seen on a weekly chart. The pattern involves three closes each within about 1% of each other. The buy point is the high in the pattern plus 10 cents. Fuel card provider…
Stocks continued to hang near their session highs ahead of the Fed's beige book report, which will be out at 2 p.m. ET.
The Dow Jones industrial average and the Nasdaq rallied 0.7% each. The S&P 500 gained 0.5%. Volume was tracking higher on both major exchanges in the stock market today, especially the NYSE.

InvenSense (INVN) was off its session peak, but still up 3% in fast trade. It's forming a cup-with-handle base with a 21.30 buy point. The stock's handle formed in heavy volume, a negative It's best if a handle forms in light trade.

Manitowoc (MTW) rose 2% to its best levels since August 2008. It's now 17% past a 21.97 buy point. Shares of the crane maker have been on a tear and are on pace for an eighth straight weekly gain. The stock is No. 36 in Wednesday's IBD 50.
But some leaders were having a rough going.

Qiwi (QIWI) plunged 20% and sliced its 50-day line in huge volume. The move may be related to reports that Russian regulators are considering restraints on cross-border electronic payments. Qiwi operates a network of Internet-based ATMs, used widely for online payments and money transfers in Russia. Intraday, the stock slumped as much as 17% below a 50.75 buy point from an ascending base.

FleetCor Technologies (FLT) fell 3% and was on pace for its third straight loss. On Tuesday, the stock ended fractionally lower after paring a 3% loss. FleetCor is now 11% off its 52-week high or still within the confines for a potential flat base.

Several Sector Leaders outperformed Monday in a mostly quiet, low-volume session for the broad market.

3D Systems (DDD) turned in a solid performance, rising 4% in light turnover. Three-dimensional printing names rose en masse after TechCrunch reported over the weekend that Stratasys (SSYS) is in talks to buy MakerBot, a maker of desktop 3D printers for the consumer market.
3D Systems tried to break out from a late-stage base last month but didn't get very far. It's forming a handle area now although price and volume so far in the handle has been erratic.

LinkedIn (LNKD), meanwhile, extended its winning streak to four sessions, rising 2% in soft trade. It has started to build the right side of a potential base but still has a lot of overhead supply to conquer. It's also still below its 50-day moving average, which could turn out to be a significant resistance level.
Priceline.com (PCLN) added 0.9% in below-average volume. The online travel firm broke out last month and continues to hold near highs, but its most recent breakout was from a late-stage base.

FleetCor Technologies (FLT) picked up 1% in lukewarm trade. The company has found great success in a niche market, providing fuel cards and workforce payment products to businesses. FleetCor is pursuing a growth-through-acquisition strategy. In March, it acquired GE Capital's fleet-card business in Australia. And in late April, FleetCor acquired CardLink, a New Zealand-based fuel card and payment processing company.

FleetCor is only 3% past an 85.66 four-weeks-tight entry, but the stock just capped its seventh straight weekly price gain. Sector Leaders all gained Friday, as the general market mounted a comeback from two prior days of big losses. A couple of Sector Leaders staged rebounds in above-average volume. FleetCor Technologies (FLT) reversed higher and gained 1.02 to 73.44 in slightly above-average trade. Intraday, the stock fell below its 50-day moving average and 4% under a 73 buy point from…
In the course of a year, what was once a high-flying stock can tank, while a poorly rated stock can soar. But the best stocks are the stable ones that have stayed strong throughout the year.

Ten companies — including 3D Systems (DDD), Qihoo 360 Technology (QIHU) and Michael Kors (KORS) — started the year on the IBD 50 list and made it to the end of 2013 by maintaining superior earnings, strong price performance and leadership within industries.
Chinese Internet companies have gained recognition among U.S. investors as they expand their reach in the world's most populous country.
Qihoo outshone rival Baidu (BIDU) as the operator of software distribution websites, branching out to include antivirus software, a search engine and online games.
Qihoo started the year at No. 11 on the IBD 50 and finished at No. 3. Shares have soared 174% since the start of 2013.

Generac Holdings (GNRC) saw a boost from the housing recovery as construction crews bought generators for backup power and nighttime work. Homeowners who are worried about power outages due to hurricanes and other disasters purchased generators too.
The self-sufficiency that its generators provide also helped put Generac on the list of stocks that would prepare you for a zombie apocalypse.
The company started 2013 at No. 15 on the IBD 50 and ended at No. 7. Shares have rallied 87%.

3D Systems and Stratasys (SSYS) led the 3D printing craze as more manufacturers looked to the companies' machines to custom-build parts, including components for jet engines, cars and medical devices.
Starting off the year at No. 1 on the IBD 50, 3D Systems ended it at No. 13, with shares surging 155%. Stratasys started at No. 12 and ended at No. 32, with shares up 61%.
During the year, shale drilling continued to rise as part of an ongoing energy renaissance, putting the U.S. on the path for energy independence in the next decade.

U.S. Silica (SLCA) is having its own renaissance as it shifts away from making silica for the glass and chemical sectors to making fracking proppants for the oil and gas industry, which now accounts for 60% of its revenue.
Shares doubled during the year. U.S. Silica began 2013 at No. 29 on the IBD 50 and is ending it at No. 40.

While fashion trends come and go quickly, Michael Kors and its affordable luxury products have remained trendy and are even winning over fickle teens, who are shunning prior youth retailer mainstays like Abercrombie & Fitch (ANF) and American Eagle (AEO).

Last month, Kors said fiscal Q2 same-store sales in North America surged 21%, helped by its accessories and watch collections. Since going public in December 2011, the company has consistently posted double- or triple-digit sales and earnings growth.
Shares have climbed 58%. It began at No. 6 and ended at No. 41.

Other stocks that were featured on the year's first and last IBD 50 lists were Fleetcor Technologies (FLT), Grand Canyon Education (LOPE), Polaris Industries (PII) and ARM Holdings (ARMH).In the course of a year, what was once a high-flying stock can tank, while a poorly rated stock can soar. Meanwhile, HomeAway (AWAY) lost ground for the seventh straight session, slipping 0.1% in average volume. The company went…

A wobbly market got a little more wobbly Wednesday as major averages fell sharply in higher volume.Most sector leaders took it on the chin, including  HomeAway (AWAY). The online marketplace for vacation rentals extended its losing streak to six sessions, falling nearly 4% in huge volume. The stock gapped up out of an 18-week base in February and could be ready for an initial test of the 10-week moving average, currently around 29.The company went public in June 2011 at 27. Earnings growth has accelerated for two straight quarters and growth prospects are bright with full-year profit seen rising 33% in 2013 and 25% in 2014.Meanwhile, online professional network LinkedIn (LNKD) also fell hard, losing 3% in above-average turnover. It's the stock's first above-average volume decline since it started to consolidate gains last month. LinkedIn is still holding above its 10-week moving average, but not by much.Proto Labs (PRLB) surrendered 3% in soft trade. It's also holding above its 10-week average as it consolidates recent gains. It's working on a base-on-base pattern. The pattern forms after a stock breaks out from a base, rallies less than 20%, and then forms another base on top of the prior base.Finally, FleetCor Technologies (FLT) dropped 0.7% in average volume. The company is generating big profits in a niche market, providing fuel cards and workforce payment products and services to commercial fleets, oil companies, petroleum marketers and government entities. No sell signals have appeared yet in FleetCor, and the stock remains under accumulation, but it's also extended after a big run-up. If it pulls back more, watch for support at its 10-week moving average around 70.

Stocks backed off again Tuesday, with higher volume making for a higher distribution day count for the S&P 500 index.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.6%, the S&P 500 lost 0.3% and the Nasdaq dipped 0.2%.
That's the second straight loss for the Nasdaq, and the third straight for the Dow and S&P 500.
The Nasdaq barely escaped recording a distribution day, losing a hair less than the 0.2% threshold. But the S&P 500 now has eight distribution days, which is pushing the envelope.
Volume in the stock market today climbed 8% on the Nasdaq and 12% on the NYSE, according to preliminary data.

Chinese real-estate info and marketing website SouFun Holdings (SFUN), which shot up 11% Monday, tacked on 7% and hit a new high in reasonably fast trade. SouFun has soared 176% since it broke out July 16 from a six-month consolidation. SouFun said Monday it will debut its new financial services platform, SouFun Financial Services Channel, Dec. 16. Through this platform, the company will be able to offer third-party financial services to SouFun's home-buying members, real estate agents, developers and providers of home-improvement products and services. And look for SouFun to offer its own financial products in coming months.

Nutritional and weight-loss products maker Herbalife (HLF), famous for its network-style marketing model, shot up 7% in heavy volume and struck a new high. The company won a court decision in Belgium, where a consumer group alleged that the company operated as a sort of Ponzi scheme. In overturning a lower court's decision, an appeals court disagreed.

Krispy Kreme Doughnuts (KKD) crashed 20% in monster volume, piercing well below its 10-day line and leaving in its wake a huge gap. This is Krispy Kreme's third straight loss, and its second with heavy volume.

The company's Q3 report (for the three months through October) showed earnings rose 33% to 16 cents, while sales climbed 7% to $114.2 million. Both metrics came up shy of estimates, which had been running at 15 cents on $115 million.

Also disheartening, Krispy Kreme guided Q4 earnings in the range of 11 cents to 14 cents. The Street had been looking for 14 cents, the upper end of this band. Even worse, the company's full-year guidance for 2015, 71 cents to 76 cents, was shy of the consensus, which was at 77 cents.Stocks backed off again Tuesday, with higher volume making for a higher distribution day count for the S&P 500 index.The Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.6%, the S&P 500 lost 0.3% and the Nasdaq dipped 0.2%.That's the second straight loss for the Nasdaq, and the third straight for the Dow and S&P 500.The Nasdaq barely escaped recording a distribution day, losing a hair less than the 0.2% threshold. Fewer stocks have been earning a spot on the Sector Leaders screen in recent sessions. Out of the three stocks currently in the lineup, two joined in Monday's moderate market sell-off, while one resisted the negative trend. It was a noteworthy day for the Sector Leaders Monday, as three made bearish price reversals and a fourth hit a new high.
Shares of FleetCor Technologies (FLT) rose 0.57 to 77.24 to a record high in above-average trading. The stock rallied in the final hour of the session to avoid posting a loss.
The provider of fuel payment cards is above its buy range from a buy point at 73, marked by a three-weeks-tight pattern.
The pattern was one of a few follow-on buy areas FleetCor has formed since a breakout in August launched an impressive 85% advance.
Despite the prolonged advance, FleetCor is not flashing any sell signals. But its gain from the initial breakout justifies taking profits.
Three leaders seemed to get caught up in the market's wave of selling and reversed lower.
HomeAway (AWAY) slid 0.90, or 3%, to 31.60 in volume about 40% above average.
The provider of vacation rental bookings is still well above the 27.57 buy point from a breakout on Feb. 21. Still, Monday's loss marked its worst day since the breakout.
LinkedIn (LNKD) fell 2.45 to 173.61 in volume one-fourth lower than usual. The stock remained in a two-week sideways range, well extended from its January breakout past a 117.42 buy point.
The social media company appears to be taking a breather after its Q4 results sparked a steep five-week ascent.
Proto Labs (PRLB) hit resistance around 49.50 for the third time in less than three weeks, shedding 1.56 to 47.54. Volume was 23% above normal.

Some market-leading stocks held up better than others Tuesday as the major averages reversed lower with increased volume. The Nasdaq, which had poked 0.2% higher and struck a new 14-year high, reversed lower and ended off 0.6%. The S&P 500 fell 0.7% and the Dow Jones industrial average dropped 0.9%. Volume in the stock market today climbed 17% on the…
Analysts get most of their data about a company directly from the company.
When a company's Wall Street earnings estimates are rising, that reflects the confidence the company has in itself that its profit will keep growing, making it worthy of special notice.

Today's Screen Of The Day is Leaders with Rising Estimates. The five top companies on the screen are: Cabela's (CAB), FleetCor Technologies (FLT), Stratasys (SSYS), Grand Canyon Education (LOPE) and Hertz Global (HTZ).

Cabela's, an outdoor equipment chain, competes with Big Five Sporting Goods (BGFV) and other sporting equipment chains. Cabela's is an IBD 50 list stock, and it sports a best-possible 99 IBD Composite Rating, meaning its stock has recently outperformed 99% of all stocks.

Cabela's sales have spiked in recent quarters as prospects of tighter gun control measures in the wake of shootings led to higher gun sales. Shares, up 76% since late December, fell 1.3% Thursday in stock market trading.
Analysts now expect Cabela's to report a 30% EPS gain in the next quarter.

FleetCor, which provides fuel cards for truckers and other vehicle fleets, on May 2 reported a 50% hike in earnings per share, its strongest gain in years, beating estimates by 7 cents. Revenue surged 32% to $193.7 million, sending its shares to an intraday all-time high 85.56 the next day, closing at 80.34. Shares have moved sideways since then, edging up 0.3% Thursday to 82.06.
Analysts now expect FleetCor to report a 30% EPS gain in the next quarter.

3D printing is a disruptive technology, and Stratasys and 3D Systems (DDD) are the market leaders, although new arrival ExOne (XONE) joined the party with its Feb. 7 IPO. Stratasys, No. 3 on the rising estimates screen, on May 17 reported that Q1 EPS climbed 34%, beating forecasts by 5 cents. Revenue more than doubled to $97.2 million, just missing estimates. Its stock price has rallied more than 50% from a Feb. 26 low and closed up 2.4% Thursday, near a recent all-time high. 3D also is on the Rising Estimates screen.
Analysts now expect Stratasys to report a 38% EPS gain in the next quarter, with 3D up 33%.

Grand Canyon Education, a private Christian university, is the top-rated company in the Consumer Services-Education group and carries a 99 IBD Composite Rating. Its stock grew at a moderate pace in the second half of 2012 and early in 2013, but really took off this month. Shares have risen 28% since the company reported outstanding results on May 7, although they edged down 0.6% Thursday.
Analysts now expect Grand Canyon to report a 14% EPS gain in the next quarter.

Hertz, the car rental giant, is another IBD 50 lister. It's also the top-rated company in the 28-stock Leisure-Services group. Its stock prices has popped 77% since mid-November in sync with a market upturn. Shares edged down 0.5% Thursday.
Analysts now expect Hertz to report a 29% EPS gain in the next quarter.
Related: Check Out 5 Big Caps With Long-Term Growth Prospects

Stocks slumped early Wednesday as eurozone worries again flared up.
The Dow Jones industrial average, Nasdaq and S&P 500 each slid 0.7%. Volume was running mixed in the stock market today: higher on the NYSE and lower on the Nasdaq.
In U.S. economic news, pending-home sales fell 0.4% in February vs. forecast for a 0.7% drop.
Leading stocks were mostly lower, but those down big in high volume were few.

Westlake Chemical (WLK) lost 2% in slightly above-average volume and fell below a 94.16 buy point from a flat base. But the stock is nearing potential support at its 50-day line. The stock broke out March 12 in lackluster volume.

Visa (V) pulled back 1% after ramping up in the past three sessions. It's still 3% past a 161.88 buy point from a handle in a flat base. The stock broke out Monday in heavy volume. Visa's latest pattern is a third-stage structure. Generally, first- or second-stage bases are preferable.
FleetCor Technologies (FLT) slipped 1%, but remains near new highs. The stock is back in buying range from a 73 buy point in a three-weeks-tight pattern.

On the upside, Gilead Sciences (GILD) rose 2% to a record high. It cleared a 46.47 buy point from a three-weeks-tight pattern. With the market in a confirmed uptrend, the list of stocks breaking out to new highs is expanding across a wider range of sectors. J2 Global (JCOM) advanced 1.19 to 76.12 , clearing a 75.72 flat-base buy point in above-average volume. The stock gapped up and rose 5% Monday, when the Internet services provider said it completed nine acquisitions in…

Even as the indexes probe ground near multiyear highs, a number of top-rated stocks are offering entries. But beware, some entries are better than others. FleetCor Technologies (FLT), which provides specialty payment systems to commercial fleets and the oil industry, shot up 5% in double-paced trade Friday. That move was a breakout from a three-weeks-tight, as well as a further…
The typical long-haul tractor-trailer truck gets about 6 miles per gallon in the U.S., according to industry data.

The average daily run for a long-haul, over-the-road truck driver is roughly 500 miles. The Energy Information Association estimates that the average retail price of on-highway diesel fuel will be $3.91 per gallon this year.

Do the math, and it comes out to about $325 in fuel costs for a typical 500-mile haul. That doesn't even include a laundry list of other expenses from logistics systems and administrative costs to maintenance and salaries.
That's why trucking firms try to trim costs wherever they can.

One company that aims to help them do that is FleetCor Technologies (FLT). It provides payment products and services to commercial fleets, major oil firms and petroleum marketers, serving more than 530,000 commercial accounts in 18 countries.
The company's core product is fleet vehicle payment processing services for commercial and government fleets, mainly for fuel purchases.

Its FleetCards USA business unit offers cards that work like credit cards but can handle a variety of tasks beyond just buying gas. Those tasks include helping clients manage fuel and maintenance expenses, reduce fraudulent fuel charges, locate fueling locations, and track drivers and vehicles.
FleetCor acts as a sort of middleman between the customer and the fuel merchant, helping customers control operating costs while helping fuel merchants grow sales.
Better Management

"FleetCor's payment programs allow fleets to better manage and control employee spending, while driving repeat business for its merchant partners," JPMorgan analyst Tien-tsin Huang noted in a recent report.
FleetCor gets a fee every time a card is used. It's the kind of steady, low-cost business that earns high marks from analysts.
"FleetCor's business is characterized by recurring revenue, low capital expenditures, and strong operating margins and cash flow," Huang said.

The company's annual revenue has more than doubled over the past five years thanks to a combination of organic growth and acquisitions. About two-thirds of FleetCor's business comes from North America, with the rest coming from international markets across the globe.
FleetCor went public in December 2010 at an opening stock price of 23. Shares peaked at 38 in April and currently trade near 36 .
The company claims it can help save clients 15% or more on fuel and other costs compared to other payment methods. For 18-wheelers, that can add up to thousands of dollars a year.
Such savings are especially important nowadays with oil and fuel prices trading near historical highs.

High prices at the pump have a double benefit for FleetCor. The company not only gets more business from cost-conscious fleet managers, it also gets better spreads between the fuel price it charges its fleet customers and the wholesale price paid to the fuel merchant. Around 19% of the company's revenue comes from fuel-price spreads.

Thanks to these and other factors, FleetCor put up impressive numbers in its first year as a public company. It logged 2011 net income of $181.7 million, or $2.17 a share. Revenue was $520 million, a 20% gain from the prior year.

In a recent report, Citigroup analyst Philip Stiller cited several FleetCor strengths, including "high barriers to entry, strong margins, prospects for international expansion and a strong M&A track record."

FleetCor reported fourth-quarter earnings Feb. 8. Profit came in at 56 cents a share, topping Wall Street views by 6 cents. Revenue was $140 million, a 32% gain from the prior year and above estimates for $128 million.

"Revenue growth remained robust, helped by higher fuel prices and wider fuel spreads," Stiller noted. "The North America segment had strong growth of 34% due to positive environmental factors and the ongoing rollout of its universal fleet card product. In the international segment, recent acquisitions helped drive some upside relative to expectations."
Earnings Guidance
FleetCor guided 2012 earnings in a range of $2.55 to $2.60 a share. It guided revenue of $615 million to $620 million.
Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect full-year profit to grow 19% this year and 10% in 2013.
FleetCor will get the full benefit this year of a couple acquisitions it made during the latter half of 2011, both of which bolstered the company's international footprint.
In September, it acquired a prepaid fuel card company in Mexico that serves more than 10,000 businesses with more than 800,000 cardholders and beneficiaries.

Three months later, FleetCor spent $304 million to buy AllStar Business Solutions, a U.K. fuel card company. AllStar's cards let fleet operators provide company drivers with a payment card to securely fuel their vehicles without the need to pay with cash or personal cards.

"FleetCor is clearly executing very well and has opportunities to drive continued strong EPS growth going forward given its recent acquisitions and a full pipeline of potential contracts and M&A," analyst Stiller noted.The typical long-haul tractor-trailer truck gets about 6 miles per gallon in the U.S., according to industry data.The average daily run for a long-haul, over-the-road truck driver is roughly 500 miles. Sector Leaders gave a mixed performance Friday, just as the major indexes closed mixed.

Jazz Pharmaceuticals (JAZZ) rose 1.62, or 2%, to 67.13 in seesaw trading. The stock recouped a little more than half of Thursday's 4% drop after again finding support near the 65 level. Volume jumped 33% above average Friday.
Despite the gain, Jazz still lost 5% for the week. It snapped a five-week win streak. The stock cleared a 60.30 buy point from a cup-with-handle base May 21.
On Friday, it finished 11% past that trigger. Jazz has yet to test its 10-week moving average.
Yandex (YNDX) bounced modestly after suffering its biggest loss in two months Thursday. Shares rose 0.43 to 26.41 in fast trade. Yandex is finding support at its 50-day moving average.
In recent weeks, the stock has erased all gains from its breakout past a 26.07 buy point. It was up as much as 13% past that trigger a few weeks ago.
With the market now in a correction, shareholders shouldn't let a double-digit winner turn into a loser.

FleetCor Technologies (FLT) eased just 0.13 to 83.80 after sliding 4% intraday. The stock closed above support at its 50-day moving average and the 80 level. But it's still 6% below an 88.93 buy point from a three-weeks-tight pattern.
The stock, which has been on a huge tear since its August breakout, posted its first weekly loss in nine weeks.
Ocwen Financial (OCN) racked up its fifth loss in the past six sessions. It fell 0.83 to 41.51 in about double its average volume.

The leading stocks in IBD's 33 sector groups rose Friday in higher volume.FleetCor Technologies (FLT) rose 3.44, or 5%, to a new high of 75.82 in almost three times its average daily trade. The stock also cleared a buy point of 73 in a three-weeks-tight pattern. The pattern gives current shareholders a chance to buy more shares, though aggressive investors may open a position.The financial leader is hitting new highs despite triggering a key IBD sell rule Feb. 8, when it broke above an upper channel line connecting a series of highs. That's often a sign the stock has peaked.The provider of fuel cards to commercial vehicle fleets has posted strong revenue and profit growth in recent quarters, which accounts for its best-possible 99 Earnings Per Share Rating. Its Accumulation-Distribution Rating of A- indicates strong demand.HomeAway (AWAY), an online market for vacation home rentals, also hit a new high, climbing 1.21 to 33.11 in huge volume. It's well out of buying range, however, 20% above a 27.57 cup-base entry.Like FleetCor, HomeAway finished near its intraday high, which is a good sign.HomeAway was trading in a tight range until Thursday, when the company announced a partnership with Asia-based Travelmob and Morgan Stanley upgraded the stock to overweight from equal weight.The company's annual pretax margin has been above 20% in each of the past two years.Elsewhere, business networking site LinkedIn (LNKD) rose 6.44 to 181.48, putting it within 1% of an all-time high. Volume was modest.Like the other leaders, LinkedIn boasts strong fundamentals. But it's far beyond the 5% limit that defines a buy area.

CommVault (CVLT) broke out above a 79.63 buy point in huge volume Thursday, hitting a new high on a day when most other leading stocks showed quiet action.The developer of database management software soared 6.63, or 9%, to 84.20 in huge volume following a Bloomberg report that said CommVault could be a takeover target.The big gain sent the stock 6% beyond the 79.63 buy point from a flat base, putting it just out of buying range.The software developer has posted strong profit growth ranging from 43% to 58% over the past three quarters. Sales growth has ranged from 21% to 24% over that period. The company has said it's been landing bigger accounts.Meanwhile, business networking site LinkedIn (LNKD) edged up 58 cents to a new high of 179.85 in volume that was just below average. The stock had been up as much as 4.88, or 3%, before ending near the bottom of its intraday range.LinkedIn is 54% past a 116.97 handle entry and isn't flashing a sell sign.Elsewhere, FleetCor Technologies (FLT) added 6 cents to 70.56, remaining 3% off its record high.The provider of fuel cards to commercial vehicle fleets jumped above its upper channel line more than a month ago, triggering a sell signal. However, after a high-volume gap down on March 7, the stock has settled down and traded in a tight range in recent sessions.The other leading financial stock, mortgage loan servicer  Ocwen Financial (OCN), climbed 25 cents to 40.66. The stock remained 3% above a 39.35 buy point in a cup-with-handle base, putting it within the 5% limit that defines a buy area. Ocwen boasts a best-possible 99 Composite Rating.

As chairman and chief executive of FleetCor Technologies (FLT), Clarke attributes the Norcross, Ga.-based firm's growth to one word: focus. Stocks ended modestly lower Wednesday after Federal Reserve chief Janet Yellen said there was a "live possibility" of an interest-rate hike next month.The S&P 500 fell 0.4%, the Dow Jones industrial average edged down 0.3% and the Nasdaq dipped 0.1%. Volume was mixed, dipping about 1% on the NYSE and rising 4% on the Nasdaq compared to Tuesday, according to preliminary data.Makers of consumer telecommunications stocks were among the biggest losers in the stock market today. Motorola Solutions (MSI), which makes two-way radios and other communications products, plunged more than 8% despite better-than-expected Q3 profit and sales results. The stock, which had been working on a flat base, crashed through its 50-day moving average before finally steadying just above its 200-day line.Tesla Motors (TSLA) led shares of automakers higher, soaring 11% as the electric vehicle maker's Q4 delivery outlook trumped a weaker-than-expected quarterly earnings report. The stock is testing resistance at its 200-day line but remains 19% off its 52-week higher.HomeAway (AWAY) rocketed in post-session trading after Expedia (EXPE) agreed to buy the online marketplace for vacation rentals for $3.9 billion. The deal, which is expected to close in the first quarter of next year pending regulatory approval, is expected to help Expedia compete against home-rental businesses such as Airbnb.Meanwhile, Facebook (FB) rose in after-hours trading following its Q3 earnings report. Profit for the period rose 33% to 57 cents a share on a 41% gain in revenue to $4.5 billion. Both topped Wall Street estimates.The company said the number of daily active users rose 17% from a year ago to 1.01 billion on average for September. Mobile daily active users jumped 27% to 894 million on average during the month.Facebook rose 1% during the regular session. It's out of buying range from a 96.59 buy point.Qualcomm (QCOM) was down sharply after hours after its outlook for the fiscal first quarter that ends in December trailed analysts' estimates. That outweighed better-than-expected results in the latest period.Disney (DIS), Celgene (CELG), CyberArk Software (CYBR) and Nvidia (NVDA) are among companies scheduled to report quarterly earnings Thursday.Economic reports due Thursday include initial jobless claims for the week ended Oct. 31 and Q3 productivity data.

The top stocks from IBD's 33 sectors rose across the board Wednesday, following the major averages higher. But their volume was mostly below average.Many leaders remain within striking distance of their recent highs despite recent pullbacks.FleetCor (FLT), which provides fuel cards to commercial vehicle fleets, was among the biggest gainers. It rose 91 cents to 69.74.The stock has been holding up fairly well despite triggering a key IBD sell rule on Feb. 8, when it jumped above a long-term upper channel line. It's still just 4% off its high. The stock formed three-weeks-tight pattern with a buy point at 73 but has dipped modestly below that pattern. Jazz Pharmaceuticals (JAZZ) is also holding within striking distance of an all-time high despite pulling back recently in light volume.The stock climbed 5 cents Wednesday to 58.21 as it manages to stay above a 58.09 cup-with-handle buy point.Ireland-based Jazz boasts strong profit and sales growth thanks to strong demand for its narcolepsy drug Xyrem. Though it relies heavily on Xyrem, Jazz has been trying to diversify through acquisitions.The stock's Accumulation/Distribution Rating is A-, reflecting strong institutional demand for the shares.Meanwhile, CommVault Systems (CVLT) tacked on 1.41 to 82.74, snapping a three-day losing streak. Yet volume was well below average.The stock is now 4% above a 79.63 buy point from a flat base. The data management software company's shares had been up as much as 9% from the buy point. It broke out last Thursday on takeover speculation.

One could argue that the L in CAN SLIM is the lynchpin of IBD's investing system. It stands for leaders — the best stocks culled from thousands on offer.Finding just a handful of true leaders in the early stages of their big run-ups can bring great wealth to the disciplined investor. Baidu (BIDU), Apple (AAPL) and Alexion Pharmaceuticals (ALXN) are just a few recent examples of top stocks that racked up huge returns."The top one, two or three stocks in a strong industry group can have unbelievable growth, while others in the pack may hardly stir," wrote IBD founder William O'Neil in "How to Make Money in Stocks."Leading stocks have the best fundamentals and sound chart patterns. The shares are in demand by mutual funds and other big investors. Why? Top companies offer unique products and services that take market share away from their competitors."By number one, I don't mean the largest company or the one with the most recognized brand name," O'Neil wrote. "I mean the one with the best quarterly and annual earnings growth, the highest return on equity, the widest profit margins, the strongest sales growth, and the most dynamic stock-price action."The Big Picture column and the Market Pulse box that appear in IBD each day focus on the action of leading stocks.Use the Timesaver Tables, the Stock Spotlight and IBD's Smart Tables, which focus on stocks with superior fundamentals.Each stock is accompanied by key metrics, such as the Relative Price Strength Rating. The RS rating is the quickest way to create a list of promising candidates. A rating of 99 indicates the stock is outperforming 99% of all listed companies over the past 52 weeks. An RS Rating of 50 shows that it's outperforming only half of all stocks. Eliminate those with an RS Rating of 85 or lower.The Composite Rating, Accumulation-Distribution Rating and the Earnings Per Share Rating can also be used to screen for the best stocks. It's not unusual to see leading stocks post triple-digit quarterly earnings and sales growth before starting their big runs. Many also show strong prior uptrends that have outperformed most other stocks.FleetCor Technologies (FLT) had strong fundamentals when it broke out above a 41.40 cup-base buy point on Aug. 15, 2012. Profit during the quarter of its breakout jumped 48%, topping the healthy 28% increases in each of the prior two quarters. Sales growth was similarly strong.At the time, the stock scored a 98 Composite Rating, a 97 EPS and a 91 RS. The day after the breakout, FleetCor appeared in the Market Pulse box, Stock Spotlight and in the Time Saver tables, highlighting it as a leader.FleetCor has moved up steadily along its 10-week line. Investors who bought at the breakout are up 64% in just six months so far.
Stocks gained ground in soft trade Friday, with earnings reports and positive trade balance data boosting investor confidence.
The Nasdaq bolted 0.9%. The S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average gained 0.5% each. Volume was down 6% on the Nasdaq and 10% lower on the NYSE compared with Thursday morning's action.
The stock market today opened with the major indexes showing modest losses for the week. But the Nasdaq, Dow and S&P 500 quickly turned positive and were tracking toward a sixth straight weekly gain.

Wholesale inventories tightened 0.1% in December, according to Commerce Department data. That compared with a downwardly revised 0.4% expansion in November and was less than the 0.4% increase expected. Tighter inventories mean industries are actively moving more product than they are purchasing to restock supplies.
In stocks, LinkedIn (LNKD) spiked 17% at the open. The social networking site for professionals reported a big fourth-quarter win late Thursday.

Leading stocks edged moderately higher in early trade, except for FleetCor Technologies (FLT). It gapped up to a 12% gain, leading the IBD 50 list of stocks, after its Q4 results swept past analysts' consensusestimate.

CommVault Systems (CVLT) bolted 4% in hefty trade after four straight down days. Standard & Poor's announced late Thursday the stock would join the S&P MidCap 400 index. The date for the change was not announced. The move put CommVault 3% below its Feb. 1 high and 10% above a 70.02 buy point.

Stocks finished narrowly mixed Wednesday as the main indexes touched fresh multiyear highs in a muted, choppy session.

The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.3% and again hit a record high. The S&P 500 edged up a bit more than 0.1%, while the Nasdaq dipped less than 0.1%. Volume increased from Tuesday's level in the stock market today for the NYSE, but decreased for the Nasdaq, according to early data.

After the market's close, FleetCor Technologies (FLT) dropped as it announced a secondary offering of 4.5 million shares by certain stockholders. The provider of fuel cards for fleets was No. 1 in Wednesday's IBD 50.

Also after hours, specialty retailer PetSmart (PETM) and SolarCity (SCTY), a residential solar installer, both tumbled on their quarterly reports. PetSmart's earnings beat estimates, but revenue missed. It's been consolidating since August. Meanwhile, December IPO SolarCity posted a wider-than-expected Q4 loss.
In economic news Wednesday, the Fed's beige book showed modest to moderate growth, and ADP's monthly jobs report beat forecasts.
In Washington, the Republican-controlled House voted to prevent budget wrangling from shutting down the government on March 27, when current funding expires.

Stocks stayed near session highs Friday as buyers continued to put money to work. The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 hit new all-time highs.
The Nasdaq rose 1.4%; the S&P 500 added 1.2% and the Dow Jones industrial average picked up 1.1%. Nasdaq volume was tracking about 10% higher than Thursday. NYSE volume rose 3%.

The economy created 165,000 jobs in April, slightly ahead of expectations. The unemployment rate ticked lower to 7.5%. Big upward revisions to February and March job growth were also welcomed by the market.

In the stock market today, several IBD 50 components made big moves, many in heavy volume. Proto Labs (PRLB) jumped 4% in nearly double-average volume to a new high. The stock tried to break out during the week of April 12 but didn't make much progress. Shares fell 9% the following week in heavy volume.
Meanwhile, Green Mountain Coffee Roasters (GMCR) touched a fresh 52-week high ahead of its earnings report May 8 after the close. Shares rose 2% in slightly heavier volume.
Other big percentage gainers in the IBD 50 included fracking play U.S. Silica Holdings (SLCA), Worthington Industries (WOR), FleetCor Technologies (FLT) and 3D Systems (DDD).

In earnings news, Fortune Brands Home & Security (FBHS) broke out in heavy volume, rising 7%. It cleared a flat base with a buy point of 38.26. Late Thursday, the ancillary housing play reported profit of 24 cents a share, up 200% from a year ago and well ahead of views of 16 cents. Sales growth accelerated for the third straight quarter, up 11% to $890 million. The company also initiated a quarterly dividend of 10 cents share, giving it a yield of 1.1%.

Elsewhere in earnings, Regeneron Pharmaceuticals (REGN) continued its recent ascent, rising 7% in heavy volume. Late Thursday, the drugmaker reported continued strong sales of its flagship drug Eylea, used to treat age-related wet macular degeneration, a leading cause of blindness in the elderly. First-quarter profit soared 381% to $1.78 a share. Sales rose 90% to $439.7 million. Analysts were modeling 95 cents on sales of $424.3 million. Shares of Regeneron soared 10% earlier this week after Allergan (AGN) announced a delay in an eye drug it's developing that would've competed with Eylea.
At the New York Mercantile Exchange, June gold traded at $1,466 an ounce, down $1.60. June oil traded at $95.68 a barrel, up $1.69.

In the energy space, oil and gas producer Bonzana Creek Energy (BCEI) jumped 6% in sluggish volume ahead of its earnings report May 9 after the close. Another strong quarter of growth is expected with profit seen rising 46% from a year ago to 41 cents a share. Sales are forecast to rise 60% to $79.5 million. But the stock closed below a 90.64 buy point and its 50-day line. The Latin American e-commerce company is new to Sector Leaders.FleetCor Technologies (FLT) fell 1.68 to 72.42. It ended just above potential support at its 50-day moving average. Volume was below average Thursday, which is positive in a pullback.FleetCor has had a massive run since breaking out in August and has already found support at the similar 10-week line.HomeAway (AWAY) lost ground for the second straight session. Shares gave up 0.66 to 31.74 in brisk trade. That was its third loss of the week.The stock is still 15% past a 27.57 buy point from a cup-without-handle base cleared Feb. 21. It had been up as much as 24% from the buy point. In most cases, profits should be taken when they amount to 20% to 25%.

IBD's leading stocks ended mixed Friday in weak volume as the major averages declined.Proto Labs (PRLB) was the biggest loser, plunging 2.08, or 4%, to 50.15 in double its average daily volume. It's just above a 49.78 buy point.The maker of molds used to produce prototype parts has swung wildly since rocketing above the entry Wednesday in huge trade.Proto Labs is due to report first-quarter earnings April 25 before the opening bell. Wall Street analysts expect profit to rise 35% from a year ago to 31 cents a share. Sales are seen climbing 23% to $36.8 million.The stock's Accumulation-Distribution Rating has slipped to a still-decent B-.LinkedIn (LNKD) bucked Friday's downdraft by reversing higher to end up 5.21, or 3%, at a new record high of 185.39. Volume was slightly above normal. The social network went public in May 2011. It's become extended from a rebound off its 10-week moving average.The company said late Thursday that it bought Pulse, an app that delivers news to handheld devices.HomeAway (AWAY) was the only other winner among Sector Leaders, edging up 0.12 to 33.03 in weak trade. The online marketplace for vacation rentals is extended 20% past a 27.57 buy point and is just 3% below its March 25 high.HomeAway is due to report first-quarter earnings April 23. Profit is expected to rise 44% to 13 cents a share on a 23% rise in sales, to $64.1 million.Elsewhere, FleetCor Technologies (FLT) and auto dealer Lithia Motors (LAD) each slipped 1% in weak volume. FleetCor is just out of buying range from a 73 buy point in a three-weeks-tight pattern. Lithia is getting support at its 10-week moving average.
International payment systems operator Euronet International (EEFT) saw better-than-expected fourth quarter earnings on stronger electronic fund transfer and money transfer revenues.

Euronet reported adjusted earnings of 42 cents, up 13.5% from a year ago and a penny over analysts' forecasts. Net revenue climbed 10% to $351.2 million, topping analyst forecasts for $338.28 million.
"This earnings growth was the result of our continued focus on new products and markets together with effective execution across most of our business," CEO Michael Brown said in a statement.

Those results back out one-time charges, including impairment charges related to its electronic payments business in Brazil. Including those charges, it posted a 26 cents per-share loss, from a 21 cents per-share gain the year before.
Shares were down almost 3% intraday to 23.78 on the stock market today.
The company said its struggling electronic-payment business should stabilize in the second quarter.
The fleet fuel card and payments systems firm FleetCor Technologies (FLT) last week gapped sharply higher after posting better-than-expected results. FleetCor shares were up fractionally Wednesday.

Much larger rivals Visa (V) and MasterCard (MA) also beat analyst forecasts in their most recent quarters. Stocks posted solid gains Friday, with Nasdaq volume rising despite a tough comparison. The S&P 500 and the Nasdaq each advanced 0.7% Friday. The IBD 50 tacked on 0.5%. Volume rose slightly on the Nasdaq and slipped on the NYSE. The higher volume on the Nasdaq was impressive considering a tough comparison vs. Thursday. Oracle's (ORCL) volume soared Thursday on…
Stock futures on Tuesday advanced toward the open for a second straight day, but showed a bit more strength than in Monday's premarket session.

Dow futures were ahead 91.1 points, well above Monday's premarket levels, and rising. Nasdaq 100 futures climbed 23.6 points above fair market value. S&P 500 futures showed a healthy 10.2-point gain. Small caps also looked in good shape, with Russell 2000 futures up 4.8 points.

The stock market today rolls into December with automakers releasing November sales numbers throughout the session. Fiat Chrysler (FCAU) reported a 3% gain in sales to its best level for November in 15 years. Jeep sales drove the results, rising 20%, vs. a 12% decline for Chrysler products, an 8% slip for Dodge and a 3% fall for Fiat autos.
Auto researcher Edmunds forecasts a total of 1.33 million light vehicles sold during the month, up 2.5% from a year ago. If accurate, it would make this the best November for automakers since 2001.
At 10 a.m., the Institute for Supply Management releases its November ISM Index and the Commerce Department reports October construction spending.

Retailers with a strong online presence may get a bump from data released by Adobe Systems (ADBE) showing shoppers spent a total of $2.98 billion during "Cyber Monday" — the Monday following the Black Friday launch of the holiday shopping season, which is designated as a day of technology and online shopping specials. The amount was a record and up 14% from last year's Cyber Monday sales, Adobe said. Adobe also estimated that Thanksgiving through Cyber Monday receipts would top $11 billion, up 15% year-over-year and also a record.
About a third of the Dow's issues were positive in premarket action, the rest were flat. The best gain came from Home Depot (HD), which added 1%.
Adobe Systems rose 2% to lead the Nasdaq 100. Baidu (BIDU) posted the Nasdaq 100's largest decline, down nearly 2%.

Automated network control specialist Infoblox (BLOX) rocketed 17% higher before the open. The Santa Clara, Calif.-based company reported late Monday fiscal first-quarter earnings, revenue and Q2 guidance above expectations, and management announced a $100 million share buyback initiative.

Mattress Firm Holding (MFRM) bounced 5% higher after announcing late Monday it would buy HMK Mattress Holding, owner of the Sleepy's retail chain, in a $780 million deal. The company said it expects about $40 million a year in cost savings. Mattress Firm also announced its fiscal Q3 sales rose 51%, and said it expected a 10% EPS gain — in line with consensus views.

China-based Qihoo 360 Technologies (QIHU) added 3% after the Wall Street Journal reported an investor group was prepared to offer $9 billion to take the Internet security and content provider off the U.S. market. The $77-per-American Depositary Receipt deal could be completed in the coming weeks, the report said. Plans then call for relisting the company on one of China's domestic exchanges.

Qihoo is the most recent in a wave of privatizations among China-based companies trading in the U.S. Another China-based issue, Ikang Healthcare (KANG), announced Monday it was being taken private by a group of investors at $22 per ADR.

Among leaders, stocks on the IBD 50 list were quiet ahead of the open. Most of the group remained flat. Among the few gains and losses, all held to less than 1%. The same was true for stocks on IBD's Your Weekly Review list.
Overseas, markets across Asia gained as PMI gauges tracking China's manufacturing and services sectors showed further divergence during the month. European markets were narrowly mixed near midday.

New highs and new lows were scarce in Monday's holiday-shortened session. A few top-rated stocks showed noteworthy action, even if volume was understandably absent. Fuel-card provider FleetCor Technologies (FLT) popped 0.39 to 53.49, marking its sixth daily gain in a row. The stock hit a 52-week high. The Georgia-based company has been a decent performer in the current market uptrend.…
European Union regulators are looking into whether MasterCard's (MA) fees violate antitrust rules.
The EU's watchdog European Commission said it's also investigating whether the world's second-largest credit card company's business practices lock merchants into its cards in violation of EU rules.

In a statement, the commission said it intends by summer to propose a regulation of interbank fees for card payments "to ensure legal certainty and a durable level playing field across the EU for all providers."
If the EC determines that MasterCard engaged in anti-competitive practices, the company can be fined up to $740 million, or 10% of its 2012 revenue.

The EC is also looking into whether Visa Europe, the European licensee of Visa (V), the world's biggest credit card company, imposes unfair card fees there. Visa Europe is the region's largest credit card network.
The EC said the investigation into MasterCard is open-ended with no legal deadline to complete the inquiry.

MasterCard shares fell 1.7% in Tuesday morning trading in the stock market today. The credit card issuer went public in May 2006 at 39 a share. It hit an all-time high 546.90 on April 1 before consolidating.
Its stock has an 89 IBD Composite Rating, which means it's outperformed 89% of all stocks recently on key metrics such as sales and profit growth.
Visa dropped 1%. It went public on March 21, 2008 after pricing at 44. It hit an intraday high of 170.99 on April 1 before retreating. It sports a lofty 92 Composite Rating.
Among other credit card companies, American Express (AXP), which issues cards and offers travel and other services, fell fractionally.
Smaller Discover Financial Services (DFS), parent of the Discover card, slid 0.8%.
Fleetcor Technologies (FLT) has grown rapidly by providing specialized payment processing to fleet operators, which provide credit cards to their employees.
This service saves companies money and frees resources. Fleetcor shares rose 0.4%. The company's stock has a best-possible 99 Composite Rating.

They are all in the Finance-Credit Card/Payment Processing group, ranked a lackluster 135 on IBD's list of 197 industry groups.European Union regulators are looking into whether MasterCard's (MA) fees violate antitrust rules.The EU's watchdog European Commission said it's also investigating whether the world's second-largest credit card company's business practices lock merchants into its cards in violation of EU rules.In a statement, the commission said it intends by summer to propose a regulation of interbank fees for card payments "to ensure legal certainty and a durable level playing field across the EU for all providers."If the EC determines that MasterCard engaged in anti-competitive practices, the company can be fined up to $740 million, or 10% of its 2012 revenue.The EC is also looking into whether Visa Europe, the European licensee of Visa (V), the world's biggest credit card company, imposes unfair card fees there. The stock fell 0.21 to 54.11 in fast trade. Shares had gapped lower at the open, posting a 4% loss and testing the 50-day line within the session's first hour…

Sector Leaders on Monday pretty well reflected the broad market's action: mixed results on mixed volume. But the biggest moves were on the upside, and none of the Sector Leaders fell hard. The big winner of the bunch was "affordable luxury" fashion house Michael Kors (KORS), which moved up 1.52, or 3%, to 54.46 in average volume. The gain puts…
Stocks backed off again Tuesday, with higher volume making for a higher distribution day count for the S&P 500 index.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.6%, the S&P 500 lost 0.3% and the Nasdaq dipped 0.2%.
That's the second straight loss for the Nasdaq, and the third straight for the Dow and S&P 500.
The Nasdaq barely escaped recording a distribution day, losing a hair less than the 0.2% threshold. But the S&P 500 now has eight distribution days, which is pushing the envelope.
Volume in the stock market today climbed 8% on the Nasdaq and 12% on the NYSE, according to preliminary data.

Chinese real-estate info and marketing website SouFun Holdings (SFUN), which shot up 11% Monday, tacked on 7% and hit a new high in reasonably fast trade. SouFun has soared 176% since it broke out July 16 from a six-month consolidation. SouFun said Monday it will debut its new financial services platform, SouFun Financial Services Channel, Dec. 16. Through this platform, the company will be able to offer third-party financial services to SouFun's home-buying members, real estate agents, developers and providers of home-improvement products and services. And look for SouFun to offer its own financial products in coming months.

Nutritional and weight-loss products maker Herbalife (HLF), famous for its network-style marketing model, shot up 7% in heavy volume and struck a new high. The company won a court decision in Belgium, where a consumer group alleged that the company operated as a sort of Ponzi scheme. In overturning a lower court's decision, an appeals court disagreed.

Krispy Kreme Doughnuts (KKD) crashed 20% in monster volume, piercing well below its 10-day line and leaving in its wake a huge gap. This is Krispy Kreme's third straight loss, and its second with heavy volume.

The company's Q3 report (for the three months through October) showed earnings rose 33% to 16 cents, while sales climbed 7% to $114.2 million. Both metrics came up shy of estimates, which had been running at 15 cents on $115 million.

Also disheartening, Krispy Kreme guided Q4 earnings in the range of 11 cents to 14 cents. The Street had been looking for 14 cents, the upper end of this band. Even worse, the company's full-year guidance for 2015, 71 cents to 76 cents, was shy of the consensus, which was at 77 cents.Stocks backed off again Tuesday, with higher volume making for a higher distribution day count for the S&P 500 index.The Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.6%, the S&P 500 lost 0.3% and the Nasdaq dipped 0.2%.That's the second straight loss for the Nasdaq, and the third straight for the Dow and S&P 500.The Nasdaq barely escaped recording a distribution day, losing a hair less than the 0.2% threshold. Stocks reversed higher at the closing bell Monday, ending a four-session skid despite another rout in China's stock market and a further drop in oil prices.

The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.3% and the S&P 500 edged up 0.1%, while the Nasdaq dipped 0.1%. Volume in the stock market today rose 10% on the Nasdaq and 6% on the NYSE compared with Friday, according to preliminary data.
Energy, mining and biotech stocks lagged, while department store, hospital and tobacco stocks led the upside.
Aluminum producer Alcoa (AA) rose after hours following its Q4 earnings report. The stock ended the regular session down nearly 1%, declining for the eighth straight session.

Macy's (M) led the S&P 500, rising 8% in strong volume after investment advisory firm Starboard Value reportedly said Monday it supports the department store's recent joint ventures for its mall-based and real estate properties. Other department store stocks also rallied, with Kohl's (KSS) rising 5% and Dillard's (DDS) 2%.

On a sour note, IBD 50 stock Celgene (CELG) dropped nearly 6% to its lowest level in over four months. The biotech offered 2016 guidance and named COO Mark Alles as its new CEO starting March 1. Current chief Bob Hugin will become executive chairman.
Companies due to report quarterly results Tuesday include CSX (CSX) and IHS (IHS).

The several Sector Leaders were moderately mixed Friday, although the calm chart activity of one of the stocks was still significant.CommVault (CVLT) rose 1 to 77.47 in about half its usual volume. What was meaningful about that otherwise pedestrian move was the fact that the stock has now been consolidating for five weeks.That shallow correction can now be considered a flat base in the making. For yet another week, the current stock market uptrend stayed intact and produced more bullish moves by highly rated stocks.A few IBD 50 names took it on the chin, however. It's important in IBD-style investing to watch for possible breakdowns among leading stocks, since that can serve as a caution flag. So far, though, struggles among the leaders haven't been that widespread.3D Systems (DDD) and Stratasys (SSYS) were among the week's big losers.3D Systems slumped to its 10-week moving average in big volume. It had dropped that key support level in the week ended Feb. 1, then tried to rally. Meanwhile, rival 3D printer maker Stratasys undercut its 10-week line.Generac Holdings (GNRC) also lost considerable ground, though it erased some losses after touching its 10-week line. The power generator maker reported Q4 results that crushed forecasts, but its outlook disappointed the market.Among the week's big winners, Michael Kors (KORS) made a gap-up move on its strong earnings report. The fashion house jumped back above its recent 58.72 buy point after running into resistance at that level in late January.Other IBD 50 stocks have continued to climb to fresh highs, becoming even more extended from their last buying ranges. ARM Holdings (ARMH), FleetCor Technologies (FLT), Marathon Petroleum (MPC) and Waddell & Reed Financial (WDR) match this description.You also can still find some stocks that aren't that far extended from their recent buy zones. Ocwen Financial (OCN) cleared a 39.35 trigger from a cup-with-handle base a couple of weeks ago, but it's still not that far past that level.Note that the mortgage servicer's latest base was a third-stage pattern — riskier and not as fresh as a first- or second-stage structure.In addition, there are IBD 50 names that have offered secondary buying opportunities via 10-week rebounds.Consider fracking play U.S. Silica (SLCA) and South Korean chipmaker MagnaChip Semiconductor (MX). Keep in mind that MagnaChip's action also could be viewed as a base-building effort.For the week, the IBD 50 index fell 0.6%. Meanwhile, the Nasdaq and NYSE composite both edged down less than 0.1% for the week. The Nasdaq bid farewell to a six-week winning streak.The S&P 500 edged up a little more than 0.1%, extending its winning streak to seven weeks.
Consumer confidence is up, and household debt is down. That's good news for retailers. It's also good for credit card processors Visa (V) and MasterCard (MA).
The two are among the 20 stocks on Monday's Healthy Profit Margin Screen of the Day. Strong revenue is only part of the story. Leveraging profits from those sales is key.
Visa posted a profit margin last year of 60.2%, meaning it generated just over 60 cents of profit for each buck in swipe fees and other income it brought in. That was up from 56.5% the year before.
MasterCard posted a 52.4% margin last year, up from 49.8% the year before.
Rival credit card company Discover Financial (DFS) also made the list, with a 41.1% margin, up sharply from the previous year's 15.4%.

And FleetCor Technologies (FLT), which issues specialized gas cards for fleets, posted a 50% margin last year. The previous year it reported a 46.2% margin.Consumer confidence is up, and household debt is down. That's good news for retailers. Last fall, $1.2 billion MFS Mid Cap Growth Fund was willing to buy growth stocks with a little cyclicality.
That play is done. Now the fund is aiming for pure-play growth stocks.
"Back then, some of those names were on sale," co-manager Paul Gordon said Monday. "If you were willing to take some cyclical risk, you could get stocks cheaper."
"But that's played out now," Gordon added. "We're not early in the cycle. Margins have recovered. Valuations are up. So we're even more focused on just secular, three-plus-years earnings stories."

Ecolab (ECL) is an example of the fund's shift. The fund opened a stake in February. The stock was trading in the low to mid-70s. The cleaning products supplier's earnings per share have accelerated for three quarters.

"We look at it as a sustainable market-share gainer," Gordon said. "The stock had underperformed but earnings were growing above the market pace. So the stock was cheaper as cyclical names were getting more expensive."
Around the same time, the fund trimmed Cummins (CMI), whose valuation was looking pricey, he says.
The fund added to its stake in Stericycle (SRCL) in February. The medical-waste collector was trading around the mid-90s. Now it's above 105.
"Regardless of what the economy is doing, there is medical waste in the U.S. and abroad," Gordon said. "These guys pick it up. So their earnings and revenues are not cyclical."
Riding The Rails
The fund modestly added to its stake in Kansas City Southern (KSU) in December.
"These guys have a number of growth drivers," Gordon said. He cited growth of manufacturing in the U.S., transportation of crude oil and grain and an expected increase in transporting new cars.
"And if you look a couple years out, they should get business from plastics and ethylene factories being built in the U.S. as a result of low natural gas prices," he said.
The stock is up 42% over the past 12 months. It's tested its 10-week moving average line twice this month and hasn't been below the line since November.
Among other holdings, Gordon says FleetCor Technologies (FLT) has benefited from acquisitions.
"It buys poorly managed businesses that have big profit opportunities once FleetCor starts to manage them, often in faster growing international markets," Gordon said.
The provider and processor of payment cards for commercial vehicle fleets often does a better job of controlling costs and raising prices than its takeovers did for themselves, he adds.
The stock has eased 4% from its recent high, but remains above its 10-week moving average.
Chuy's Holdings (CHUY) debuted in July at 13. The Tex-Mex chain offers full-service dining. With bills averaging about $13 per customer vs. $16.50 for competitors, it attracts customers, Gordon says.
"They have a lot of unit growth potential," Gordon said. "They should grow units at about a 20% annual clip."
The fund was up 7.67% this year going into Tuesday. Its midcap growth rivals tracked by Morningstar Inc. averaged a 7.18% gain. The big-cap S&P 500 was up 9.51%.

Over the past three years Mid Cap Growth's average annual return was 10.14% vs. 9.63% for its peers and 10.96% for the S&P 500.Last fall, $1.2 billion MFS Mid Cap Growth Fund was willing to buy growth stocks with a little cyclicality.That play is done.
