Stocks from IBD's Sector Leaders screen all joined in Monday's broad sell-off, with Proto Labs (PRLB) sending a sell signal. Proto Labs shed 3.74, or more than 7%, to 46.41 in strong volume. The stock traded as much as 8% below its recent buy point at 49.78, tripping a key IBD sell rule for buyers at that level. This rule…

With the market uptrend now more than a month in length, the major indexes are at their best levels in months or, in the S&P 500's case, in four years.But the choppy action has made the environment tough. One thing investors can do to find leaders in a tough market is to look for those with strong relative strength lines. A few issues in this week's Your Weekly Review have RS lines at or near new highs and are still in buying range.Texas Capital Bancshares (TCBI) is about 2% past a 44.70 buy point from a three-weeks-tight pattern. Although the stock is near an all-time high, it hasn't done much since clearing the secondary buy setup Aug. 20.The stock has been in a solid uptrend since clearing a cup-with-handle base in December. Its 10-week moving average has contained the majority of the move.Last month, the regional bank beat expectations with a 73% surge in Q2 earnings. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters see profit rising 50% for the year.FleetCor Technologies (FLT) cleared a 41.40 trigger in a cup base Aug. 15 in more than twice its average trade. It's now about 4% past that trigger and within buying range up to 43.47.The fuel card provider's stock has nearly doubled after going public in December 2010, but it hasn't been a smooth ride. Last year, the stock went through a 36% correction. The correction in its latest base was half of that.Natural Grocers by Vitamin Cottage (NGVC) is just about 5% past a 20.58 buy point from an IPO base cleared Aug. 27. Its buying range extends to 21.61.The Lakewood, Colo.-based firm runs supermarkets that sell natural and organic foods and diet supplements in about 12 states.Natural Grocers had delivered triple-digit profit growth for three straight quarters. Analysts are expecting another this quarter.

The broad market's romp to new highs has obscured stumbles by some leading stocks.The major indexes' four-day winning streak, which struck new multiyear highs, sparked some standout volume. But volume also appeared on the downside the past few weeks, and the distribution day is getting awfully high.Meanwhile, a good number of IBD 50 stocks are falling hard.Prototype systems maker Proto Labs (PRLB) on Wednesday broke out past its 49.78 buy point from a consolidation. But the stock reversed lower the next day, surrendering all of a fat 6% gain. The stock fell further Friday, and closed below its trigger.Ocwen Financial (OCN), which services mortgage loans, sliced below its 50-day line with huge volume March 19 and has made just one attempt to regain it — unsuccessfully.U.S. Silica Holdings (SLCA) logged plenty of volume since peaking March 11. The stock reversed lower that day and went on to correct as much as 18% through April 5. The decline, sparked by news of a secondary offering, was halted at the stock's 10-week line.But this is the stock's third such test and, what's worse, has so far been unable to muster much of a bounce.Some top-rated stocks seem to be rising reluctantly.Flooring retailer Lumber Liquidators (LL) made its second test of its 10-week line two weeks ago. The stock has bounced some, but volume has been dismal.FleetCor Technologies (FLT), a provider of payment systems to commercial auto fleets and the oil industry, lurched to new highs last week.But the biggest volume surges seen in the past three weeks have been on the downside. FleetCor Technologies has tested its 10-week line three times since its mid-August breakout.Alaska Air Group (ALK) has yet to recover from its three-day sell-off April 1-3, which had cost the stock 10%. Volume soared in two of those sessions and has since calmed.Since breaking out of a cup-shaped base in late October, Alaska Air has provided entries through two three-weeks-tight patterns and two tests of its 10-week line. A third test would carry added risk, especially if the stock rushes the line with heavy volume.Biomed issue Medicines Co. (MDCO) reversed lower March 26, and has since drifted down to rest on its 50-day line.The bounce so far has been meager, as has the volume.

Stocks packed on more losses in late trading Wednesday, despite the Federal Reserve keeping its bond-buying program intact. Once again, the central bank stressed that it wanted to see more "sustained growth" before tapering.

The Nasdaq and the S&P 500 each dropped 0.7%. Meanwhile the Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.6%. Turnover was again tracking mixed in the stock market today. NYSE trade was running a tad higher and Nasdaq volume was trading a little lower.

AVG Technologies (AVG) gapped down and tumbled 11% after being cut to hold from buy at BWS Financial. The stock recently had a failed breakout past a 23.88 buy point in a flat base. AVG reports earnings Nov. 7. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters see the security software firm's profit rising 9% to 47 cents a share. That would be down from three prior quarters of double-digit growth.

But on the upside, Acadia Healthcare (ACHC) gapped up and bolted 9% to an all-time high after beating views. Before the open, the provider of psychiatric services reported a 76% jump in Q3 earnings and a 79% gain in revenue. The company also boosted its full-year profit outlook. Acadia cleared a 41.40 buy point from a six-week flat base.

Iconix Brand Group (ICON) rose 2% to a record high. On Tuesday, it cleared a 34.73 buy point from a seven-week flat base. Before the open, the marketer of Joe Boxer and London Fog delivered Q3 results above views and raised its full-year profit outlook. Iconix's sales grew 24% in the third quarter, the second straight period of acceleration.

The Nasdaq rose 1.2%, the S&P 500 gained 1.3% and the Dow Jones industrial average was up 1.5% in the stock market today. The market continued a recent pattern of dropping on rising volume and gaining on lighter volume.
U.S. employers added 223,000 jobs in April, confirming suspicions that sluggish growth in March was an anomaly. April job growth helped lower the unemployment rate to 5.4% from 5.5% in March.

Shoemaker Skechers (SKX)vaulted nearly 3% to an all-time high after Sterne Agree raised its price target on the stock to 111 from 90. The stock trades near 100, where it might find resistance caused by an even number. The stock is up more than 60% since it broke out of a base in January.

Stocks remained lower near the midpoint of Monday's session. But losses were again modest as stocks have already risen for the past few weeks.

The Nasdaq fell 0.4%, but heavyweight Apple (AAPL) rose 2% to an all-time high. The S&P 500 lost 0.3% and the Dow Jones industrial average gave up 0.2%. Turnover was again tracking sharply lower across the board.

Elli Mae (ELLI) tumbled 9% in fast trade and erased gains from the past three sessions. Despite the drop, the stock is still extended from a rebound off its 10-week line. Elli Mae broke out from a deep base in late February. The Pleasanton, Calif.-based firm provides mortgage origination services.

Mortgage service companies including Elli Mae and Nationstar Mortagage (NSM) have been red hot as the housing market recovers. Nationstar fell 2%. It staged a downside reversal in light volume Friday.

Elsewhere, Hibbett Sports (HIBB) fell 4% and fell back below its 50-day moving average. Raymond James downgraded the sporting goods retailer to market perform from outperform. On Friday, Hibbett fell more than 8% below a 62.03 flat base buy point after the retailer reported disappointing Q2 sales.

On the upside, FleetCor Technologies (FLT) was up 2% and hit a new high in heavy trading. It's now 4% past a 41.40 buy point from a cup base cleared Aug. 15. Stocks notched a solid open Tuesday, with tech and transportation stocks leading and energy and mining issues bringing up the rear.
The Nasdaq climbed 0.5%. The S&P 500 added 0.4% and the Dow Jones industrial average tacked on a 0.3% gain.
Volume was briskly mixed in the stock market today, up 28% on the Nasdaq and down 20% on the NYSE, the inverse of early trading action on Monday.

Air transport issues, led by FedEx (FDX) and United Parcel Service (UPS), notched the best early gains among the 197 industry groups tracked by IBD. Gold, coal and oil groups posted the five worst losses on the list.
The Commerce Department reported construction spending surged 1.1% in October. That reversed a revised 0.1% decline for September and easily outpaced economist expectations for a 0.5% increase.

Early stock action showedBiogen (BIIB) skipping up 5% after the company reported positive results from a phase 1b study of its Alzheimer's Treatment, and plans to aggressively move into a phase 3 trial. The gain lifted shares back above their converged 10- and 40-week moving averages, but left the stock still within a three-month consolidation.

Cypress Semiconductor (CY) powered up 17% and punched to a 16-month high after agreeing to be acquired by Sunnyvale, Calif.-based Spansion (CODE) in an all-stock deal valued at $4 billion. Cypress shares have been wallowing in a consolidation since mid-2013. Spansion shares fired ahead 24%, well into new highs.
Among leaders, Ambarella (AMBA) and Celgene (CELG) jumped to the front of the IBD list.

Ambarella popped 3% at the start of trade, retaking a portion of its 8% tumble taken on Monday. The video chip maker is trading 9% below Friday's high, and extended after a strong October rebound from 10-week support.

A sluggish economy is injecting austerity into household budgets. But shoppers are still willing to splurge on the right dash of colors and prints to brighten up a wardrobe. That's helped fashion boutique chain Francesca's Holdings (FRAN) lure in customers and attract another key demographic: institutional investors.
Francesca's is one of five companies on the elite IBD 50 list (No. 4 there) that is also on today's Screen of the Day, which highlights companies with Accelerating Mutual Fund Ownership.
Those and other large players are the ones driving prices higher when they buy in. They also can send shares tumbling when they get out.
Mutual fund interest in Francesca's has accelerated in the past three quarters, with 247 funds holding a stake in the boutique as of the last quarter.
The other IBD 50 stocks are:
FleetCor Technologies (FLT), No 13 on the IBD 50 list, offers gas cards and specialized payment services for commercial fleet vehicles. It ended the last quarter with 246 mutual funds on board.

Grand Canyon Education (LOPE), the for-profit operator of Grand Canyon University, is No. 25 on the IBD 50 list. Such educators have gotten a bad rap because of the federal grants they accept for students who often don't graduate. But Grand Canyon has put some of that concern behind it, setting aside money in the last quarter to cover grants that may need to be returned, and posting higher-than-expected quarterly results.
It had 246 mutual funds invested in it in the last quarter.

Israeli chip designer Mellanox Technologies (MLNX), No. 3 on the IBD 50 list, is riding the wave of cloud computing, data center buildouts and Big Data analytics. That's won it the attention of 195 different funds in the last quarter.

Mortgage origination processing software developer Ellie Mae (ELLI) signed on new lenders in the last quarter. And the No. 38 on the IBD 50 list leveraged those customers for higher revenue as mortgage applications came in above industry forecasts.

Funds are paying attention too. The stock had 133 of them invested in it the last quarter.A sluggish economy is injecting austerity into household budgets. The venture capital industry rang in the New Year by celebrating a fourth-quarter surge in initial public offerings by VC-backed startups, the most in nearly 10 years.
There were 32 such IPOs last quarter, the most since 89 in Q3 2000, the National Venture Capital Association said Monday.

The year ended with 72 venture-backed IPOs, the most since 86 in 2007. The venture industry, which funds the most promising startups, largely in technology industries, is trying to recover from hard times. There were just 12 IPOs in 2009 and six the year before, the two worst years since the mid-1970s.
The slow IPO market hurt the ability of VC firms to make money and to raise new funds. The fourth-quarter IPO boomlet provides hope.

"We're not where we'd like to be just yet, but things are certainly moving in the right direction," said NVCA President Mark Heesen. "I'm particularly optimistic about the 44 companies in registration."
These are companies that have filed to go public, but haven't done so yet. This number is up from just 25 at this time a year ago.
The 72 IPOs in 2010 raised $7 billion, more than four times the $1.6 billion raised in 2009. The 32 venture-backed IPOs in the fourth quarter raised $3.6 billion.
Similar VC-backed IPO figures were reported separately Monday by Dow Jones VentureSource.

"We're seeing a very strong start to the new year," said Jessica Canning, global research director at VentureSource. "It's very welcomed. It's been a while since we've had news this good. The past two years have been extremely difficult."
Of the IPOs last quarter, 20 were trading above their offering prices as of Dec. 31, said the NVCA. That indicates investors are warming back up to buying shares of startups.

China powered the surge, as 17 of the 32 U.S. IPOs in the quarter were China-based companies. They included the high-profile launch of Youku.com (YOKU), considered the YouTube of China, which rose 161% on its first day of trading. It went out at $12.80 a share and closed Monday at 35.55. Another was E-Commerce China Dang-dang (DANG), which soared 87% on its first day. It went out at $16 a share and closed Monday at 26.40.
Not all were winners, though. China online retailer Mecox Lane (MCOX) went out at $11 and closed Monday at 7.71, even after rising 4% on Monday.

The largest VC-backed IPO last quarter was FleetCor Technologies (FLT), a U.S.-based provider of credit card processing services. FleetCor raised $291 million with its Dec. 15 IPO. It went out at $23 a share and closed Monday at 30.47.

The number of mergers and acquisitions among VC-backed, privately held companies also rose. There were 120 such M&A deals in 2010, up from 92 the year before, says the NVCA. The disclosed value total was $18.3 billion, up from $13.6 billion in 2009.
The biggest deal in the quarter was in health care services, when HealthSpring paid $545 million to acquire Bravo Health.
"We're hoping to see a stable economy over the next several quarters and an improving stock market," NVCA's Heesen said.
One worry, he says, is that government stimulus money is running out at a time when city, state and federal budgets are expected to be cut.
"We could see significant budget cutting in next few quarters, and that will impact the economy," Heesen said.
Still, many say the outlook is good.
A recent poll of 50 attorneys who specialize in IPOs found that 77% anticipate a strong year for IPOs in 2011.
The survey by KCSA Strategic Communications was a marked change from a year ago, said KCSA CEO Jeff Corbin.

"The difference is like night and day," he said. "People are feeling more positive, issuers are active and companies are seeing success in their business, all leading to a more robust IPO environment."

In a separate poll released Monday by accounting and consulting firm BDO USA, 72 of 100 investment bank executives said they expect IPO activity to increase in 2011 over 2010. Of those, 24% said they expect the increase to be substantial, and they expect information technology to show the biggest jump.The venture capital industry rang in the New Year by celebrating a fourth-quarter surge in initial public offerings by VC-backed startups, the most in nearly 10 years.There were 32 such IPOs last quarter, the most since 89 in Q3 2000, the National Venture Capital Association said Monday.The year ended with 72 venture-backed IPOs, the most since 86 in 2007. Stocks continued to trade in narrowly mixed territory late Thursday.
The Nasdaq rose 0.3% and the S&P 500 eked out a 0.1% gain. Meanwhile, the Dow Jones industrial average was fractionally lower. Volume was again tracking lower across the board.

FleetCor Technologies (FLT) was off its session high, but still up 9% after topping views and raising guidance late Wednesday. The company earned 73 cents a share in the second quarter, up 28% from a year ago. It beat views by 8 cents. Sales climbed 28% to $171.8 million. Fleetcor now sees full-year profit coming in at $2.74 to $2.78 a share vs. views for $2.58 a share. The stock is in a cup base with a 41.40 buy point.

Express Scripts (ESRX) rose 3% to a new high in heavy trading. It's now 11% past a 56.30 buy point from a cup-with-handle base cleared July 13. However, that move lacked big volume. An investor could regard 59.08 — the left-side high plus 10 cents — as a more valid entry. The stock cleared that buy point in strong volume Wednesday and is 6% past the entry.

Late Tuesday, the pharmacy benefits manager beat analysts' expectations with a 24% rise in its Q2 earnings and a 144% pop in sales. The revenue surge was largely due to its buyout of Medco Health Solutions, completed in April. Management raised full-year EPS guidance to above consensus views.

Valspar (VAL) pushed its gain to 4% in heavy trading and climbed further north of its 50-day moving average barely regained Wednesday. The stock had fallen more than 8% from a 53.06 buy month earlier this month, but has been rebounding since. Valspar will report fiscal Q3 results Aug. 14. Analysts see the paint company's earnings rising 20% to 84 cents a share. Sales are slated to rise about 6% to $1.13 billion.

On the downside, Monster Beverage (MNST) was near its session low and down 8% after reporting disappointing Q2 results late Wednesday. The energy drink maker's second-quarter earnings came in at 59 cents a share, or 2 cents below views. Sales of $592.6 million missed expectations of $596.1 million. The company cited higher-than-expected costs in its international expansion efforts. Its gross margin slipped to 51.8% from 52.8% a year ago. The stock is now 26% off its April 30 peak.

SodaStream International (SODA) trimmed its loss to 1%, but looked to be on pace for its third straight loss. The stock had turned tail in the past two sessions. On Wednesday, the maker of home carbonation systems beat views with a 37% jump in Q2 earnings and a 49% gain in sales. SodaStream also raised its full-year growth forecast for profit and revenue. As the major indexes lost ground Tuesday, several stocks fought off the head winds and rose to new highs. For FleetCor Technologies (FLT), the positive action was especially reassuring. On Monday, the fuel-card provider retreated 1% in 135% faster than usual trade. Generally, bulls like to see declines come in quiet volume. On Tuesday, however, FleetCor surged 3% in volume…
Stocks showed modest gains in early-afternoon action Wednesday, erasing losses after upbeat comments from Washington about avoiding the fiscal cliff.

The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.5%, while the S&P 500 added 0.3%. The Nasdaq tacked on 0.2%, after being down nearly 1.1%. Volume was tracking up slightly from Tuesday's levels on both main exchanges.
House Speaker John Boehner said he was optimistic that Washington could make a deal to avoid the fiscal cliff, and President Obama said he hoped for an agreement before Christmas.

On the downside, Fresh Market (TFM) lost 13% in big turnover, though it had been down as much as 19%. The upscale grocery chain posted October-ended third-quarter earnings that missed forecasts, as well as a weaker-than-expected outlook. The stock had been consolidating along its 50-day moving average for about three months, but it's now plunged below that level and its 200-day moving average.

DaVita HealthCare Partners (DVA) fell 1% in big volume, undercutting its 50-day moving average. The stock, No. 48 in Wednesday's IBD 50 lineup, hasn't closed below that key support level since early September.

FleetCor Technologies (FLT) slid 2% in giant turnover, pulling back from an all-time high reached Tuesday. Late Tuesday, the provider of fuel cards for fleets announced a secondary offering of 4.5 million shares by certain selling shareholders, but also a concurrent stock buyback of up to 4 million shares. Before the open today, it said the offering and buyback were under way. FleetCor, No. 3 in the IBD 50, remains well extended past its last proper buy zone.

HDFC Bank (HDB) slumped less than 1% in strong trade. The Indian bank now stands about 2% beyond a 39.42 flat-base buy point that it cleared last week, after being as much as 8% beyond that level. HDFC is No. 11 in the latest IBD 50.

On the upside, some retail stocks are faring well. American Eagle Outfitters (AEO) surged 7% in heavy volume, coming back near its 50-day line. The clothing retailer said third-quarter earnings rose 37%, in line with views. Sales grew 11%, above forecasts. Management also guided full-year earnings expectations above estimates. American Eagle remains about 9% off its Oct. 18 high. It sports a so-so IBD Composite Rating of 76 out of the best-possible grade of 99.

In economic news, the Commerce Department reported October new-home sales that missed expectations. Earnings and revenue growth are key metrics for investors looking for top stocks to invest in.
Today's Screen Of The Day is Leaders with Rising Estimates: top-rated companies that analysts are raising earnings estimates on.
Here are the top six Rising Estimates equities ranked by expected EPS growth in the stock market today.
Topping the list is Evercore Partners (EVR), which provides advisory services on mergers, acquisitions, divestitures and the like. Consensus is that its EPS will spike 440% this quarter.
Evercore is a boutique investment bank that's filling a void left when many of the largest banks focused on mortgages and other services, leaving investment advice to companies like Evercore.
Its stock consolidated in the first half of 2012, bottomed at 20.57 intraday on July 27 and then began rising. It's since climbed 98% to 40.70 Thursday, up 0.7% for the day, at an all-time high.

LinkedIn (LNKD), the social network site for professionals, is projected to record 100% higher EPS for the quarter as it expands by providing career advice and bringing employees and employers together in an era of lingering high unemployment.
LinkedIn began trading on May 20, 2011 at 45 a share and closed Thursday at 168.18, up 274% since its IPO and down 0.2% for the day.

Michael Kors (KORS), which began trading in December 2011 at 20 a share, has met with tremendous acceptance. The luxury apparel, accessories and footwear retailer is forecast to report an 86% jump in EPS this quarter.
Kors turned heads when it reported a blowout holiday quarter on Feb. 12, which caused shares to gap up 8.8% for the day. Shares hit an all-time high 64.84 on Feb. 19, but have retreated a bit since.
Its share price has nearly tripled from its IPO to a 59.28 close Thursday, down 0.3% for the day.

Soufun Holdings (SFUN), a Chinese real estate marketing and listings company, is forecast for 53% higher EPS. It sports a hefty 7.1% dividend yield, which may or may not be attractive to investors, depending on investing strategy.
Like many U.S. counterparts, it's seen profit and sales grow at double- and triple-digit rates lately amid a hot real estate market.
After consolidating in early 2012, it stock began rising again on Aug. 1 and has since soared 145% to close at 26.85 Thursday, up 0.7% for the day.
FleetCor Technologies (FLT) provides specialized payment services to companies that operate commercial fleets, and is forecast to post a 37% EPS increase in EPS this quarter.
It's also No. 1 on the elite IBD 50 list of top-rated stocks. Earlier this month, it cruised past estimates, fueled by global expansion.

It's benefited from an improving economy as companies shipped more goods of all sorts. Shares more than doubled from a midsummer low 34.82 on July 23 to close at an all-time high 69.81 Thursday, up 2.3% for the day. It's trading well above its 50-day and 200-day averages.

TripAdvisor (TRIP), the travel information provider spun off of web travel site Expedia (EXPE) in December 2011, is also on the Leaders with Rising Estimates list. TripAdvisor is expected to report a 21% EPS rise this quarter.
After a post-IPO surge, shares began consolidating last July. It's formed a long cup or saucer-type base and closed up 0.6% Thursday, 7% off its all-time high 49.35, reached on Feb. 6.
Related:
LinkedIn, Celgene, ARM Among Top 5 Big Cap Leaders

The stock market showed no quit Thursday as buyers had the upper hand again. Tech stocks led again and the S&P 500 made a fresh high. Wall Street liked news that weekly jobless claims fell unexpectedly ahead of Friday's employment report. An interest rate cut in the eurozone also fueled positive sentiment. The Nasdaq had the leadership baton again, rising…
Stocks opened higher in steady trade Thursday.
The Nasdaq powered up 0.6% at the open. The S&P 500 added 0.3% and the Dow Jones industrial average put up a 0.3% gain.
The stock market today opened with volume up about 2% on both the NYSE and the Nasdaq compared with the same time Wednesday.
Leaders were in fervid motion: Tesla Motors (TSLA) dropped 10% and Keurig Green Mountain (GMCR) jumped 6% after reporting quarterly results.

Priceline (PCLN) slumped 4% in opening trade. The online travel megalith reported a huge Q1 earnings beat, but revenue just met expectations and management pared Q2 earnings guidance below views. The loss sent shares below their 40-week moving average for the first time since January 2013.

Avis Budget Group (CAR) jumped 4% after reporting better-than-expected first-quarter sales and earnings. The company raised full-year revenue and earnings guidance in line with expectations. The stock is near its April 17 high.

Solar City (SCTY) soared 13% after turning in a first-quarter loss of 26 cents, much better than the consensus forecast. Revenue sailed ahead 112%, also above views. The maker and installer of solar energy systems raised its full-year forecast for installations by about 5% and said it expects its installations to double in 2015.
The stock had corrected 48% in the past 10 weeks. Thursday's move sent shares to the top of the week's range, but shares remain deep in the correction.

Oil producer Gulfport Energy (GPOR) collapsed 19% following a narrow miss on first-quarter earnings and revenue. Management trimmed the range of its full-year production guidance by 26% to 30% as part of a strategic shift toward long-term value rather than near-term growth. The stock pierced its 10-week and 40-week moving averages.Stocks opened higher in steady trade Thursday.The Nasdaq powered up 0.6% at the open. Of several recent top-performers, only Visa and MasterCard resisted Thursday's stock market sell-off. Firms that have benefited from the housing rebound are among the leaders. So are small banks, boosted by warming GDP…

Despite a 6% loss in Walt Disney (DIS), which fell on disappointing earnings, the Dow Jones industrial average edged up a fraction. For the week, the Nasdaq dropped 2.6%, extending its losing streak to five weeks. The upside reversal wiped out Thursday's fall and then some. Sales grew 39% to $186.9 million, the largest in 10 periods. Stocks were mixed Monday afternoon, but have improved from the morning's sell-off. Techs continued to lead the pack. The Nasdaq rose 0.6% and regained its 50-day moving average. Apple (AAPL) and Amazon.com (AMZN) helped lift the tech-heavy index. The S&P 500 edged up 0.2% after bouncing back from a 0.5% loss. Meanwhile, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.1%, hurt…

Stocks made a fine step forward Thursday as investors reacted to a raft of economic news — both good and bad.
The Nasdaq rose 1%, the S&P 500 added 0.7% and the Dow Jones industrial average gained 0.6%. Volume increased 29% on the Nasdaq and 23% on the NYSE, according to preliminary data.

Economic data were mixed: New-home construction fell 1.1% to an annualized 746,000 units, a bit weaker than expected. But building permits, seen as a harbinger of future activity, rose to 812,000. That was a four-year high and better than expectations.
The Philadelphia Federal Reserve's manufacturing index fell to minus 7.1, also weaker than expected.
Did investors focus on the building-permits segment? It adds to a picture of a slow-but-improving recovery.
But some say the real boost Thursday came from the weak construction and Philadelphia reports.
How so? Evidence of slower-than-expected activity adds to the argument that the Fed should move ahead with another round of quantitative easing. In this way, bad news can be good news.

FleetCor Technologies (FLT) rose 2% in big trade, touching a new high and moving further past a 41.40 buy point from the cup-shaped consolidation it cleared Wednesday. The IBD 50 stock is about 3% past 41.40, meaning it's still within a possible buying range. FleetCor provides fleet-vehicle payment-processing services.

PetSmart (PETM) added 5% in strong turnover, clearing a flat base with an entry at 70.07. The specialty retailer is getting a lift from its better-than-expected quarterly earnings, reported late Wednesday. The stock, often featured in IBD's Income Investor column, has a strong IBD Composite Rating of 91 out of a highest-possible 99.

Cisco Systems (CSCO) shot up 10% in fast trade. Late Wednesday, the tech-sector bellwether posted fiscal fourth-quarter profit and revenue that squeaked past estimates. The company raised its dividend 75%, yielding better than 3% at Wednesday's close. The stock is climbing the right side of a 30% correction.

NetEase (NTES) swooned 15% after second-quarter sales and earnings, released late Wednesday, missed consensus estimates. The company cited a slowdown in subscribers for its online games. Advertising revenue rose 41% vs. Q1, while gaming revenue slipped 5%.

Dollar Tree (DLTR) ended the day off just 2% in three times its average volume. But the stock had plunged as much as 23% out of the gate. The discount retailer reported second-quarter earnings that beat forecasts. But revenue just matched expectations, and its Q3 targets disappointed. The stock traded well below its 200-day line before recovering, spoiling the flat base it was forming.

Facebook (FB) slid 6% in big turnover, touching a fresh all-time low. The lockup period on 271 million Facebook shares owned by insiders, who already sold some shares in the IPO, expired today, as noted in a story Wednesday on Investors.com. A sizable number of those shares is apparently being sold. Stocks coasted to a mixed finish Wednesday, with the tech-heavy Nasdaq leading the way.
The Nasdaq rose 0.5% and the S&P 500 added 0.1%, while the Dow Jones industrial average fell a fraction. Volume fell on both major exchanges, according to preliminary data.

FleetCor (FLT) surged 3% in fast turnover, hitting a new all-time high and clearing a 41.40 buy point from a cup pattern. The stock, No. 22 in Wednesday's IBD 50 lineup, is adding to its gains after climbing 13% last week on its strong quarterly earnings report. The Norcross, Ga.-based company provides payment processing services to commercial and government vehicle fleets, mainly for fuel purchases.

Dick's Sporting Goods (DKS) climbed 2% in moderately above-average volume, rebounding after finding support at its 50-day moving average. The sporting goods retailer lost 4% Tuesday after giving a full-year EPS target at the low end of Wall Street's expectations, even as its second-quarter results beat forecasts.
Dick's is also working to retake a 50.42 buy point from a cup-with-handle pattern. The stock was No. 39 in Monday's IBD 50 lineup, but didn't make the cut for Wednesday's list.

Francesca's Holdings (FRAN) moved up 4% in below-average volume, helped by Janney Montgomery Scott starting coverage with a buy rating and a 38 price target. The brokerage praised the clothing retailer's ability to drive high sales per square foot using a broad, shallow inventory approach, as well as its potential for 900 stores nationwide. Francesca's, No. 14 in the IBD 50, has been working to clear a 32.69 buy point from a cup-with-handle base.

Thinly traded Movado (MOV) climbed 6% after Capstone Investments initiated coverage with a buy rating and a 31 price target. The New Jersey-based watch designer is back above its 10-week average after correcting as much as 27% after a May peak.
Cisco Systems (CSCO), NetApp (NTAP), PetSmart (PETM) and Sina (SINA) were among the companies scheduled to report results after the close.
A raft of economic data, mostly positive, did little to advance the will-they-or-won't-they debate regarding Fed policymakers' decision on another round of quantitative easing.

Industrial production and capacity utilization rose more than expected in July, and builder sentiment gained for a fourth straight month. But New York region manufacturing unexpectedly contracted in August, as gauged by the New York Fed's Empire State Manufacturing Survey.Stocks coasted to a mixed finish Wednesday, with the tech-heavy Nasdaq leading the way. The Sector Leaders ended 2012 on a high note Monday, rising across the board amid signs that Washington was close to a deal to avert the fiscal cliff. But volume was weak in the pre-holiday session. FleetCor Technologies (FLT) and 3D Systems (DDD) jumped to new highs while Encore Capital Group (ECPG) ended just pennies short of a new peak.…

Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) rallied 0.95 to 59.03. It erased the bulk of Thursday's drop and nearly climbed back to a 59.10 buy point from a shallow double-bottom pattern. Young companies are flexible with innovative products and adaptive management, looking towards the future stock runs and not resting on past successes.The Young Guns Screen of the Day features stocks that that went public in the last 15 years, with strong fundamentals and stock performance.Young financial stocks have been rebounding on a mix of healthy signs such as an increase in merger-and-acquisition activity and a rebounding housing market.Evercore Partners (EVR) advises companies and manages private equity and venture capital funds for institutional investors. It advised General Motors (GM) on its restructuring and Burlington Northern, which was acquired last year by Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway (BRKA). The firm was founded in 1996 and made its IPO in 2006.Evercore's shares have doubled from the July low, closing at a new high of 41.97 in the stock market Tuesday.FleetCor Technologies (FLT), a provider of fuel cards for vehicle fleets, has been public since December 2010. The company's shares gapped up 11% on Feb. 8 after it reported a 46% in Q4 EPS to 82 cents, topping analyst estimates. Revenue climbed 45%, also beating views on lower wholesale fuel costs and its global expansion. The company guided Q1 earnings estimates above analyst views.Since the report, FleetCor shares have been climbing, closing at a new high of 72.07 in the stock market Tuesday.Everbank Financial (EVER), which debuted in May, offers innovative financial products such as foreign currency deposits in the U.S. insured by the FDIC.After reporting Q4 earnings Jan. 30, shares initially crashed 15% the following day before closing down less than 1%. The stock soon continued its consolidation. On Tuesday, shares rose 5% to 16.14, clearing a 4-month consolidation intraday.Another financial-related Young Gun is Verisk Analytics (VRSK), which provides risk-actuarial data for insurers. Shares shot up 8% Feb. 27 after reporting better-than-expected profit and accelerating revenue growth. The stock continued to set new closing highs, edging down 5 cents to 59.32 on Tuesday.Home Loan Servicing Solutions (HLSS) shares have risen steadily since its debut last February. The company acquires and services loans but doesn't originate them.Shares closed at a new high of 23.56 on Tuesday.Nationstar Mortgage Holdings (NSM), debuted in March 2012, taking a stake in the residential mortgage businesses that many larger banks abandoned after the financial crisis.Analysts expect the loan servicer to report Q4 earnings of 69 cents per share and revenue of $305.90 million when it announces results Thursday.Nationstar shares jumped 17% on Jan. 7 after the company announced it would acquire the servicing rights to $215 billion in residential mortgage loans from Bank of America (BAC). The stock tried to clear a short consolidation in mid-February but quickly reversed. Nationstar has risen for the past six sessions, including a 3% rise to 41.03.Related story: Homebuilders, Energy Plays Among Top Estimate Beaters

The 50-day moving average proved to be a friend to the Sector Leaders on Monday. FleetCor Technologies (FLT) continued to rebound from the line, while Lithia Motors (LAD) closed back above that key support level, and LinkedIn (LNKD) reversed higher after nearing its own 50-day line. FleetCor rose 1.86 to 75.30. The stock dipped below the 50-day average on Friday…
Rising Treasury bill rates and the ongoing budget impasse in Washington Tuesday sent investors scurrying for cover.
The Nasdaq, weighed by crashing tech stocks, slid 2%. The S&P 500 lost 1.2% and the S&P 500 dropped 1.1%
Volume surged in the stock market today: 47% on the Nasdaq and 32% on the NYSE, according to preliminary data.

LinkedIn (LNKD) slid 6% in 3-1/2 times its normal volume, putting it further south of its 50-day line, breached Monday. Intraday, the stock fell 8% below a 238.06 buy point from a rare short stroke pattern. That sets off IBD'S 8% sell rule.
Web.com Group (WWWW) swooned 10% in 3-1/2 times its usual trade, slicing below its 10-week line for the first time since April.
NQ Mobile (NQ) dived 7% in heavy volume. The May 2011 IPO had actually traded up to a 2% gain early in the session, far better than many had thought they'd see.

After Monday's close, NQ had announced a proposed offering of $150 million in convertible notes. That news crushed NQ in after-hours trade, so Tuesday morning's small gain was a surprise. But the gains didn't stick.

Other high-volume losers included networks solutions provider Infoblox (BLOX), off 3%, name-your-price travel website Priceline (PCLN) off 4%, Chinese real-estate listings and info website SouFun Holdings (SFUN) off 9%, social networker Facebook (FB) off 7%, Chinese search engines Baidu (BIDU) off 6% and Qihoo 360 Technology (QIHU) off 7%, and global payment systems provider FleetCor Technologies (FLT) off 6%.Rising Treasury bill rates and the ongoing budget impasse in Washington Tuesday sent investors scurrying for cover.The Nasdaq, weighed by crashing tech stocks, slid 2%. Stocks fought back Thursday as economic data mostly missed views and the shorts showed signs of adding to bearish bets. The Nasdaq eased 0.1% after being down 1% in midmorning trade. The S&P 500 slipped less than 0.2%. However, the NYSE composite sank 0.5%. Volume rose on the NYSE (1), giving the composite a fifth distribution day. That's an uncomfortably…
A few financial stocks, such as Visa (V) and FleetCor (FLT), have emerged as sound market leaders. But many others also are performing well and are giving the sector a boost.
About 15 financial stocks are in today's Your Weekly Review, representing one of the largest concentrations of stocks in the screen.
Two years ago, financials were about to begin an eight-month slide as they faced the aftershocks of the 2008 financial crisis and the risks of the eurozone's debt problems.
The sector has been recovering since its 2011 lows and it's off to a good start in 2013, up about 7% so far.
The housing recovery has spread to mortgage stocks, and a few specialty financial companies have rallied.

FleetCor, a payment-card company that caters to fleets and oil companies, has cruised to new highs since a breakout on Aug. 15. Shares are up more than 40% from their 41.40 buy point and have flashed not even a hint of a sell signal.
Regional banks have been improving since last year.

Viewpoint Financial (VPFG) is forming a cup-with-handle base with a possible buy point at 22.02. The Dallas-area bank's earnings increased 60% and 88% the past two quarters. But, like most regional banks, Viewpoint is thinly traded.
Among foreign banks, Grupo Financiero Santander Mexico (BSMX) is finding support at its 10-week moving average.
The company, which went public in September on the NYSE, posted earnings gains of 5%, 32% and 14% in the past three quarters. Yet, it has a solid Composite Rating of 96.
Peru-based Credicorp (BAP) and India's Icici Bank (IBN) are extended from their breakouts in November and December, respectively.

Bofi Holdings (BOFI), an online bank holding company, broke out at the start of the year. Shares of the thinly traded stock are 5% above their 28.54 buy point. Another reasonable buy point was 28.10 from a handle.A few financial stocks, such as Visa (V) and FleetCor (FLT), have emerged as sound market leaders. The top stocks from IBD's 33 sectors rose across the board in mixed volume Thursday. Many hit new highs and are extended from buy points. Financial Engines (FNGN) rose for the sixth straight session, climbing 0.61 to a fresh high of 32.44 in volume that was 87% above normal. The stock is 32% above a 24.60 buy point from a…

Mutual funds and other big institutional buyers have the financial muscle to move stocks. They also can spend heavily on research to try to find the best investments. So investors should take notice when top growth stocks enjoy growing fund sponsorship.IBD's Accelerating Mutual Fund Ownership Screen Of The Day ranks companies with accelerating mutual fund ownership over the past three quarters.Here are the top five companies:FleetCor Technologies (FLT), a provider of fuel cards for vehicle fleets, leads the screen with 299 funds owning stakes in the company. FleetCor is a relatively new traded company, it began trading on the NYSE in December 2010, but has posted steady growth since its debut.The company reported a 46% rise in EPS on Feb. 8, sending shares soaring 11%. FleetCor is bullish on the future, guiding its Q1 earnings estimates above analyst views.FleetCor shares have been on the uptick since the earnings report, closing at a new high of 72.25 in the stock market Wednesday. Shares fell 3% in the stock market Thursday after the company announced it would sell 4.5 million shares on behalf of shareholders.Dunkin' Brands (DNKN) is No. 2 with ownership by 298 mutual funds. On Jan. 31 the doughnut and ice cream shop operator's share spiked up 11% on a positive earnings report.In February the company announced plans to expand its Dunkin' Donuts coffee and doughnut shops to California.While coffee, doughnuts and ice cream have been simple pleasures for a long time, Dunkin' Brands is embracing the latest technology and customers can now load gift cards for its shops into Apple 's (AAPL) Passport smartphone app.Shares fell 2 cents to 38.07 Thursday.The Manitowoc Co. (MTW) has 295 funds, placing it at No. 3. It's a diversified equipment maker, but its cranes have been in demand as the housing market revives. It leads the Machinery-Construction/ Mining group with a Composite Rating of 88. IBD's Composite Rating rates stocks in five areas, with extra weight on earnings and stock price strength.Shares rose 7 cents to 19.13 Thursday as it hovers near a two-year high set in mid-February.The Russian online search engine Yandex (YNDX) has 295 funds as well. The Internet is ever expanding and foreign firms like Yandex and China's Baidu (BIDU) have popped up as competition to the Google (GOOG).But last month Yandex reported mixed Q4 results and warned on slowing sales growth for the year, sending shares falling 10% below its 50-day line.Shares have since rebounded above its 50-day, closing at 24.42 on Thursday.Delek U.S. Holdings (DK) rounds out the top five with 291 funds. Late Wednesday, the refinery reported Q4 EPS of $1.10 up from a loss of 10 cents per share a year ago. Revenue jumped 9% to $2.18 billion, well above Wall Street analyst expectations. The company, like many of its peers, was able to widen margins on cheap shale oil from Texas.Shares fell 9 cents to 38.92 on Thursday, Delek's third straight modest loss from an all-time closing high.Related:4 Best Tech Stocks Based On Long-Term FundamentalsFleetCor, Nationstar Among Top 6 Financial Young Guns

The finance sector is producing top performers in diverse areas. And analysts say several still have legs.The broad sector has been catapulted by the Finance/Mortgage & Related Services industry group.That group has been ranked No. 1 among IBD's 197 industry groups for weeks.The finance sector is getting strength from other groups such as Finance-Investment Management. It's in the top 20, up from No. 74 seven months ago. Another is Finance-Investment Banks/Bankers, near 50, up from 141.A third is Finance-Credit Cards/Payment Processing, which is hovering near 50.A lot of the sector's thrust comes from mutual funds. In its latest disclosure, $84.7 billion Fidelity Contrafund added to its stake in Visa (V). The $596 million Wells Fargo Advantage Enterprise opened a position in Affiliated Managers Group (AMG). The $244 million American Century Small Company started a stake in NetSpend Holdings (NTSP).Visa is surfing the transition to electronic payment from cash and checks. It has also benefited from waning investor fears over impact of the Durbin Amendment. That law limits debit-card swipe fees.Visa's share of the debit-card market fell. "The law didn't impact Visa as much as investors feared," said Sterne Agee analyst Greg Smith.Visa also has an initial settlement of a large merchants' lawsuit over alleged antitrust actions related to credit card transaction fees.Half the world pays for goods and service in cash, Smith noted. "So the emergence of middle classes in those countries will likely benefit Visa and MasterCard (MA)," he added.Debt-Card DynamoNetSpend, which provides reloadable prepaid debit cards, went public at 11 in 2010, peaked above 16 and troughed below 4 in 2011.Regulatory issues prevented it from adding new customers, Smith says. The company has solved much of that, diversified its bank partners and is adding customers.It has expanded sales by selling cards through retailers, with recent deals with 7-11, Safeway (SWY) and some dollar stores."We expect acceleration in revenues and earnings growth next year," Smith said.Affiliated Managers has been driven by a shift in its business model, says Morningstar Inc. analyst Greggory Warren. The firm used to rely solely on taking equity stakes in one boutique money manager after another. Now Affiliated has developed a global distribution network. Its affiliates grow revenue and earnings by expanding their sales."As long as they have performance and products investors want — which is emerging markets funds and alternative investment vehicles — there's no reason to think they can't keep this up," Warren said.Affiliated's assets under management have grown about 8% this year, he said, vs. contraction for the industry.Daniel Kraninger, a manager of $56 million CAN SLIM Select Growth , likes FleetCor Technologies ' (FLT) earnings growth. Mutual fund sponsorship has grown for the processor of truck fleet fuel payments. And on Nov. 27, it hit an all-time high on above-average volume.

Most sector-leading stocks fell Wednesday as the major averages ended mixed. SodaStream's  (SODA) rally fizzled in high volume, but FleetCor (FLT) approached a new high. FleetCor, which provides fuel cards to commercial vehicle fleets, rose 78 cents to 52.45, closing a shade below its high of 52.87 hit on Nov. 27. The stock is well beyond a 41.40 cup-base…

Polaris Industries (PII) and 3D Systems (DDD) led the sector-leading stocks lower Monday. But SodaStream (SODA) rose for the fifth straight session as it tries to climb out of a deep consolidation. Polaris, a maker of all-terrain vehicles, closed below its 50-day line after sinking 2.85, or 3%, to 81.96. Volume was 72% above normal. It was Polaris' second straight…
Stocks continued to improve near midday Friday following the earlier release of better-than-expected consumer sentiment. Overall, equities are bouncing back from two days of big losses.

The Nasdaq led with a 0.7% gain, thanks in part to heavyweights Apple (AAPL), Amazon.com (AMZN) and Google (GOOG). The S&P 500 rose 0.5% and regained its 200-day line. Meanwhile, the Dow Jones industrial average climbed 0.3%. Turnover was running higher across the board, especially on the Nasdaq.

FleetCor Technologies (FLT) gapped up and rose as much as 7% before trimming its gain to 4%. Late Thursday, the provider of fuel cards and other payment products easily beat expectations with Q3 earnings that jumped 48% to 83 cents a share — the biggest gain in seven quarters. Sales grew 39% to $186.9 million, the largest in 10 periods. The company also raised its outlook for full-year profit and revenue.
Beacon Supply (BECN) erased earlier losses and climbed 3% in fast trade. The upside reversal also wiped out Thursday's drop and then some. Beacon revisited a 30.90 flat base buy point intraday.

MDC Holdings (MDC) extended recent losses, falling 5% to a three-month low. The stock cleared a 41.39 buy point in a flat base Nov. 1, but triggered the 8% sell rule just one day later. The homebuilder recently reported Q3 earnings that beat views, but sales missed expectations.

Jazz Pharmaceuticals (JAZZ) shaved a large chunk of its early losses, but was still down 3% in heavy trading. The drugmaker slumped as much as 11% intraday in reaction to late Thursday's disappointing Q3 earnings and sales. Jazz bounced back after finding support near its 200-day line.Stocks continued to improve near midday Friday following the earlier release of better-than-expected consumer sentiment. The market uptrend continued on its merry way Friday. Stocks were poised to end the week with solid gains with about one hour left in the session.
The Nasdaq gained 1.1% while the S&P and the Dow Jones industrial average added 1% each. Volume on the Nasdaq and NYSE was tracking about 4% higher than Thursday.

In the stock market today, FleetCor Technologies (FLT) surged 4% in more than double its average volume. Late Thursday, the company reported another stellar quarter of growth, with profit and sales handily beating expectations. The provider of fuel cards to fleets also raised its full-year earnings outlook. However, FleetCor has run up too much to consider buying at current levels. Its last base breakout was all the way back in August.

Meanwhile, investment manager BlackRock (BLK) gapped up, rising 3%. It's not ideal to see a stock hit new highs in light volume, but that's exactly what Blackrock's been doing in recent days. Group peer Apollo Investment Management (APO) reports earnings on Monday.
Elsewhere, 3-D printing firms continued to work on the right sides of potential bases. Stratasys (SSYS) and 3D Systems (DDD) were on pace for solid weekly gains in higher volume. Both stocks rose 3%.

TripAdvisor (TRIP) hit a 52-week high ahead of its earnings report next week. Shares rose nearly 4%. Volume was slightly above average. Earnings are due Tuesday after the close. The online travel firm is expected to report profit of 46 cents a share, up 21% from a year ago, with sales up 22% to $223.8 million.

In economic news, Wall Street breathed a sigh of relief on news the economy created 165,000 jobs in April, slightly ahead of expectations. The unemployment rate ticked lower to 7.5%. Big upward revisions to February and March job growth were also welcomed by the market.
At the New York Mercantile Exchange, June gold settled at $1,464.20 an ounce, up $3.40. For the week, it rose 0.7%. June oil ended at $95.61 a barrel, up $1.62. For the week, oil rose nearly 3%.
Earnings season is winding down, but next week's docket is still busy. Here's a look at some interesting names set to report.
Monday: Apollo Global Management (APO), Chuy's Holdings (CHUY), First Solar (FSLR), MercadoLibre (MELI).

The $1 billion Nuveen Mid Cap Growth Opportunities Fund is notching a nice, though not spectacular, return for shareholders. It has not outperformed both its midcap growth peers and the S&P 500 since the first quarter. But it topped its direct rivals in Q2. It was close in Q3. And its Q1 outperformance was large. So for the whole year…
Stocks drove higher in strong trade at Friday's open, as stronger than expected April jobs data trumped soft readings on factory orders and service-sector growth.
The Nasdaq rumbled ahead 1.2% in a 24% rise in volume. The S&P 500 climbed 1.1% and the Dow Jones industrial average jumped 1%. Volume on the NYSE rose 4% above the levels at the same time Thursday.
Caterpillar (CAT) gained 3% to lead the Dow. Gilead Sciences (GILD) was out in front of the Nasdaq 100, with a 5% advance.
The stock market today received a solid send-off from an April payrolls report that topped expectations by a wide margin and shifted the unemployment rate a notch lower, to 7.5%.

But factory orders slipped 4% in March, below February's downwardly revised 1.9% gain and the gauge's biggest decline since August, the Commerce Department reported. It was also a much deeper cut than the 2.8% drop expected.
In April, growth in the service portion of the economy slowed, sending the Institute of Supply Management's service index to 53.1, down from 54.4 in March and missing expectations for 54.
Some stocks moved dramatically higher and lower as earnings reports continued to roll in.

Trucking fleet and logistics operator YRC Worldwide (YRCW) sailed ahead 43% after reporting a loss of half what analysts forecast for the first quarter. The move lifted the stock just above 10, leaving it still far below its March 2005 high.

Among leaders, FleetCor Technologies (FLT) initially topped the IBD 50 list with a 10% surge, then pared its gain to 3%. The provider of fuel credit systems for vehicle fleets reported a 50% jump in earnings and a 32% sales gain in the first quarter, both better than views.
The move vaulted the stock to a new high and the top of its buying range after a rebound from the 10-week moving average.

Bonanza Creek Energy (BCEI) leapt 6% at the open, retaking its 50-day moving average in strong trade. The Denver based shale oil producer has climbed the past two weeks off the bottom of a possible base begun in March.
United Rentals (URI) gapped up to a 6% gain, putting shares back above the 50-day line as it tries to form a new base.
OpenTable (OPEN) grabbed a 4% gain, moving back above its 50-day moving average. The online restaurant reservation service is in its fifth week of a possible base.
The market also saw steep losses, led by low-rated stocks like Vocera (VCRA), Zagg (ZAGG), Teradata (TDC) and Arena Pharmaceuticals (ARNA).

In commodities, oil prices jumped more than 1%, to above $95 a barrel, after the morning's job report. Gold slumped a fraction to trade above $1,466 an ounce. The online restaurant reservation service is in its fifth week of a possible base.The market also saw steep losses, led by low-rated stocks like Vocera (VCRA), Zagg (ZAGG), Teradata (TDC) and Arena Pharmaceuticals (ARNA).In commodities, oil prices jumped more than 1%, to above $95 a barrel, after the morning's job report. Gold slumped a fraction to trade above $1,466 an ounce. Natural gas and corn were steady.

Selling accelerated into the close and stocks ended near lows as investors weighed weak jobs data from ADP, an in-line reading from the Institute for Supply Management Manufacturing index and a Fed statement that revealed lingering concerns about the health of the U.S. economy.
At the close, the Dow Jones industrial average, S&P 500 and Nasdaq each lost 0.9%. Preliminary data showed NYSE and Nasdaq volume coming in slightly lower than Tuesday.

After the close, Visa (V) reported better-than-expected bottom-line and top-line growth. First-quarter profit came in at $1.92 a share, up 20% from a year ago. Sales rose 15% to $2.96 billion. Analysts expected earnings of $1.81 a share with sales of $2.85 billion. Shares popped 2% in early after-hours trading. Competitor MasterCard (MA) fell 2% during the regular session on disappointing earnings.

Meanwhile, first-quarter profit at Facebook (FB) was flat from a year ago at 12 cents a share. The results missed views by a penny. Sales rose 38% to $1.46 billion, slightly ahead of views. Mobile ads made up 30% of total advertising revenue in the quarter, up 23% from a year ago.

Also in the after-hours session, shares of Las Vegas Sands (LVS) rose nearly 2% after the casino operator reported profit of 71 cents a share, up 1% from a year ago but 4 cents above the consensus estimate. Sales were in line at $3.3 billion, up 20%.

In economic news, investors were spooked by sluggish jobs data from ADP. The payroll processor said the economy added 119,000 private-sector jobs in April, below expectations for 155,000. ADP's report comes ahead of Friday's jobs report.

Meanwhile, after Tuesday's weaker-than-expected reading for the Chicago Purchasing Managers Index, investors worried about a similarly weak reading from the ISM Manufacturing Index. The index came in at 50.7 for April, down from 51.3 in March, but mostly in line with expectations.

When it comes to the Fed statement released earlier today, there wasn't a whole lot new. Clearly, policymakers remain concerned about the health of the U.S. economy. Some observers said the biggest change was the central bank hinting at an increase in its asset purchases, if necessary.

In the stock market today, shares of Apple (AAPL) lost 0.8% in average volume. According to new data from IDC, tablet sales more than doubled in the first quarter to 49.2 million units. Apple's market share dropped to 39.6% from 58.1% a year ago. Samsung's share increased to 17.9% from 11.3%.

LinkedIn (LNKD) strengthened late in the session ahead of its report Thursday after the close. Shares ended at 194.82, up 1%. Earnings are seen rising 107% to 31 cents a share with sales up 68% to $317.1 million

At the New York Mercantile Exchange, June gold settled at $1,446.20 an ounce, down $25.90. After the Fed statement was released, gold traded up to $1,454.80. June oil, meanwhile, ended at $91.03 a barrel, down $2.43, or 2.6%.
Before the open Thursday, watch for earnings reports from Catamaran (CTRX), Church & Dwight (CHD), Cigna (CI) and Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX).

Stocks packed on more losses in late trading Thursday, with techs leading the downside action. The Nasdaq swooned 1.1%. Heavyweights Apple (AAPL), Google (GOOG) and Amazon.com (AMZN) were all lower. Meanwhile, the S&P 500 slumped 0.8% and the Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.6%. Turnover was again tracking sharply lower on both major exchanges. Michael Kors (KORS) stretched its loss…

As a general rule for successful investing, the biggest stock winners tend to have superior fundamental and technical factors. IBD put together five key criteria, including earnings and share price performance, into an overall Composite Rating from 1 to 99. A high Composite Rating isn't a buy signal. Investors need to take a close look at the actual fundamental and…

Stocks were holding near their session highs late Monday, on pace for a third straight gain.Thanks in part to Apple  (AAPL) and Facebook (FB), the Nasdaq composite continued to outshine with a 0.6% gain. Meanwhile, the Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 edged up 0.1% each. Volume was running sharply lower across the board in the stock market today .

3D Systems  (DDD) gapped up and bolted 10% to a record high in big volume. It cleared a 51.55 early entry from a long consolidation. Citigroup started coverage of the 3D printer maker with a buy rating.
Rival Stratasys (SSYS) also got a buy rating from Citigroup. It gapped up and rallied 6% to an all-time high. The lift puts its 18% past a 95 buy point from a late-stage base.

FleetCor Technologies  (FLT) climbed 5% to a record high. It’s now 6% past a 100.97 buy point from a three-weeks-tight pattern cleared Aug. 22. On the downside, Ambarella (AMBA) slumped 9% after giving up earlier gains.

But the October IPO is getting close to potential support at its 200-day moving average. Shares of the chip designer appeared to be under pressure due to a negative Seeking Alpha article, which says that it might miss analysts’ earnings estimates.Stocks were holding near their session highs late Monday, on pace for a third straight gain.Thanks in part to Apple  (AAPL) and Facebook (FB), the Nasdaq composite continued to outshine with a 0.6% gain. But the October IPO is getting close to potential support at its 200-day moving average. Shares of the chip designer appeared to be under pressure due to a negative Seeking Alpha article, which says that it might miss analysts’ earnings estimates.
Stocks were back near the session's worst levels after rebound efforts weakened.
The Dow Jones industrial average shed 0.8%, while the Nasdaq and S&P 500 lost 0.7% each. Turnover was again running mixed with NYSE higher and Nasdaq lower.

Big Lots (BIG) extended its loss to nearly 23%. The closeout goods retailer had gapped vastly lower on disappointing Q2 results and a lowered outlook. Fellow deep discounters Dollar Tree (DLTR), Dollar General (DLTR) and Family Dollar (FDO) were off their session lows, but still down about 1% each.

Better-than-expected new-home sales data for July on Thursday failed to lift Nationstar Mortgage Holdings (NSM). It fell 3% in fast trade and was on pace for its fifth straight loss. Nationstar has now erased all of last week's 10% advance, but remains well above its fast-rising 50-day moving average.

FleetCor Technologies (FLT) was off its session low, but still down 2%. Earlier, the stock nearly retested a 41.40 buy point from a cup base. The stock broke out Aug. 15 in more than twice its average trade. FleetCor provides fuel cards to the government and private sector. The firm recently beat views with Q2 earnings that rose 28% and raised its full-year profit outlook.

On the upside, Cirrus Logic (CRUS) rallied 5% to its best levels since November of 2000. Barclays Capital started coverage of the chip designer at overweight. Cirrus is well extended after gapping out of a short consolidation in late July. Cirrus designs chips for Apple's (AAPL) products.

Synopsys (SNPS) pulled back, but was still up 5% in heavy trading. Earlier, the stock gapped up to an eight-year high on better-than-expected fiscal Q3 results from late Wednesday. The software firm's earnings rose 20% to 55 cents a share or 5 cents above views. Sales grew 15% to $443.8 million, a hair shy of expectations. The company pegged full-year profit at $2.09 to $2.11 per share vs. the consensus view of $2.07 a share. Most stocks from IBD's Sector Leaders screen rose Friday in above-average volume, with 3D Systems (DDD) and several others hovering near new highs. Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX), the top medical stock, was the only decliner. The drugmaker edged down 0.36 to 60.71 in double its average daily volume. It had fallen sharply intraday but managed to rebound to finish in the…

Stocks sold off late after Secretary of State John Kerry commented on the situation in Syria, saying there’s no doubt the Syrian government used chemical weapons against rebels. Kerry also said Syria’s decision to allow United Nations inspectors came too late.

The Nasdaq Composite ended at 3657, down fractionally, after rising as much as 0.7% earlier in the session. The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 each lost 0.4%. Preliminary data showed NYSE and Nasdaq volume coming in lower than Friday.
After the close, shares of J.C. Penney (JCP) fell 3% on news hedge fund manager Bill Ackman is selling his entire stake in the company. He resigned from J.C. Penney’s board about two weeks ago.

In the stock market today, Amgen  (AMGN) fueled a biotech rally on news it’s acquiring Onyx Pharmaceuticals (ONXX) for 125 a share, or just over $10 billion. Onyx turned down an offer in June from Amgen for 120 a share. Shares of Amgen jumped 8%. Onyx rose 6%.

Also in the biotech space, Celgene (CELG) picked up 2%. It continues to trade well after a recent bounce off its 10-week moving average but it’s extended in price. And group peer Gilead Sciences  (GILD) added 1%. It’s now 4% above a recent buy point of 58.16.

Notable gainers included 3D Systems (DDD). Shares jumped 7% in heavy trade after Citi initiated coverage with a buy rating. It cleared a late-stage, base-on-base pattern with a buy point of 52.04. Group peer Stratasys (SSYS), meanwhile, also got a buy rating from Citi. Shares rose 4%.

FleetCor Technologies  (FLT) and Netflix  (NFLX) hit fresh all-time highs. Both stocks rose 2%. FleetCor is now extended 4% after clearing a three-weeks-tight pattern last week. The buy point was 100.97. And Netflix is extended 14% after a recent base breakout over 248.95.

No notable earnings reports after the close today, but on Tuesday, watch for earnings from new issue Workday (WDAY). The enterprise software firm went public in October at 28 and has more than doubled in price. Shares rose fractionally ahead of the results. Workday isn’t profitable yet but shows strong revenue growth in recent quarters.

Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect a loss of 18 cents a share. Sales are seen rising 60% from the year-ago quarter to $100.5 million.Stocks sold off late after Secretary of State John Kerry commented on the situation in Syria, saying there’s no doubt the Syrian government used chemical weapons against rebels. Big-block trades of thousands and tens of thousands of shares of stock by mutual funds and other big institutions are a powerful force that collectively moves the market up or down. NetSuite (N), Chemtura (CHMT) and FleetCor Technologies (FLT) are among the leading stocks that mutual funds are accumulating. Today's Screen Of The Day is Accelerating Mutual Fund Ownership. Companies…

Citigroup (C) shares shot up 9% in the latest week as the banking giant announced big job cuts as part of a new restructuring. Bank of America (BAC) leapt 8% to its best level since mid-2011. Yet while Citi, BofA and other Wall Street titans had a good week, their profitability remains a real question amid a sluggish global economy…

Most leading stocks finished lower in mixed volume Friday as 3D Systems (DDD) sank for a second day. But FleetCor Technologies (FLT) reversed higher. FleetCor rose 0.60 to 52.19 in triple its average daily volume, ending a mild two-day slide. The stock had been down as much as 2% intraday before staging a late rally and closing at the upper…

Sector Leaders recorded an odd session Thursday: Price leaders were volume laggards, while price losers saw the most trade. The opposite would be preferable. Financial Engines (FNGN) rose 0.43 to 26.41, and SodaStream (SODA) added 0.37 to 38.65. Neither of these leaders could muster even average volume. Financial Engines is 7% past its 24.60 entry from a saucer with handle,…

With many players absent from Friday's half-day session, most Sector Leaders performed like the broad market, moving up with much-decreased volume. Polaris Industries (PII) climbed above its 50-day line, adding 1.32, or 2%, to 84.02 in less than half its usual volume. The stock recorded its sixth-straight win, regaining a good chunk of ground lost in the prior six sessions,…

Stocks closed narrowly mixed Monday amid continuing concerns about the so-called fiscal cliff, a package of deep spending cuts and tax hikes due to take effect Jan. 1. The S&P 500 edged up a fraction while the Nasdaq ticked down and the Dow Jones industrial average ended flat. The major averages had been up slightly in afternoon trading. Volume was…

The number of new 52-week highs sharply dropped Wednesday, as the general market fell hard from multiyear highs etched the prior day. Although many leaders hit new peaks, the market's weight caused some to close poorly and others to reverse lower. Grand Canyon Education (LOPE) climbed as much as 6% in reaction to its better-than-expected Q4 results announced late Tuesday,…
The major indexes remained positive for the week, but edged lower near midday Friday in dwindling trade.
The Dow Jones industrial average dipped 0.4%, despite strong gains by Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) and DuPont (DD). The S&P 500 shed 0.3%. The Nasdaq held to a 0.2% loss.

Trade weakened in the stock market today, with volume slipping 1% on the Nasdaq and down 16% on the NYSE. A raft of weak economic news dented optimism early in the session. Only one in five industry groups moved higher in morning trade.

In stocks, Toyota Motor (TM) defended the 3% gain that followed its second-quarter report late Thursday. ValueClick (VCLK) continued to hold one of the morning's worst losses, down 16% after reporting second quarter results.
The IBD 50 index headed into Friday with a 2.3% gain so far for the week, and leading stocks continued the strong performance.

MercadoLibre (MELI) surged 10% to breakout above a cup base. LinkedIn (LNKD) jumped 9% and took out a new high. YY (YY) tacked on a 7% gain, adding to its already extended run in a fifth straight week of steep gains.

FleetCor Technologies (FLT) swept ahead 6% after reporting late Thursday its second-quarter revenue and earnings comfortably cleared analyst views. The fleet fuel financing specialist raised full-year earnings guidance above expectations, and offered revenue guidance in line with views.
The big-volume move hoisted the IBD 50 stock more than 9% above an 89.85 buy point in a flat base.

Web.com Group (WWWW) muscled up 3% in heavy trade, adding a second strong-volume session to the IBD 50 stock's rebound from 50-day support. The website design and services provider turned in better-than-expected Q2 sales and earnings results.

Beyond the IBD 50 list, drug maker Mylan (MYL) climbed 7% after narrowly beating analyst sales and earnings forecasts for the second quarter. Stocks sat on moderate losses in late morning action, after the dollar and some disappointing economic data set the tone of the morning's trade.The Nasdaq and the Dow Jones industrial average had drilled down 0.9%. The S&P 500 stumbled 0.8%. Disppointing weekly jobs data and a weaker-than-expected read on Q4 productivity soured early trade in the stock market today. A sharp drop in the euro vs. the dollar appeared to worsen the mood, following earlier statements from European Central Bank President Mario Draghi.Losses were broad, with nearly nine in 10 industry groups losing ground. Trading firmed through the morning and was slightly higher on both the Nasdaq and the NYSE, compared to action at midday Wednesday.In stocks, for-profit educators posted some of the morning's strongest moves.DeVry (DV) scorched out a 21% gain on stronger than expected earnings and an uptick in enrollments in some segments during its most recent term.Grand Canyon Education (LOPE) aced a 4% gain, boosting it just past a 25 buy point in a flat base. Grand Canyon plans to report results after the market close on Feb. 19.ExOne (XONE) rocketed 47% in its debut session. The new entrant to the 3D printer market priced at $18, opened at 23.90 and quickly spiked to 25.60. The company offered 5.3 million shares.On the IBD 50 list, SodaStream International (SODA), Stratasys (SSYS) and Western Digital (WDC) all slipped 3%.Grain and oilseed processing giant Bunge (BG) dropped 9% in massive trade. The White Plains, N.Y.-based company said adjusted fourth-quarter earnings fell 65%, well below consensus views for a 43% gain. Revenue increased 9% to $17.04 billion, missing projections for a 14% gain. The company also announced CEO Alberto Weisser would retire June 1. It named Soren Schroder, CEO of Bunge North America, to take over the top job.The move drove Bunge's shares back below a 73.58 buy point in a flat base, and below their 50-day line of support.The Federal Reserve plans to serve up December consumer credit data at 3 p.m. ET. The market looks toward another busy after-hours session, with Athenahealth (ATHN), Molina Healthcare (MOH) and CoinStar (CSTR), as well as IBD 50 stocks Fleetcor Technologies (FLT) and OpenTable (OPEN), among the companies slated to report after the close.

What financial crisis? The credit crunch obliterated financial stocks for a long time. But with housing in recovery and credit conditions improving, financial services stocks are rich in IBD's Bolting RS Lines Screen Of The Day. The Relative Strength line tracks a stock's performance vs. the S&P 500 index. In a confirmed rally, as now, laggard stocks may advance, but…
Stocks hung on to broad gains in mixed trade near midday Thursday, as the Nasdaq, Dow and S&P 500 all moved to new highs.
The Nasdaq and S&P 500 were up 1.1% and steady. The Dow Jones industrial average showed a 0.9% gain.

Trade came off its lows on the Nasdaq and was down only 3%. NYSE volume rose 25% compared to action near midday Wednesday. Gains were very broad, with only eight of the 197 industry groups tracked by IBD declining in morning trade.
The stock market today received a strong leg up in positive comments from the Federal Reserve on Wednesday and healthy jobs and manufacturing reports early Thursday.

Construction spending was less positive, down 0.6% in June, according to the Commerce Department. The number disappointed analyst views for a 0.4% gain and was the first decline since March, but still topped year-ago levels by 3.3%.

In stocks, data storage was among the morning's strongest segments, with Teradata (TDC) up 8% in powerful trade on strong second-quarter results. Memory card maker SanDisk (SNDK) climbed 4% in strong trade after announcing a quarterly dividend and a share repurchase initiative.

Energy stocks were generally under pressure, after both ExxonMobil (XOM) and Royal Dutch Shell (RDSA) turned in unexpectedly weak second-quarter results. One exception, Pioneer Natural Resources (PXD), leapt 13% in huge trade, the biggest gain among S&P 500 stocks. A 90% gain in adjusted earnings stopped a penny short of estimates, but revenue easily beat expectations.

Salvage auto parts distributor LKQ (LKQ) vaulted 15% higher after reporting second-quarter results. Both earnings and revenue topped analyst expectations and management saw strong increases in organic growth in both the U.S. and Europe. The gain lifted LKQ to a new high after a test of support at its 10-week moving average.

On the IBD 50 list, enterprise software maker Tangoe (TNGO) jumped 5% in better than double its average trade. The stock is just below a 52-week high, and extended after a rebound from 10-week support.

IBD 50 stock Proto Labs (PRLB) sank 7%. Its second-quarter earnings narrowly topped expectations, but revenue growth ended shy of forecasts. The slip sent shares back below a 67.50 buy point in a flat base, after briefly clearing that mark in strong trade on Wednesday.

Today's after-hours session promises to be busy, with earnings reports due out from MercadoLibre (MELI), FleetCor Technologies (FLT), AVG Technologies (AVG) and OpenTable (OPEN), among many others.Stocks hung on to broad gains in mixed trade near midday Thursday, as the Nasdaq, Dow and S&P 500 all moved to new highs.The Nasdaq and S&P 500 were up 1.1% and steady. The Dow Jones industrial average showed a 0.9% gain.Trade came off its lows on the Nasdaq and was down only 3%. NYSE volume rose 25% compared to action near midday Wednesday. Gains were very broad, with only eight of the 197 industry groups tracked by IBD declining in morning trade.The stock market today received a strong leg up in positive comments from the Federal Reserve on Wednesday and healthy jobs and manufacturing reports early Thursday.Construction spending was less positive, down 0.6% in June, according to the Commerce Department. The number disappointed analyst views for a 0.4% gain and was the first decline since March, but still topped year-ago levels by 3.3%.In stocks, data storage was among the morning's strongest segments, with Teradata (TDC) up 8% in powerful trade on strong second-quarter results. Memory card maker SanDisk (SNDK) climbed 4% in strong trade after announcing a quarterly dividend and a share repurchase initiative.Energy stocks were generally under pressure, after both ExxonMobil (XOM) and Royal Dutch Shell (RDSA) turned in unexpectedly weak second-quarter results. One exception, Pioneer Natural Resources (PXD), leapt 13% in huge trade, the biggest gain among S&P 500 stocks. A 90% gain in adjusted earnings stopped a penny short of estimates, but revenue easily beat expectations.Salvage auto parts distributor LKQ (LKQ) vaulted 15% higher after reporting second-quarter results. Both earnings and revenue topped analyst expectations and management saw strong increases in organic growth in both the U.S. and Europe. The gain lifted LKQ to a new high after a test of support at its 10-week moving average.On the IBD 50 list, enterprise software maker Tangoe (TNGO) jumped 5% in better than double its average trade. The stock is just below a 52-week high, and extended after a rebound from 10-week support.IBD 50 stock Proto Labs (PRLB) sank 7%. Its second-quarter earnings narrowly topped expectations, but revenue growth ended shy of forecasts. The slip sent shares back below a 67.50 buy point in a flat base, after briefly clearing that mark in strong trade on Wednesday.Today's after-hours session promises to be busy, with earnings reports due out from MercadoLibre (MELI), FleetCor Technologies (FLT), AVG Technologies (AVG) and OpenTable (OPEN), among many others.

Cash isn't going away yet. But most people wouldn't leave home without their plastic. Those ubiquitous credit and debit cards rack up big sales for retailers.
They also drive fat profits for the companies whose logos are on them.
Credit card giant Visa (V) posted a 60.2% pretax profit margin last year. Rival MasterCard (MA) earned 53.4%. The fleet gas card provider FleetCor Technologies (FLT) posted a 50% margin.
Those are three of the highly ranked firms in today's Healthy Profit Margins Screen of the Day.
A profit margin of 50% means the company is generating 50 cents of profit for each $1 of sales. More is better.
The commercial real estate investment trust Starwood Property Trust (STWD) tops the screen with 72.3% margin in its last full year.
Visa is No 2.
The exchanges operator IntercontinentalExchange (ICE) is a healthy No. 3 at 58.6%
Baidu (BIDU), the Google (GOOG) look-alike that dominates the Chinese search and ad market, is No. 4 with 54.9% margin last year.
The IT software developer SolarWinds (SWI) ranks No. 5 with pretax margin last year of 52.7. It's also No. 2 on the elite IBD 50 list.

Visa is No. 21 on the IBD 50. MasterCard is No. 7 on the margins screen but isn't on the IBD 50. FleetCor, No. 9 on the screen, is No. 16 on the IBD 50.Cash isn't going away yet.
